1 Overview

1.1. Features
1.2. Package Contents

Backbase Portal offers a flexible way to manage web portals. Its architecture is based on a rich presentation layer and a loosely coupled Web-Oriented Architecture, and combines content and interaction in one solution. This is most evident with widgets, independent web applications that form the portal building blocks.

With Backbase Portal, end-users can personalize the online environments, the information and the applications they need. They can also add content, adjust visualisation preferences, and rearrange layouts.

The following figure shows the main modules of Backbase Portal:

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client shows the portal and enables interaction with the widgets. It communicates with Backbase Portal Foundation on the background to store the changes the end-user makes to the portal.

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation is the main engine that receives requests from clients, retrieves objects from the data store, sends responses back to the client and stores changes in the data store. It can serve multiple portal instances. For more information, see Portal.

Mashup Services.  Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Mashup Services.

Content Services.  Content Services, an optional module, delivers local and remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Content Services.

1.1 Features

Backbase Portal Foundation

  • Multi-tenancy—Backbase Portal Foundation is capable of hosting multiple portals.

  • Data Storage—a single data store stores all portal instances (and their personalization data), Access Control List mappings, and (optionally) user credentials. This combination provides the foundation for a robust and flexible authorization and authentication mechanism.

  • Personalization—changes made by end-users to their personal Backbase Portal space are persisted from one application session to the next. The storage of personalizations is based on storing only the changes made to the original object. This method makes the data store very efficient.

  • Authentication—the use of Spring Security allows custom integration with a variety of authentication services. Backbase Portal relies on a single identity store to serve all portal instances, and can be configured to use either an external identity store or one that resides in the Backbase Portal data store. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Authorization—support for both role-based and resource-based authorization delivers a robust and flexible access control mechanism. In both cases, authorization is governed by the combination of the authenticated end-user, permissions (as defined by the groups to which an end-user belongs), and the Backbase Portal object the end-user is trying to access. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist objects, users, groups and preferences to several supported databases.

  • Portal and Page Management—a REST interface is available for managing Backbase Portal Foundation and and the portal instances it hosts. For more information, please refer to the REST API.

  • Widget Compatibility—Backbase Portal supports multiple widget formats, including Backbase Portal 4 gadgets.

  • Widget Library—out-of-the-box widgets are available for common end-user tasks, including a login page.

Content Services

  • Content Aggregation—data imported from remote content sources is stored in the Content Services content repository.

  • Installation—Content Services is delivered as a web application (WAR file) that can be deployed to one or more J2EE application servers.

  • Integration—CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) and WebDAV interfaces for working with content.

  • Administration—JMX (Java Management Extensions) interface for managing and monitoring the delivery service.

  • Scalability—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for a variety of backend technologies, including enterprise-level databases and JCR (Java Content Repository).

  • Performance—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for optimal delivery.

  • Failover—support for clustering means that requests can be routed to different Content Services instances if one instance is unavailable.

  • Importers—an optional Content Services component for importing external feeds.

  • Schedulers—for automated import of content.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist content to several supported databases.

Mashup Services

  • Proxy Service—proxying is needed to overcome the same-origin security policy that modern browsers apply to AJAX calls. To request resources (such as an XML file or application) from other intranet or Internet domains, Proxy Services proxies the request to the remote resource.

  • Transformation Service—provides filters and transformers that act on the request/response workflow.

  • Caching Service—improves performance by writing requested resources to cache. The default caching mechanism is implemented using Ehcache.

Top

1.2 Package Contents

The installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) includes the following:

  • Web and Java applications

    • portal-dev-5.3.1.0.war — Backbase Portal Foundation

    • contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war — Content Services

    • mashup-web-5.3.1.0.war — Mashup Services stand-alone application

    • orchestrator-5.3.1.0.war — Orchestrator

    Note

    If you want to develop Backbase Portal, it is recommended to set up a portal project instead of installing one of the delivered WAR files directly, see Development Setup.

  • Documentation

    • Product documentation of Backbase Portal

  • Configuration

    • Database scripts

2 Install Backbase Portal Foundation

2.1. Databases
2.2. Application Servers

You can find the Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file in the installation package.

Note

If you want to develop Backbase Portal, it is recommended to set up a portal project instead of installing one of the delivered WAR files directly, see Development Setup.

If you are working with a portal project, you can package it into a WAR file, see Package the Project.

This topic describes how to install a Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file (whether from the installation package or created from a portal project).

Installation Prerequisites

The server that will host the portal needs to meet the following requirements:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • A database, see Databases.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

  • Content Services (optional), see Install Content Services.

Installation Procedure

  1. Database setup

    Setup a supported database. See Databases.

  2. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  3. Deploy on application server

    Deploy the WAR file on a supported application server. See Application Servers.

  4. Test installation

    Open the Backbase Portal Foundation URL in a browser:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext

    The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 2.1. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    If the installation was successful, a welcome message should appear on the screen.

  5. Enable Audit Trails (optional)

    To enable Audit Trails, see Install Audit Trails.

2.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Backbase Portal Foundation.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Create a schema named, for example, bbdbfoundation and a user. Log in to MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create schema

    Create schemas by running the following command:

    CREATE SCHEMA schema_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user and assign it a password:

    CREATE USER 'user_name'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

  3. Grant privileges

    Grant the user all privileges on the schema:

    GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on schema_name.* to 'user_name'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  4. Populate the database

    The scripts to populate the database are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    1. Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects, or copy the file contents and paste them to the MySQL command line.

    2. Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

      mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

Oracle

Create a user named, for example, bbdbfoundation and a schema. Log in to the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create user

    Create a user, assign it a password, and unlock the account:

    CREATE USER user_name
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE user
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

  2. Grant privileges

    Grant the user privileges to create tables, views, and sequences, then grant it unlimited tablespace:

    GRANT create session TO user_name;
GRANT create table TO user_name;
GRANT create view TO user_name;
GRANT create sequence TO user_name;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO user_name;

  3. Create schema

    Create a schema as system user:

    CREATE SCHEMA AUTHORIZATION user_name;

  4. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the scripts schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql that will populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    @schema.ddl
@default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

IBM DB2

Create a database named, for example, bbfound and a user.

  1. Create database

    Create a Standard database with a Default bufferpool and table space page size of 32K and UTF-8 codeset.

  2. Create user

    Create a user account on the operating system.

  3. Grant rights

    Add the user to the database and grant it authorities. A minimum set is: Connect, Create tables, Create packages, Create schemas implicitly, Access Load Utility, and Connect to quiesced database.

    Create a schema for the database and set its Authorization name to the operating system user.

  4. Populate the database

    Connect to the database and run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    db2 -tvf schema.ddl
db2 -tvf default-foundation-data-blank.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

Microsoft SQL Server

Create a database named, for example, bbdbfoundation and a user. Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

  1. Create database

  2. Set transaction isolation level

    Run the following commands:

    ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

  3. Create user

    Create a schema, then create a user.

    In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  4. Populate the database

    The scripts to populate the database are located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    1. Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects.

    2. Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

2.2 Application Servers

This section explains how to deploy Backbase Portal Foundation on specific application servers.

Apache Tomcat

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the Apache Tomcat installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 2.2. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  2. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  3. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    foundation.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.foundation.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
foundation.ptc.profile=ptc-[local|remote]
foundation.environment.editorial=[true|false]

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 2.3. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. Setting it to remote disables the embedded instance of Mashup Services.

    4. Set foundation.environment.editorial to true if this instance of Backbase Portal Foundation is an editorial environment, and to false if it is a staging or live environment.

    5. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

    Note

    If you want to enable Audit Trails, set the additional properties as explained in Install Audit Trails.

  4. Set HTTP only (only Apache Tomcat 7)

    This step only applies to Apache Tomcat 7. Find the <Context> definition in the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Replace <Context> with <Context useHttpOnly="false">.

  5. Create datasource

    Create a datasource jdbc/portalDS by copying the following resource tag to the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder:

    <Resource name="resource_name"
 auth="Container"
 type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 maxActive="4"
 maxIdle="2"
 username="user_name"
 password="password"
 maxWait="5000"
 validationQuery="select 1"
 driverClassName="jdbc_driver_class"
 url="database_url"/>

    Follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 2.4. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 2.5. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  6. Enable UTF-8 support

    Open the conf/server.xml file located in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Add the attribute URIEncoding="UTF-8" to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run.

    For example:

    <Connector port="8080" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
    connectionTimeout="20000"
    URIEncoding="UTF-8"
    redirectPort="8443" />

  7. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

  8. Deploy the WAR file

    Change the WAR file name to portalserver.war (to set the context root). Deploy the WAR file with the Tomcat Web Application Manager.

    Note

    If a URL redirection changes the application context root, use the this.config.resourceRoot and this.config.serverRoot parameters in the portal.js file to reset the resources and REST Interface contexts, respectively.

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

WebSphere

Follow these steps to deploy Backbase Portal Foundation on WebSphere. If you are planning to enable Audit Trails, follow the steps listed in Install Audit Trails first.

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the WebSphere installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 2.6. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  2. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  3. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    foundation.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.foundation.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
foundation.ptc.profile=ptc-[local|remote]
foundation.environment.editorial=[true|false]

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 2.7. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. Setting it to remote disables the embedded instance of Mashup Services.

    4. Set foundation.environment.editorial to true if this instance of Backbase Portal Foundation is an editorial environment, and to false if it is a staging or live environment.

    5. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

    Note

    If you want to enable Audit Trails, set the additional properties as explained in Install Audit Trails.

  4. Create JDBC provider

    Navigate to Resources > JDBC > JDBC Providers and create a JDBC provider.

    • For IBM DB2, Microsoft SQL Server and Oracle, let WebSphere determine the settings. Set the Database type, set Provider type to a JDBC driver, and Implementation type to Connection pool data source.

    • For MySQL, select User-defined as Database type. Enter com.mysql.jdbc.jdbc2.optional.MysqlConnectionPoolDataSource as Implementation class name.

  5. Create JC2 authentication alias

    1. Navigate to Security > Global security > Java Authentication and Authorization Service > J2C authentication data and create a new JC2 authentication alias.

    2. Enter a name for the Alias and the database username and password.

  6. Create datasource

    Follow these pointers when creating the datasource portalDS:

    1. Set both the Data source name and the JNDI name to the same data source name mentioned above.

    2. Select the J2C authentication alias created in the previous steps.

    3. Select the JDBC provider created in the previous steps.

    4. Fill out the database properties according to your database setup.

    5. Deselect the Use this data source in container managed persistence (CMP) option.

    6. For MySQL, reopen the data source and edit the database URL via the Custom Properties link. For MySQL the default URL is: jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true.

    7. For IBM DB2 running on Unix, reopen the data source and edit the deferPrepares property via the Custom Properties link. Set the property value to false.

    8. Test the data source. Open the data source and click Test connection.

  7. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

  8. Deploy the WAR file

    Deploy the WAR file. If you are deploying on WebSphere 6.1 with Web Services Feature Pack, follow the additional steps for WebSphere 6.1 with Web Services Feature Pack. Set the context root to portalserver and map the jdbc/portalDS resource reference to the portalDS datasource.

    If you want to enable Audit Trails, map the auditDS resource reference to the auditDS datasource.

    Note

    If a URL redirection changes the application context root, use the this.config.resourceRoot and this.config.serverRoot parameters in the portal.js file to reset the resources and REST Interface contexts, respectively.

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

JBoss

  1. Decompress the WAR file

    The following steps apply to the WAR file generated by Maven as well as the Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). Decompress the relevant WAR file.

  2. Remove conflicting dependencies

    Remove xercesImpl-2.9.1.jar, stax-api-1.0.1.jar, stax-api-1.0-2.jar, and xml-apis-1.3.04.jar from the application dependencies located in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file.

  3. Re-compress the WAR file

    From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

    jar -cvf portalserver.war *

    Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

  4. Install the JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/lib folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 2.8. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  5. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  6. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    foundation.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.foundation.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
foundation.ptc.profile=ptc-[local|remote]
foundation.environment.editorial=[true|false]

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 2.9. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. Setting it to remote disables the embedded instance of Mashup Services.

    4. Set foundation.environment.editorial to true if this instance of Backbase Portal Foundation is an editorial environment, and to false if it is a staging or live environment.

    5. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

    Note

    If you want to enable Audit Trails, set the additional properties as explained in Install Audit Trails.

  7. Create datasource definition

    Create a datasource definition file in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy directory. The name of the file is database-ds.xml. Replace database with the database you use, e.g. mysql-ds.xml:

    Table 2.10. Database Parameters

    Database

    Parameter

    MySQL

    mysql

    Oracle

    oracle

    IBM DB2

    db2

    Microsoft SQL Server

    sqlserver

    H2

    h2


    You can find examples in jboss_install_dir/docs/example/jca.

    Create a datasource named jdbc/portalDS by copying the following lines to the datasource file:

    <datasources>
    <local-tx-datasource>
        <jndi-name>resource_name</jndi-name>
        <connection-url>database_url</connection-url>
        <driver-class>jdbc_driver_class</driver-class>
        <user-name>user_name</user-name>
        <password>password</password>
        <!--pooling parameters-->
        <min-pool-size>5</min-pool-size>
        <max-pool-size>100</max-pool-size>
        <blocking-timeout-millis>5000</blocking-timeout-millis>
        <idle-timeout-minutes>15</idle-timeout-minutes>
        <!-- sql to call on an existing pooled connection when it is obtained from pool -->
        <check-valid-connection-sql>select 1 from dual</check-valid-connection-sql>
        <query-timeout>300</query-timeout> <!-- maximum of 5 minutes for queries -->
    </local-tx-datasource>
</datasources>

    Follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 2.11. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 2.12. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  8. Enable UTF-8 support

    Open the server.xml files in jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/jboss-web.deployer and in jboss_install_dir/server/all/deploy/jboss-web.deployer. In both files, add the attribute URIEncoding="UTF-8" to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run.

    For example:

    <Connector port="8080" URIEncoding="UTF-8" address="${jboss.bind.address}"
    maxThreads="250" maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"/>

  9. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

    • -Dorg.apache.catalina.STRICT_SERVLET_COMPLIANCE=false — disables strict servlet compliance.

  10. Deploy the WAR file

    Deploy the WAR file in JBoss either by using the JBoss Web Manager or by dropping the WAR file into the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy directory.

Continue with Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

WebSphere 6.1 with Web Services Feature Pack

Follow these additional steps to deploy on WebSphere 6.1 installations with Web Services Feature Pack:

  1. Click Applications > Install New Application from the left-hand navigation bar.

  2. Select either Local file system or Remote file system according to your installation, then click on the Browse... button and navigate to the location of the .war file. Set the Context root to portalserver in the relevant field, select Show me all installation options and parameters and click on Next.

  3. Click Next on the screen titled Preparing for the application installation, then click Continue on the screen titled Application Security Warnings.

  4. Check the box labelled Precompile JavaServer Pages files in the screen titled Install New Application, then click on the Next button until you reach the step titled Provide options to compile JSPs.

  5. Change the value of JDK Source Level to 15 (the default is 13), then click on the Next button until you reach the step titled Summary.

  6. Review the installation options and click on Finish.

3 Install Content Services

3.1. Databases
3.2. Application Servers
Installation Prerequisites

Prior to installation, check that the following requirements are met:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • A database, see Databases.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Installation Procedure

  1. Database setup

    Setup a supported database on the server that will host Content Services, see Databases.

  2. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  3. Deploy on application server

    Deploy the WAR file on a supported application server, see Application Servers.

  4. Test installation

    Open the Content Services URL in a browser:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext

    The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 3.1. Content Services URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Content Services.

    port

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    contentservices

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


3.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Content Services.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Create three schemas named, for example, bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent, and bbdbresource and users. Log in to MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool as administrator and repeat the following steps for each schema:

  1. Create schema

    Create schemas by running the following command:

    CREATE SCHEMA schema_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user and assign it a password:

    CREATE USER 'user_name'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

  3. Grant privileges

    Grant the user all privileges on the schema:

    GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on schema_name.* to 'user_name'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  4. Populate the database

    Run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script to create the database objects. The script is located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/mysql folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    To run the script from the command line, type the following:

    mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < create-schema-bbcs.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Content Services.

Oracle

Create three users named, for example, bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent, and bbdbresource and schemas. Log in to the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator and repeat the following steps for each user:

  1. Create user

    Create a user, assign it a password, and unlock the account:

    CREATE USER user_name
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE user
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

  2. Grant privileges

    Grant the user privileges to create tables, views, and sequences, then grant it unlimited tablespace:

    GRANT create session TO user_name;
GRANT create table TO user_name;
GRANT create view TO user_name;
GRANT create sequence TO user_name;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO user_name;

  3. Create schema

    Create a schema as system user:

    CREATE SCHEMA AUTHORIZATION user_name;

  4. Populate the database

    Log in as each of the users you created and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/oracle folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Content Services.

IBM DB2

Create three databases named, respectively, bbdbconf, bbdbcont, and bbdbres and users. Repeat the following steps in the IBM DB2 Control Center for each database:

  1. Create user

    Create a user account on the operating system.

  2. Create database

    Create a Standard database with a Default bufferpool and table space page size of 32K and UTF-8 codeset.

  3. Grant rights

    Add the user to the database and grant it authorities. A minimum set is: Connect, Create tables, Create packages, Create schemas implicitly, Access Load Utility, and Connect to quiesced database.

    Create a schema for the database and set its Authorization name to the operating system user.

  4. Populate the database

    Connect to the database and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/db2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following command:

    db2 -tvf create-schema-bbcs.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Content Services.

Microsoft SQL Server

Create three databases named, respectively, bbdbconfiguration, bbdbcontent, and bbdbresource and users. Repeat the following steps in Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio for each database:

  1. Create database

  2. Set transaction isolation level

    Run the following commands:

    ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

  3. Create user

    Create a schema, then create a user.

    In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  4. Populate the database

    Select each of the three schemas and run the create-schema-bbcs.sql script to create the database objects.

    The script is located in the configuration/contentservices/scripts/sqlserver folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop-schema-bbcs.sql script located in configuration/contentservices/scripts/sqlserver in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Content Services.

3.2 Application Servers

This section explains how to deploy Content Services to specific application servers.

Apache Tomcat

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the Apache Tomcat installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 3.2. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    jTDS JDBC Driver


  2. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  3. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    contentservices.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.configuration.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
database.content.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
database.resource.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 3.3. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  4. Create datasources

    Create three datasources named, respectively, jdbc/configuration-datasource, jdbc/content-datasource and jdbc/resource-datasource. For each datasource, copy the following resource tag to the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder:

    <Resource name="resource_name"
 auth="Container"
 type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 maxActive="4"
 maxIdle="2"
 username="user_name"
 password="password"
 maxWait="5000"
 validationQuery="select 1"
 driverClassName="jdbc_driver_class"
 url="database_url"/>

    For each datasource, follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 3.4. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbc.Driver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 3.5. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://localhost:1433/database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  5. Enable UTF-8 support

    Open the conf/server.xml file located in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Add the attribute URIEncoding="UTF-8" to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run.

    For example:

    <Connector port="8080" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
    connectionTimeout="20000"
    URIEncoding="UTF-8"
    redirectPort="8443" />

  6. Enable response compression (optional)

    Open the conf/server.xml file located in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Add the following attributes to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run. For example, if the application server uses port 8080:

    <Connector port="8080" protocol="HTTP/1.1"
    ....
    compression="on"
    compressionMinSize="2048"
    noCompressionUserAgents="gozilla, traviata"
    compressableMimeType="text/html,text/xml"/>

    Compressed responses will greatly reduce data transfer to and from Content Services.

  7. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

  8. Deploy the WAR file

    Retrieve the contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file from the war directory in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). Rename the WAR file to contentservices.war, then deploy the WAR file using Apache Tomcat Manager App, or by copying it in the appBase (by default, the $CATALINA_HOME/webapps folder).

Continue installing Install Content Services.

WebSphere

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the WebSphere installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    JDBC Driver

    IBM DB2

  2. Logback configuration

The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. Add the following lines:

database.configuration.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
database.content.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
database.resource.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 3.7. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

    3. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  4. Create JDBC provider

    Navigate to Resources > JDBC > JDBC Providers and create a JDBC provider.

    • For IBM DB2, Microsoft SQL Server and Oracle, let WebSphere determine the settings. Set the Database type, set Provider type to a JDBC driver, and Implementation type to Connection pool data source.

    • For MySQL, select User-defined as Database type. Enter net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbcx.JtdsDataSource as Implementation class name.

  5. Create JC2 authentication aliases

    Create three new JC2 authentication aliases named, respectively, content, configuration and resource.

    Follow these steps to create aliases:

    1. Navigate to Security > Global security > Java Authentication and Authorization Service > J2C authentication data and create a new JC2 authentication alias.

    2. Enter a name for the Alias and the database username and password.

  6. Create datasources

    Create three datasources named, respectively, content-ds, configuration-ds and resource-ds.

    Follow these pointers when creating the datasource:

    1. Set both the Data source name and the JNDI name to the same data source name mentioned above.

    2. Select the J2C authentication alias created in the previous steps.

    3. Select the JDBC provider created in the previous steps.

    4. Fill out the database properties according to your database setup.

    5. Deselect the Use this data source in container managed persistence (CMP) option.

    6. For MySQL, reopen the data source and edit the database URL via the Custom Properties link. For MySQL the default URL is: jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true.

    7. For IBM DB2 running on Unix, reopen the data source and edit the deferPrepares property via the Custom Properties link. Set the property value to false.

    8. Test the data source. Open the data source and click Test connection.

  7. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

  8. Installations running the Web Services feature pack

    Special steps are required for WebSphere installations running the Web Services feature pack. See WebSphere with Web Services Feature Pack for a detailed explanation.

  9. Deploy the WAR file

    Retrieve the contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file from the war directory in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

    In the Administration Console, select Applications → Enterprise Applications → Install. Select the Content Services WAR file and enter contentservices as content root. Check the option Show me all installation options and parameters.

    In the deployment wizard, accept the steps in the wizard with default values, except for the following steps:

    • Map modules to servers — if necessary, modify the values for local needs

    • Map resources references to resources — match each resource reference to the corresponding datasource

  10. Replace JAR (only for WebSphere 7.0)

    In the unpacked WAR of Content Services, find the lib folder. Remove the chemistry-opencmis-client-binding-0.6.jar and replace it with chemistry-opencmis-client-binding-websphere-0.6.jar. You can download the JAR file here: www.jarvana.com/jarvana/browse/org/apache/chemistry/opencmis/chemistry-opencmis-client-bindings-websphere/0.6.0/.

Continue installing Install Content Services.

JBoss

  1. Decompress the WAR file

    Decompress the contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

  2. Remove conflicting dependencies

    Remove jcl-over-slf4j-1.6.1.jar, log4j-over-slf4j-1.6.1.jar, slf4j-api-1.6.1.jar, and stax-api-1.0.1.jar from the application dependencies located in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file.

  3. Re-compress the WAR file

    From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

    jar -cvf contentservices.war *

    Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

  4. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/lib folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 3.8. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    Connector/J

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    jTDS JDBC Driver


  5. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

  6. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines:

database.content.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

    3. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  7. Create datasource definitions

    Create a datasource definition file in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy directory. The name of the file is database-ds.xml. Replace database with the database you use, e.g. mysql-ds.xml:

    You can find examples in jboss_install_dir/docs/example/jca.

    Create three datasources named, respectively, jdbc/configuration-datasource, jdbc/content-datasource and jdbc/resource-datasource. For each datasource, copy the local-tx-datasource tag between <datasources> tags in the datasource file:

    <datasources>

        <jndi-name>resource_name</jndi-name>

        <!--pooling parameters-->

        <max-pool-size>100</max-pool-size>
        <blocking-timeout-millis>5000</blocking-timeout-millis>
        <idle-timeout-minutes>15</idle-timeout-minutes>
        <!-- sql to call on an existing pooled connection when it is obtained from pool -->
        <check-valid-connection-sql>select 1 from dual</check-valid-connection-sql>
        <query-timeout>300</query-timeout> <!-- maximum of 5 minutes for queries -->
    </local-tx-datasource>
</datasources>

    For each datasource, follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 3.11. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      net.sourceforge.jtds.jdbc.Driver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 3.12. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://localhost:1433/database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  8. Enable UTF-8 support

    Open the server.xml files in jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/jboss-web.deployer and in jboss_install_dir/server/all/deploy/jboss-web.deployer. In both files, add the attribute URIEncoding="UTF-8" to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run.

    For example:

    <Connector port="8080" URIEncoding="UTF-8" address="${jboss.bind.address}"
    maxThreads="250" maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"/>

  9. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

    • -Dorg.apache.catalina.STRICT_SERVLET_COMPLIANCE=false — disables strict servlet compliance.

  10. Deploy the WAR file

    Deploy the WAR file in JBoss either by using the JBoss Web Manager or by dropping the WAR file into the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy folder.

Continue installing Install Content Services.

WebSphere with Web Services Feature Pack

Deployment on WebSphere installations running the Web Services feature pack additionally needs the steps described below:

  1. Open the contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file and delete the WEB-INF/wsdl folder.

  2. Open the chemistry-opencmis-server-bindings-0.6.0.jar file in the WEB-INF/lib folder. Delete the following classes from the org/apache/chemistry/opencmis/server/impl/webservices/ folder in the jar file:

    • AclService.class

    • DiscoveryService.class

    • MultiFilingService.class

    • NavigationService.class

    • ObjectService.class

    • PolicyService.class

    • RelationshipService.class

    • RepositoryService.class

    • VersioningService.class

  3. Modify the web.xml file in the WEB-INF folder and comment out the WSServletContextListener listener-class.

  4. Repack the contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file and proceed to Step 9.

4 Install Orchestrator

4.1. Databases
4.2. Configuration
4.3. Application Servers
Installation Prerequisites

Prior to installation, check that the following requirements are met:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

  • A running instance of Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

Installation Procedure

  1. Database setup

    Setup a supported database. See Databases.

  2. Create storage folder

    Create a folder on the file system to store publishing requests. And name it, for example, fileStore.

  3. Configure Orchestrator

    Create a configuration file, see Configuration.

  4. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  5. Deploy on application server

    Deploy the orchestrator-5.3.1.0.war file on a supported application server. See Application Servers.

  6. Test installation

    Point your browser to one of these Orchestrator URLs:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext/workpackages
http://host:port/applicationcontext/configuration

    The URLs consist of the following parts:

    Table 4.1. Orchestrator URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Orchestrator.

    port

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    orchestrator

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    The URLs should show XML content.

4.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Orchestrator.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Create a schema named, for example, bbdborchestrator and a user. Log in to MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create schema

    Create schemas by running the following command:

    CREATE SCHEMA schema_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user and assign it a password:

    CREATE USER 'user_name'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

  3. Grant privileges

    Grant the user all privileges on the schema:

    GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on schema_name.* to 'user_name'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  4. Populate the database

    Run the create_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/mysql in your portal project and in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). This script creates the necessary database tables. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

    mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < create_database.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

Oracle

Create a user named, for example, bbdborchestrator and a schema. Log in to the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create user

    Create a user, assign it a password, and unlock the account:

    CREATE USER user_name
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE user
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

  2. Grant privileges

    Grant the user privileges to create tables, views, and sequences, then grant it unlimited tablespace:

    GRANT create session TO user_name;
GRANT create table TO user_name;
GRANT create view TO user_name;
GRANT create sequence TO user_name;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO user_name;

  3. Create schema

    Create a schema as system user:

    CREATE SCHEMA AUTHORIZATION user_name;

  4. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the create_database.sql script located in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/oracle folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

IBM DB2

Create a database named, for example, bbdborch and a user.

  1. Create database

    Create a Standard database with a Default bufferpool and table space page size of 32K and UTF-8 codeset.

  2. Create user

    Create a user account on the operating system.

  3. Grant rights

    Add the user to the database and grant it authorities. A minimum set is: Connect, Create tables, Create packages, Create schemas implicitly, Access Load Utility, and Connect to quiesced database.

    Create a schema for the database and set its Authorization name to the operating system user.

  4. Populate the database

    Connect to the database and run the create_database.sql script located in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/db2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). The script creates the necessary database tables.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following command:

    db2 -tvf create_database.sql

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

Microsoft SQL Server

Create a database named, for example, bbdborchestrator and a user. Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

  1. Create database

  2. Set transaction isolation level

    Run the following commands:

    ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

  3. Create user

    Create a schema, then create a user.

    In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  4. Populate the database

    Log in with the user you just created and run the create_database.sql script located in the configuration/orchestrator/scripts/sqlserver2008 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Note

If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_database.sql script located in configuration/orchestrator/scripts/sqlserver2008 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

4.2 Configuration

Create an XML configuration file and store it somewhere on the file system. In a later installation step, you will enter this file location in a properties file. You can find examples of configuration files in the configuration/orchestrator/examples folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

Below are examples for the configuration of Orchestrator for an editorial, staging or live environment. Also, for testing or demo purposes, a configuration of Orchestrator within one environment. For more information on the various environments a Backbase Portal implementation ideally needs, see Release Management.

Editorial

The following configuration is an example for an Orchestrator running on an editorial environment.

Note

For more information on the tags in this configuration file, see Publishing Configuration.

Please enter all host, port, user_name and password in the example below. Replace storage_folder_path with the full path of the storage folder you created in Step 2.

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<configuration>
    <name>OrchestratorEditorial</name>
    <description>This Orchestrator publishes from the editorial environment to staging and live.</description>
    <editorial>true</editorial>
    <fileStoreLocation>storage_folder_path</fileStoreLocation>
    <bundleStreamBufferSize>1024</bundleStreamBufferSize>
    <username>user_name</username>
    <password>password</password>
    <approvalGroups>
        <approvalGroup>admin</approvalGroup>
    </approvalGroups>
    <publishGroups>
        <publishGroup>admin</publishGroup>
        <publishGroup>master page editor</publishGroup>
    </publishGroups>

    <hosts>
        <host>
            <name>PortalFoundationEditorial</name>
            <hostType>PORTAL_SERVER</hostType>
            <address>portal_foundation_host</address>
            <port>portal_foundation_port</port>
            <contextPath>portalserver</contextPath>
            <user>sys2sys</user>
            <password>sys2sys</password>
        </host>
    </hosts>

    <cmsHost>
        <name>ContentServicesEditorial</name>
        <hostType>CONTENT_SERVICES</hostType>
        <address>content_services_host</address>
        <port>content_services_port</port>
        <contextPath>contentservices/atom</contextPath>
        <user>user_name</user>
        <password>password</password>
        <repositoryId>contentRepository</repositoryId>
        <lockStrategy>checkoutlocking</lockStrategy>
    </cmsHost>

    <targetOrchestrators>
        <host>
            <name>OrchestratorStaging</name>
            <hostType>ORCHESTRATOR</hostType>
            <address>orchestrator_staging_host</address>
            <port>orchestrator_staging_port</port>
            <contextPath>orchestrator</contextPath>
            <user>user_name</user>
            <password>password</password>
        </host>
        <host>
            <name>OrchestratorLive</name>
            <hostType>ORCHESTRATOR</hostType>
            <address>orchestrator_live_host</address>
            <port>orchestrator_live_port</port>
            <contextPath>orchestrator</contextPath>
            <user>user_name</user>
            <password>password</password>
        </host>
    </targetOrchestrators>
    <publishChains>
        <publishChain>
            <publishChainName>MainPublishingChain</publishChainName>
            <publishChainElements>
                <publishChainElement>
                    <targetOrchestrator>OrchestratorStaging</targetOrchestrator>
                    <requiresApproval>true</requiresApproval>
                    <publishChainElements>
                        <publishChainElement>
                            <targetOrchestrator>OrchestratorLive</targetOrchestrator>
                        </publishChainElement>
                    </publishChainElements>
                </publishChainElement>
            </publishChainElements>
        </publishChain>
    </publishChains>
</configuration>

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

                    <portalMappings>

                            <sourcePortal>myportal</sourcePortal>
                            <targetPortal>myportal_staging</targetPortal>
                        </portalMapping>
                    </portalMappings>
                    <publishChainElements>
                        <publishChainElement>
                            <targetOrchestrator>OrchestratorTest</targetOrchestrator>

                                </portalMapping>
                            </portalMappings>
                        </publishChainElement>
                    </publishChainElements>
                </publishChainElement>
            </publishChainElements>
        </publishChain>
    </publishChains>
</configuration>
