4.3 Application Servers

This section explains how to deploy the Orchestrator on specific application servers.

Apache Tomcat

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver in the lib folder in the Apache Tomcat installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 4.2. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  2. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  3. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    orchestrator.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.orchestrator.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
orchestrator.configuration.location=config_file_path

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 4.3. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set the path and file name of the Orchestrator configuration created in Step 3. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    4. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  4. Set HTTP only (only Apache Tomcat 7)

    This step only applies to Apache Tomcat 7. Find the <Context> definition in the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder. Replace <Context> with <Context useHttpOnly="false">.

  5. Create datasource

    Create a datasource named jdbc/orchestratorDS by copying the following resource tag to the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder:

    <Resource name="resource_name"
 auth="Container"
 type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 maxActive="4"
 maxIdle="2"
 username="user_name"
 password="password"
 maxWait="5000"
 validationQuery="select 1"
 driverClassName="jdbc_driver_class"
 url="database_url"/>

    Follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 4.4. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 4.5. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  6. Deploy the WAR file

    The orchestrator-5.3.1.0.war file is located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). Rename the WAR file to orchestrator.war to set the application context to orchestrator and deploy it.

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

WebSphere

  1. Install JDBC driver

    Install a JDBC driver within the WebSphere installation folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 4.6. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  2. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  3. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    orchestrator.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.orchestrator.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
orchestrator.configuration.location=config_file_path

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 4.7. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set the path and file name of the Orchestrator configuration created in Step 3. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    4. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  4. Create JDBC provider

    Navigate to Resources > JDBC > JDBC Providers and create a JDBC provider.

    • For IBM DB2, Microsoft SQL Server and Oracle, let WebSphere determine the settings. Set the Database type, set Provider type to a JDBC driver, and Implementation type to Connection pool data source.

    • For MySQL, select User-defined as Database type. Enter com.mysql.jdbc.jdbc2.optional.MysqlConnectionPoolDataSource as Implementation class name.

  5. Create JC2 authentication alias

    1. Navigate to Security > Global security > Java Authentication and Authorization Service > J2C authentication data and create a new JC2 authentication alias.

    2. Enter a name for the Alias and the database username and password.

  6. Create datasource

    Follow these pointers when creating a datasource named orchestratorDS:

    1. Set both the Data source name and the JNDI name to the same data source name mentioned above.

    2. Select the J2C authentication alias created in the previous steps.

    3. Select the JDBC provider created in the previous steps.

    4. Fill out the database properties according to your database setup.

    5. Deselect the Use this data source in container managed persistence (CMP) option.

    6. For MySQL, reopen the data source and edit the database URL via the Custom Properties link. For MySQL the default URL is: jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true.

    7. For IBM DB2 running on Unix, reopen the data source and edit the deferPrepares property via the Custom Properties link. Set the property value to false.

    8. Test the data source. Open the data source and click Test connection.

  7. Deploy the WAR file

    Follow these steps to deploy the Orchestrator WAR file located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip):

    1. In the administrative console go to Applications > Enterprise Applications. Click on Install.

    2. Enter the path to the Orchestrator WAR file in the Local file system panel. Set the Context root to orchestrator, the click on Next.

    3. Skip to Step 3: Map resource references to resources. Select Use default method (many-to-one mapping), select dbCreds from the dropdown menu and tick the orchestrator.war checkbox.

    4. In the Target Resource JNDI Name cell, click on Browse... and pick orchestratorDS, then click Apply.

      Click on Next until you are presented with the Summary.

      Review the menu summary and click on Finish.

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

JBoss

  1. Decompress the WAR file

    Decompress the orchestrator-5.3.1.0.war file located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip).

  2. Remove conflicting dependencies

    Remove the stax-api-1.0.1.jar, stax-api-1.0-2.jar, and xml-apis-1.3.04.jar files from the application dependencies located in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file.

  3. Re-compress the WAR file

    From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

    jar -cvf orchestrator.war *

    Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

  4. Install JDBC driver

    This step is only necessary if you are using a database other than H2. Install a JDBC driver in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/lib folder.

    The JDBC driver needs to be compatible with the following:

    • Database you are using

    • JDK you are using

    • JDBC API 4.0 specification

    • JDBC Type 4

    The following table shows a list of compatible drivers:

    Table 4.8. JDBC Driver

    Database

    JDBC Driver

    MySQL

    Connector/J

    Oracle

    Select a compatible driver for your database and JDK version: Oracle 11 JDBC Drivers

    IBM DB2

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers

    The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar

    Microsoft SQL Server

    Microsoft SQL Server JDBC Driver


  5. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system. The archetype contains an example of this file in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project, see Development Setup Procedure. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  6. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    orchestrator.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.orchestrator.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
orchestrator.configuration.location=config_file_path

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 4.9. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set the path and file name of the Orchestrator configuration created in Step 3. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    4. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  7. Create datasource definition

    Create a datasource definition file in the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy directory. The name of the file is database-ds.xml. Replace database with the database you use, e.g. mysql-ds.xml:

    Table 4.10. Database Parameters

    Database

    Parameter

    MySQL

    mysql

    Oracle

    oracle

    IBM DB2

    db2

    Microsoft SQL Server

    sqlserver

    H2

    h2


    You can find examples in jboss_install_dir/docs/example/jca.

    Create a datasource named jdbc/orchestratorDS by copying the following lines to the datasource file:

    <datasources>
    <local-tx-datasource>
        <jndi-name>resource_name</jndi-name>
        <connection-url>database_url</connection-url>
        <driver-class>jdbc_driver_class</driver-class>
        <user-name>user_name</user-name>
        <password>password</password>
        <!--pooling parameters-->
        <min-pool-size>5</min-pool-size>
        <max-pool-size>100</max-pool-size>
        <blocking-timeout-millis>5000</blocking-timeout-millis>
        <idle-timeout-minutes>15</idle-timeout-minutes>
        <!-- sql to call on an existing pooled connection when it is obtained from pool -->
        <check-valid-connection-sql>select 1 from dual</check-valid-connection-sql>
        <query-timeout>300</query-timeout> <!-- maximum of 5 minutes for queries -->
    </local-tx-datasource>
</datasources>

    Follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 4.11. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 4.12. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

  8. Enable UTF-8 support

    Open the server.xml files in jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/jboss-web.deployer and in jboss_install_dir/server/all/deploy/jboss-web.deployer. In both files, add the attribute URIEncoding="UTF-8" to the Connector definition corresponding to the port on which the application will run.

    For example:

    <Connector port="8080" URIEncoding="UTF-8" address="${jboss.bind.address}"
    maxThreads="250" maxHttpHeaderSize="8192"/>

  9. Deploy the WAR file

    Make sure the WAR file is named orchestrator.war and deploy it.

Continue installing Install Orchestrator.

5 Install Mashup Services

Mashup Services is a module that offers proxy capabilities to Backbase Portal. It comes embedded with Backbase Portal Foundation by default, but one can install it stand-alone on a separate environment.

Follow these instructions to install Mashup Services stand-alone.

Installation Prerequisites

Prior to installation, check that the following requirements are met:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • An application server, see Application Servers.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Installation Procedure

The following steps explain how to install Mashup Services on a stand-alone system:

  1. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  2. Change properties configuration

    Open the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation. Set the foundation.ptc.profile property to ptc-remote:

    foundation.ptc.profile=ptc-remote

  3. Configuration

    Create a file named ptc-config.xml and configure Mashup Services as explained in Proxy Configuration File.

  4. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    ptc.configfile.location=file:configuration_file_path/ptc-config.xml

    1. Enter the location of the ptc-config.xml file you created in the previous step. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

  5. Deploy the WAR file

    The mashup-web-5.3.1.0.war file is located in the war folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip). Rename the WAR file to mashupservices.war and deploy it on a supported application server. Make sure to set the application context to mashupservices.

  6. Test installation

    Open the Mashup Services URL in a browser:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext/proxy

    The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 5.1. Mashup Services Stand-alone URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Mashup Services.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    mashupservices

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.

6 Install Audit Trails

6.1. Databases
6.2. Application Servers
Installation Prerequisites

Prior to installation, check that the following requirements are met:

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

  • A database, see Databases.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Installation Procedure

Follow these steps to enable Audit Trails:

  1. Add resource to web.xml

    1. Decompress the WAR file (not when using Maven project)

      Decompress the Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file.

    2. Deployment descriptor

      Open the web.xml file located in src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project or in WEB-INF in the unpacked WAR file and uncomment the following lines:

      <resource-ref>
    <description>Portal Datasource</description>
    <res-ref-name>jdbc/auditDS</res-ref-name>
    <res-type>javax.sql.DataSource</res-type>
    <res-auth>Container</res-auth>
</resource-ref>

    3. Re-compress the WAR file (not when using Maven project)

      From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

      jar -cvf portalserver.war *

      Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

  2. Database setup

    Setup a supported database. See Databases.

  3. Setup application server

    Additional configuration of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. See Application Servers.

  4. Properties configuration

    1. Open the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation and enter the following lines:

      foundation.auditing=true
database.auditing.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 6.1. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


6.1 Databases

This section explains how to setup a database for Audit Trails.

Audit Trails uses the same database server as Backbase Portal Foundation: for example, if Backbase Portal Foundation uses IBM DB2, Audit Trails uses IBM DB2 as well.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Create a schema named, for example, bbdbaudit and a user. Log in to MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create schema

    Create schemas by running the following command:

    CREATE SCHEMA schema_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user and assign it a password:

    CREATE USER 'user_name'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

  3. Populate the database

    Run the audit_schema.ddl script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

    Note

    If you need to re-configure the database, run the audit_drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/mysql in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

  4. Grant privileges

    Grant the user the SELECT and INSERT privileges on the database:

    GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON schema.AUDIT_EVENTS TO 'user_name'@'localhost';

Continue with Install Audit Trails.

Oracle

Create a user named, for example, bbdbaudit and a schema. Log in to the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create schema

    Create a schema as system user:

    CREATE SCHEMA AUTHORIZATION user_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user, assign it a password, and unlock the account:

    CREATE USER user_name
PROFILE DEFAULT
IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE user
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp
ACCOUNT UNLOCK;

  3. Populate the database

    Run the audit_schema.ddl script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

    Note

    If you need to re-configure the database, run the audit_drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/oracle in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

  4. Grant privileges

    Grant the user the SELECT and INSERT privileges on the AUDIT_EVENTS table:

    GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON AUDIT_EVENTS TO user_name;

Continue with Install Audit Trails.

IBM DB2

Create a database named, for example, bbaudit and a user.

  1. Create database

    Create a Standard database with a Default bufferpool and table space page size of 32K and UTF-8 codeset.

  2. Create user

    Create a user account on the operating system.

  3. Populate the database

    Connect to the database and run the audit_schema.ddl script located in the configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following command:

    db2 -tvf audit_schema.ddl

    Note

    If you need to re-configure the database, run the audit_drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/db2 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

  4. Assign authorities

    Add the user to the database and grant it the Connect authority.

    Create a schema for the database, set its Authorization name to the operating system user, then grant it SELECT and INSERT privileges on the AUDIT_EVENTS table.

Continue with Install Audit Trails.

Microsoft SQL Server

Create a database named, for example, bbdbaudit and a user. Follow these steps using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio:

  1. Create database

  2. Set transaction isolation level

    Run the following commands:

    ALTER DATABASE database_name SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON
ALTER DATABASE database_name SET ALLOW_SNAPSHOT_ISOLATION ON

  3. Create user

    Create a schema, then create a user.

    In the login properties, set the created database and schema as default for this user. Make the user dbowner of the database.

  4. Populate the database

    Run the audit_schema.ddl script located in the configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 folder in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

    Note

    If you need to re-configure the database, run the audit_drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/portalserver/scripts/sqlserver2008 in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) or in your portal project.

Continue with Install Audit Trails.

6.2 Application Servers

Audit Trails has no WAR file. This section explains the additional configuration of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation.

Apache Tomcat

  • Create datasource

    Create a datasource named jdbc/auditDS by copying the following resource tag to the conf/context.xml file in the Apache Tomcat installation folder:

    <Resource name="resource_name"
 auth="Container"
 type="javax.sql.DataSource"
 maxActive="4"
 maxIdle="2"

 maxWait="5000"

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 6.2. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 6.3. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

Continue with Install Audit Trails.

  1. Create JC2 authentication alias

    1. Navigate to Security > Global security > Java Authentication and Authorization Service > J2C authentication data and create a new JC2 authentication alias.

    2. Enter a name for the Alias and the database username and password.

  2. Create datasource

    Follow these pointers when creating the datasource auditDS:

    1. Set both the Data source name and the JNDI name to the same data source name mentioned above.

    2. Select the J2C authentication alias created in the previous steps.

    3. Select the JDBC provider created in the previous steps.

    4. Fill out the database properties according to your database setup.

    5. Deselect the Use this data source in container managed persistence (CMP) option.

    6. For MySQL, reopen the data source and edit the database URL via the Custom Properties link. For MySQL the default URL is: jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true.

    7. For IBM DB2 running on Unix, reopen the data source and edit the deferPrepares property via the Custom Properties link. Set the property value to false.

  2. Web container configuration

   <resource-ref>
        <res-ref-name>jdbc/auditDS</res-ref-name>
        <res-type>javax.sql.DataSource</res-type>
        <mapped-name>jdbc/auditDS</mapped-name>
        <res-auth>Container</res-auth>

    </resource-ref>
</jboss-web>

  4. Create datasource definition

    Table 6.4. Database Parameters

        <connection-url>database_url</connection-url>
        <driver-class>jdbc_driver_class</driver-class>
        <user-name>user_name</user-name>

        <idle-timeout-minutes>15</idle-timeout-minutes>

</datasources>

    Follow these steps to enter the correct database data:

    1. Set the resource_name to the resource name mentioned above.

    2. Set the user_name and password with the credentials you configured during database setup.

    3. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 6.5. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    4. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 6.6. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

7.2. Configuration File Locations

7.1 Proxy Configuration

The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. This is necessary, because the modules can run on different machines:

The following sections describe the proxy configurations.

Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services to Mashup Services

Mashup Services needs to be aware of the location of Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services. This configuration is necessary for both the stand-alone and the embedded installation. Follow these steps to setup the proxy configuration for Mashup Services:

  1. Create properties file

    Create a file ice-config.properties and place it somewhere on the server running Mashup Services. If you run Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation, this is the server running Backbase Portal Foundation. The file should have the following content:

    cmisServerUrl=http://host:port/applicationcontext/content/atom
cmisRepositoryId=contentRepository
cmisUsername=admin
cmisPassword=admin
portalServerUrl=http://host:port/applicationcontext

    This URL points to Content Services via the proxy in Backbase Portal Foundation (the proxy is the content/atom part of the URL). Enter the host, port and application context of Backbase Portal Foundation:

    Table 7.1. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.

    The repository hosting the content. The default is contentRepository.

    The repository user name. The default is admin.

    The repository password. The default is admin.

    The Backbase Portal Foundation URL:

    Table 7.2. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


  2. Create environment entry

    Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name portalmanager/ice-config and the full path of ice-config.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

Return to the previous topic

Mashup Services stand-alone to Backbase Portal Foundation

Backbase Portal Foundation needs to be aware of the location of Mashup Services. This configuration is only necessary for the stand-alone installation of Mashup Services.

To setup the proxy configuration for Mashup Services, run the application server of Backbase Portal Foundation with the following command line parameter, or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

-DPORTALSERVER_PROXY_URL=http://host:port/applicationcontext/proxy

Content Services to Backbase Portal Foundation

Backbase Portal Foundation needs to be aware of the location of Content Services. Follow these steps to setup the proxy configuration for Content Services:

  1. Create properties file

    Create a file backbase.properties and place it somewhere on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation. The file should have the following content:

    foundation.content.proxy.destination=http://host:port/applicationcontext
foundation.content.proxy.username=admin
foundation.content.proxy.password=admin

  2. Create environment entry

    Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

Orchestrator to Backbase Portal Foundation

Backbase Portal Foundation needs to be aware of the location of Orchestrator. Follow these steps to setup the proxy configuration for Orchestrator:

  1. Create properties file

    Create a file backbase.properties and place it somewhere on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation. The file should have the following content:

    foundation.orchestrator.proxy.destination=http://host:port/applicationcontext
foundation.orchestrator.proxy.username=user_name

7.2.1 How to Set an Environment Entry

Follow the instructions for your application server and replace jndi_binding_name with the JNDI binding name listed in the table above and replace full_path_and_file_name with the full path and file name of the configuration file.

Usually it is better to declare environment entries in the application server, because that method does not involve changing the WAR file. But otherwise, you can use the web.xml method.

Apache Tomcat

Open the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file and add the following tag:

<Environment name="jndi_binding_name"
    value="full_path_and_file_name"
    type="java.lang.String" override="false"/>

Set override to false to ensure that an entry in the web.xml file does not override this environment entry. For more information, please refer to the Apache Tomcat Documentation.

Return to the previous topic

WebSphere

Follow these steps in the Integrated Solutions Console:

  1. Go to Servers > Application Servers and click on the server name.

  2. In the Server Infrastructure menu, go to Java and Process Management > Process definition.

  3. In the Additional Properties menu, go to Environment Entries.

  4. Click on the New button.

  5. Enter jndi_binding_name in the Name field.

    Fill out the Value field with the full_path_and_file_name of the configuration file.

For more information, please refer to the WebSphere Documentation.

Return to the previous topic

JBoss

Follow these steps:

  1. Create or edit a file named jboss-web.xml. Store the file in the WEB-INF folder in the unpacked WAR file. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<jboss-web>
    <resource-env-ref>
        <resource-env-ref-name>environment_entry_name</resource-env-ref-name>
        <jndi-name>jndi_binding_name</jndi-name>
    </resource-env-ref>
</jboss-web>

    Duplicate the resource-env-ref tag for additional environment entries.

  2. Create a file named applicationcontext-service.xml. The applicationcontext usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file, for example portalserver-service.xml or orchestrator-service.xml. Store the file in jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy. Add the following content:

    <mbean code="org.jboss.naming.JNDIBindingServiceMgr"
       name="jboss.apps:name=applicationcontext">
    <attribute name="BindingsConfig" serialDataType="jbxb">
        <jndi:bindings xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                       xmlns:jndi="urn:jboss:jndi-binding-service:1.0"
                       xs:schemaLocation="urn:jboss:jndi-binding-service resource:jndi-binding-service_1_0.xsd">
            <jndi:binding name="jndi_binding_name">
                <jndi:value type="java.lang.String">full_path_and_file_name</jndi:value>
            </jndi:binding>
        </jndi:bindings>
    </attribute>
</mbean>

    Replace applicationcontext with the name of the related WAR file. Duplicate the jndi:binding tag for additional environment entries.

For more information, please refer to the JBoss Documentation.

Return to the previous topic

Jetty

Edit the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project. Add the following content:

<New id="identifier" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.EnvEntry">
    <Arg>jndi_binding_name</Arg>
    <Arg type="java.lang.String">full_path_and_file_name</Arg>
    <Arg type="boolean">true</Arg>
</New>

Warning

The default jetty.xml file already contains an environment entry for the backbase/config JNDI binding. Please edit this entry instead of creating a new one.

You can use any identifier.

For more information, please refer to the Jetty Documentation.

Return to the previous topic

web.xml

Add the environment entry to the web.xml file located in src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project or WEB-INF in the unpacked WAR file:

<env-entry>
    <env-entry-name>jndi_binding_name</env-entry-name>
    <env-entry-value>full_path_and_file_name</env-entry-value>
    <env-entry-type>java.lang.String</env-entry-type>
</env-entry>

Warning

The web.xml already contains some environment entries without a value. In this case, only add the value to the existing entry.

Warning

This method does not always work in Apache Tomcat. In this case, please set the environment variable in the context.xml file.

Return to the previous topic

8 Development Setup

8.1. Create Project
8.1.1. Maven Settings File
8.2. Database setup (optional)
8.3. Portal Example
8.4. Test

Backbase Portal is available as a Maven project. Delivering Backbase Portal as a Maven project makes customization easier because Maven allows you to setup your portal project with minimal effort. At the Backbase Repository, a project template (archetype) is available.

Development Setup Prerequisites

To setup a portal project, the machine needs to meet the following requirements:

  • A supported operating system, see Operating Systems.

  • Maven version 3.

  • A Backbase Repository account.

    To request an account, please contact Backbase Support at www.backbase.com/services/support.

  • Java Developer Kit, see JDK.

Development Setup Procedure

The main steps of the development setup include:

  1. Create the Maven project

    See Create Project.

  2. Set JVM properties

    Run your application server with the following parameters, or add them to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    • The available memory:

      -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m

  3. Setup database (optional)

    By default, the Maven project uses an embedded H2 database. If you want to configure H2, or if you want to use a different database, see Database setup (optional).

  4. Logback configuration

    Create a Logback configuration file named logback.xml and save it somewhere on the file system, or use the logback.xml file included in the configuration/examples folder in your portal project. For more information, please refer to the Logback configuration.

    Note

    Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, and Content Services can share the same Logback configuration file.

  5. Properties configuration

    Create a file named backbase.properties and save it somewhere on the file system. If Backbase Portal Foundation, Orchestrator, Mashup Services and/or Content Services run on the same machine, they share the same properties. In this case, open the existing properties file. Add the following lines: 

    foundation.logging=log_folder_path/logback.xml
database.foundation.hibernate.dialect.class=org.hibernate.dialect.hibernate_dialect
foundation.ptc.profile=ptc-[local|remote]
foundation.environment.editorial=[true|false]

    1. Enter the location of the logback.xml file. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \.

    2. Enter the appropriate Hibernate dialect. Accepted values are any of the dialects listed in the Hibernate documentation, for example:

      Table 8.1. Hibernate Dialect

      Database

      Hibernate Dialect

      H2 (default)

      H2Dialect

      MySQL

      MySQL5Dialect

      Oracle

      Oracle10gDialect

      IBM DB2

      DB2Dialect

      Microsoft SQL Server

      SQLServer2008Dialect


    3. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. Setting it to remote disables the embedded instance of Mashup Services.

    4. Set foundation.environment.editorial to true if this instance of Backbase Portal Foundation is an editorial environment, and to false if it is a staging or live environment.

    5. Create an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config and the full path of backbase.properties. See How to Set an Environment Entry.

    Note

    If you want to enable Audit Trails, set the additional properties as explained in Install Audit Trails.

  6. Proxy configuration

    The modules of Backbase Portal use proxy configurations to be aware of each other URLs. See Proxy Configuration.

  7. Change Java compliance level (optional)

    Open the pom.xml file located in the root folder of your portal project. You can set the Java compliance level in the <source> and <target> parameters in the maven-compiler-plugin plugin. See JDK for the supported Java versions.

  8. Copy import file

    Copy one of the shipped import files:

    • With Backbase Portal Manager

      Copy the src/main/dashboardResources/import/importPortal.xml file in your portal project to src/main/resources/import.

      If you prefer to disable the publishing functionality, edit the importPortal.xml and remove the following widget from the dashboard portal:

      <widgets>
    <file>backbase.com.2012.tango/instance-widgets.xml</file>
</widgets>

      Note

      You might notice that several file locations and parameters concerning Backbase Portal Manager use the term Spitfire and Dashboard. Spitfire and Dashboard are synonyms of Backbase Portal Manager.

    • Without Backbase Portal Manager

      Copy the src/main/coreResources/import/importPortal.xml file in your portal project to src/main/resources/import.

    For more information, see Import File.

  9. Create a portal (optional)

    See Portal Example.

  10. Test the portal

    See Test.

After the development setup, you can start customizing the portal. For more information, see Customization.

Package the Project

To package the portal project in a WAR file, open a command shell and go to the project folder. Run the following command:

mvn package

Maven will create a WAR file in the target folder.

You can deploy the WAR file on an application server as described in Install Backbase Portal Foundation.

8.1 Create Project

Follow these steps to create the portal project:

  1. Maven setup

    1. Create or open the settings.xml file in the .m2 folder. The default location of the .m2 folder depends on the operating system:

      • On Microsoft Windows — C:\Documents and Settings\your_windows_user_name\.m2

      • On Unix — ~/.m2

      If Maven has never run, the .m2 folder does not exist. If so, create it manually.

    2. Copy the content of this Maven Settings File to your settings file and enter your user name and password at the bottom. If you do not have a user name, please contact Backbase Support at www.backbase.com/services/support to request an account.

  2. Comodo certificate

    The https://repo.backbase.com/repo/ repository uses SSL authentication and a Comodo addtrustexternalca certificate must be present in your Java Runtime Environment (JRE) keystore.

    1. To list all certificates, run the following command. On Unix machines, prepend the command with ./.

      keytool -list -keystore path_to_keystore/cacerts

      The default password for the Java default keystore is changeit.

    2. If the addtrustexternalca certificate is not listed, download it from the Comodo website and import it by running the following command. On Unix machines, prepend the command with ./.

      keytool -import -trustcacerts -alias comodoaaaca -file path_to_file/AddTrustExternalCARoot.crt -keystore path_to_keystore/cacerts

    3. Check that the addtrustexternalca certificate is listed in the JRE keystore by once again running the keytool command as described in Step 2.a.

  3. Generate project

    Open a command shell and go to a location where you want to create the portal project. Execute the following command:

    mvn archetype:generate -DarchetypeArtifactId=backbase-portal-archetype-blank -DarchetypeGroupId=com.backbase.portal.archetypes -DarchetypeVersion=5.3.1.0

  4. Enter project parameters

    In response to a series of command line prompts, set the following parameters:

    • groupId — a fully qualified package name identifying the organization, such as my.company.com.

    • artifactId — an identifier for the portal project, such as mycompany-portal. This setting defines the name of the folder in which the project is created.

    • version — defines the version of the portal project. The default value is 1.0-SNAPSHOT.

    • package — a fully qualified package name identifying the package, such as my.company.com. Defaults to the value of groupId.

    Finally, confirm the settings.

    The project is now created in the folder defined by artifactId.

You have finished creating a project. Continue with Development Setup Procedure.

Top

8.1.1 Maven Settings File

The Maven settings file (settings.xml in the .m2 folder) should look as follows.

Note

Enter your user name and password at the bottom of the file.

<settings xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0"
          xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
          xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/SETTINGS/1.0.0
                              http://maven.apache.org/xsd/settings-1.0.0.xsd">
    <profiles>
        <profile>
            <id>backbase</id>
            <activation>
                <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
            </activation>
            <repositories>
                <repository>
                    <id>Backbase Artifact Repository</id>
                    <url>https://repo.backbase.com/repo/</url>
                </repository>
            </repositories>
        </profile>
    </profiles>
    <servers>
        <server>
            <id>Backbase Artifact Repository</id>
            <username>your_user_name</username>
            <password>your_password</password>
        </server>
    </servers>
</settings>

Continue with Step 2 of the Create Project topic.

Top

8.2 Database setup (optional)

Backbase Portal ships with an embedded H2 database. This section explains how to to configure the behavior of H2, or use a different database.

H2

The embedded H2 database is already configured. If you want to change the settings, follow these steps:

  1. Database setup

    You can edit the database setup in the pom.xml file in your portal project. The relevant parameters are within the configuration element of the sql-maven-plugin plugin:

    <configuration>
    <driver>org.h2.Driver</driver>
    <url>jdbc:h2:file:~/.backbase/portalFoundationBlankArchetype</url>
    <username>sa</username>
    <password></password>
    <srcFiles>
        <srcFile>${project.basedir}/configuration/schema.ddl</srcFile>
        <srcFile>${project.basedir}/configuration/default-foundation-data-blank.sql</srcFile>
    </srcFiles>
</configuration>

    The H2 JDBC driver.

    The location of the database file. Note that multiple projects on the same machine overwrite the database file in the default location, so you might want to change this parameter.

    The database user name.

    The database password.

    The location of the schema.dll script in your portal project.

    The location of the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script in your portal project.

  2. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">jdbc_driver_class</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">database_url</Set>
            <Set name="user">user_name</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    1. Replace user_name and password with the credentials you configured in previous steps.

    2. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 8.2. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

      com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver

      H2

      org.h2.Driver


    3. Replace database_url with the URL of the database. The default URLs for supported databases are as follows:

      Table 8.3. Database URL

      Database

      URL

      MySQL

      jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/database?cacheServerConfiguration=true

      Oracle XE

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/XE

      Oracle

      jdbc:oracle:thin:@localhost:1521/database

      IBM DB2

      jdbc:db2://localhost:50000/database

      Microsoft SQL Server

      jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433;databaseName=database

      H2

      jdbc:h2:file:path/to/database;MVCC=true;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE


      Replace database in the database URL with the database name. For H2, enter the full path of the database file. Depending on the database settings, the database host and port can be different.

      Important

      If you append the database URL with query parameters, make sure to use the & entity to avoid XML parsing errors.

Return to Development Setup Procedure.

MySQL

  1. Open configuration file

    In Microsoft Windows, open or create the my.ini configuration file in the installation folder of MySQL. In Unix, open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file. You can also create a database-specific configuration file.

  2. Set InnoDB storage engine

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    default-storage-engine = innodb

  3. Set transaction isolation level

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    transaction-isolation = READ-COMMITTED

  4. Disable identifier case sensitivity (Unix only)

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    lower_case_table_names=2

  5. Set UTF-8 support

    Add the following to the [mysqld] section of the MySQL configuration file:

    init_connect='SET collation_connection = utf8_general_ci'
init_connect='SET NAMES utf8'
character-set-server=utf8
collation-server=utf8_general_ci
skip-character-set-client-handshake

    Add the following to the [mysql] section of the MySQL configuration file, or replace the property value if it is already defined:

    default-character-set=utf8

  6. Restart MySQL

Create a schema named, for example, bbdbfoundation and a user. Log in to MySQL Workbench or another MySQL tool as administrator and follow these steps:

  1. Create schema

    Create schemas by running the following command:

    CREATE SCHEMA schema_name;

  2. Create user

    Create a user and assign it a password:

    CREATE USER 'user_name'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

  3. Grant privileges

    Grant the user all privileges on the schema:

    GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES on schema_name.* to 'user_name'@'localhost';
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

  4. Populate the database

    Run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/mysql in your portal project.

    1. Run the schema.ddl script to create the database objects, or copy the file contents and paste them to the MySQL command line.

    2. Run the default-foundation-data-blank.sql script to populate the database with a minimal data set. To run the script from the command line, type the following:

      mysql -uroot -ppassword database_name < default-foundation-data-blank.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/mysql in your portal project.

  5. Add JDBC driver dependency

    Open the pom.xml file in the root folder of your portal project and add the following dependency to the jetty-maven-plugin definition:

    <dependency>
    <groupId>mysql</groupId>
    <artifactId>mysql-connector-java</artifactId>
    <version>5.1.9</version>
    <scope>runtime</scope>
</dependency>

  6. Remove sql-maven-plugin

    In the pom.xml file, remove or comment out the whole sql-maven-plugin plugin definition.

  7. Configure datasource

    Open the jetty.xml file in the configuration folder in your portal project and modify the datasource definition:

    <New id="portalDS" class="org.eclipse.jetty.plus.jndi.Resource">
    <Arg>jdbc/portalDS</Arg>
    <Arg>
        <New class="com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource">
            <Set name="driverClass">jdbc_driver_class</Set>
            <Set name="jdbcUrl">database_url</Set>
            <Set name="user">user_name</Set>
            <Set name="password">password</Set>
        </New>
    </Arg>
</New>

    1. Replace user_name and password with the credentials you configured in previous steps.

    2. Replace jdbc_driver_class with the compatible JDBC driver class:

      Table 8.4. JDBC Driver

      Database

      JDBC Driver Class

      MySQL

      com.mysql.jdbc.Driver

      Oracle

      oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

      IBM DB2

      com.ibm.db2.jcc.DB2Driver

      Microsoft SQL Server

  2. Add JDBC driver to local Maven repository

    Add the JDBC driver to your local Maven repository with the following command:

  3. Log in to the SQLPlus command line tool as administrator and follow these steps:

    1. Create user

      Create a user, assign it a password, and unlock the account:

      CREATE USER user_name

IDENTIFIED BY password
DEFAULT TABLESPACE user
TEMPORARY TABLESPACE temp

    2. Grant privileges

      Grant the user privileges to create tables, views, and sequences, then grant it unlimited tablespace:

GRANT create table TO user_name;
GRANT create view TO user_name;
GRANT create sequence TO user_name;

GRANT UNLIMITED TABLESPACE TO user_name;

IBM DB2

Create a database named, for example, bbdbfound and a user.

  1. Download JDBC driver

    Select a compatible driver for your database version: DB2 JDBC Drivers. The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar.

  2. Add JDBC driver to local Maven repository

    Add the JDBC driver to your local Maven repository with the following command:

    mvn install:install-file -Dfile=db2jcc4.jar -DgroupId=com.ibm.db2 -DartifactId=db2jcc -Dpackaging=jar

  3. Create database

    Create a Standard database with a Default bufferpool and table space page size of 32K and UTF-8 codeset.

  4. Create user

    Create a user account on the operating system.

  5. Grant rights

    Add the user to the database and grant it authorities. A minimum set is: Connect, Create tables, Create packages, Create schemas implicitly, Access Load Utility, and Connect to quiesced database.

    Create a schema for the database and set its Authorization name to the operating system user.

  6. Populate the database

    Connect to the database and run the schema.ddl and default-foundation-data-blank.sql scripts to populate the database. These scripts are located in configuration/scripts/db2 in your portal project.

    First, navigate to the directory that holds the scripts. Then, use the following commands:

    db2 -td; -vf schema.ddl
db2 -td@ -vf default-foundation-data-blank.sql

    Note

    If you need to drop all schemas and re-configure the database, run the drop_schema.sql script located in configuration/scripts/db2 in your portal project.

  7. Download IBM DB2 JDBC driver

    Select a compatible driver for your database version and save it on the file system: DB2 JDBC Drivers. The downloaded archive will contain a JAR file for JDBC 4.0, e.g. db2jcc4.jar.

    <version>db2_level</version>
    <type>jar</type>
    <scope>system</scope>
    <systemPath>path/to/db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar</systemPath>
</dependency>

    Replace db2_level with your IBM DB2 version, and path/to/db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar with the file system location of the db2jcc_license_cisuz.jar license file.

8.3 Portal Example

In this optional step you manually create a portal with a page, a container, and a widget. You can also use Backbase Portal Manager to create a portal, but following this manual procedure teaches you the basic elements of a portal.

  1. Create a widget definition

    The portal will include a 'Hello World' widget. The widget definition is an XHTML file that defines the HTML representation of the widget. Create the folders static/doctest/widgets/helloworld in src/main/webapp in your portal project. In the helloworld folder, create a file named index.html with the following content:

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <p>Hello World</p>
    </body>
</html>

  2. Change import file

    Open the importPortal.xml file in src/main/resources/import in your portal project. Add this tag to the <!-- ** PORTALS ** --> section:

        <!-- Doctest -->
    <portal-import>
        <name>Doctest</name>
        <file>portals/doctest/portal.xml</file>
        <rights-file>portals/doctest/rights.xml</rights-file>
        <catalog>
            <file>portals/doctest/catalog-masterpage.xml</file>
            <rights-file>portals/doctest/rights-masterpage.xml</rights-file>
        </catalog>
        <catalog>
            <file>portals/doctest/catalog.xml</file>
        </catalog>
        <pages>
            <file>portals/doctest/pages.xml</file>
        </pages>
        <containers>
            <file>portals/doctest/containers.xml</file>
        </containers>
        <widgets>
            <file>portals/doctest/widgets.xml</file>
        </widgets>
        <links>
            <file>portals/doctest/links.xml</file>
        </links>
    </portal-import>

  3. Create folder for portal import files

    Create the folders named portals/doctest in src/main/resources/import in your portal project.

  4. Portal

    Create a file named portal.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<portal>
    <name>doctest</name>
    <contextItemName>[BBHOST]</contextItemName>
    <properties>
        <property name="DefaultLandingPage">
            <value type="string">index</value>
        </property>
        <property name="DefaultDevice"><value type="string">web</value></property>
        <property name="TargetedDevice"><value type="string">web</value></property>
        <property name="title"><value type="string">Doctest Portal</value></property>
    </properties>
</portal>

  5. Rights

    This rights file allows administrators and managers to manage the portal, users to personalize the portal and anonymous visitors to view the portal.

    Create a file named rights.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes" ?>
<rights>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_admin</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_master page designer</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_manager</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_user</sid>
        <securityProfile>CREATOR</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>role_anonymous</sid>
        <securityProfile>CONSUMER</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
</rights>

  6. Master page rights

    This separate rights file is necessary for the master page in the portal catalog. Only users from the master page designer group and administrators can edit master pages.

    Create a file named rights-masterpage.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<rights>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_admin</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_master page designer</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_manager</sid>
        <securityProfile>CONSUMER</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_user</sid>
        <securityProfile>CONSUMER</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>role_anonymous</sid>
        <securityProfile>CONSUMER</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
</rights>

  7. Master page in portal catalog

    Create a file named catalog-masterpage.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<catalog>
    <!-- This master page extends the blank master page from the server catalog -->
    <page>
        <name>blankMasterPage_docTest</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <extendedItemName>[blankMasterPage]</extendedItemName>
    </page>
</catalog>

    Tip

    The blankMasterPage is shipped by default, see Nexus.

  8. Portal catalog

    Create a file named catalog.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<catalog>
    <!-- This container extends the manageable area from the server catalog -->
    <container>
        <name>manageableArea_masterPage_docTest</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>blankMasterPage_docTest</parentItemName>
        <extendedItemName>[Manageable_Area]</extendedItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="order"><value type="double">0.0</value></property>
        </properties>
    </container>
    <!-- This container extends the border layout from the server catalog -->
    <container>
        <name>borderlayout_docTest_catalog</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <extendedItemName>[Border_Layout]</extendedItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="order"><value type="double">0.0</value></property>
            <property name="area"><value type="string">0</value></property>
            <property name="rowHeights">
                <value type="string">100px,100px,100px</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </container>
    <!-- This is the Hello World widget -->
    <widget>
        <name>hello_world_widget</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="TemplateName">
                <value type="string">Standard_Widget</value>
            </property>
            <property name="src">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/doctest/widgets/helloworld/index.html</value>
            </property>
            <property name="widgetChrome" label="Widget Chrome">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/backbase.com.2012.aurora/html/chromes/widget_default.html</value>
            </property>
            <property name="area"><value type="string">west</value></property>
            <property name="order"><value type="double">1.0</value></property>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Hello World Widget</value>
            </property>
            <!-- Only Backbase Portal Manager uses the following property -->
            <property name="thumbnailUrl">
                <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/dashboard/media/icons/icons-widgets_01-default.png</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </widget>
</catalog>

    Tip

    The containers extend layouts from a shipped bundle, see Aurora.

  9. Page

    Create a file named pages.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<pages>
    <!-- This page extends the master page from the portal catalog -->
    <page>
        <name>index</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <extendedItemName>blankMasterPage_docTest</extendedItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Doctest Portal - Index</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </page>
</pages>

  10. Containers

    Create a file named containers.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<containers>
    <!-- This container is the manageable area in the master page extended from the portal catalog -->
    <container>
        <name>manageableArea_indexPage</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>index</parentItemName>
        <extendedItemName>manageableArea_masterPage_docTest</extendedItemName>
    </container>
    <!-- This container is the border layout extended from the portal catalog -->
    <container>
        <name>borderlayout_docTest</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>manageableArea_indexPage</parentItemName>
        <extendedItemName>borderlayout_docTest_catalog</extendedItemName>
    </container>
</containers>

  11. Widgets

    Create a file named widgets.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<widgets>
    <!-- This is the Hello World widget extended from the portal catalog -->
    <widget>
        <name>hello_world_widget1</name>
        <extendedItemName>hello_world_widget</extendedItemName>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>borderlayout_docTest</parentItemName>
    </widget>
</widgets>

  12. Links

    Create a file named links.xml in src/main/resources/import/portals/doctest. Add the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<links>
    <!-- This is the root link for the pages in the navigation -->
    <link>
        <name>navroot_mainmenu</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Main Navigation</value>
            </property>
            <property name="Order"><value type="string">1</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <!-- This is the root link for floating pages -->
    <link>
        <name>navroot_notinmenu</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>

            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Floating Pages</value>
            </property>
            <property name="Order"><value type="string">2</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <!-- This is the root link for master pages -->
    <link>
        <name>masterpage_root</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>doctest</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Master Pages</value>
            </property>
            <property name="Order"><value type="string">3</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <!-- This is the link for the page 'index' -->
    <link>
        <name>indexLink</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>navroot_mainmenu</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Index</value>
            </property>
            <property name="ItemRef"><value type="string">index</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">page</value>
            </property>
            <property name="sectionName">
                <value type="string">index</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
    <!-- This is the link for the master page -->
    <link>
        <name>blankMasterPageLink</name>
        <contextItemName>doctest</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>masterpage_root</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Blank Master Page</value>
            </property>
            <property name="ItemRef"><value type="string">blankMasterPage_docTest</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">

    </link>
</links>

This concludes the portal example. You can now start to Test the portal.

Top

8.4 Test

Follow these steps to test the project:

  1. Run the project

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

    The last command starts a Jetty server with an instance of an embedded H2 database and deploys the portal on it. The -P modifier sets the Maven profile to with-dashboard. Exclude this modifier to run Backbase Portal without Backbase Portal Manager.

  2. Run the importer tool

    Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 8.12. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Log in with the administrator user name admin and password admin. To load the login page directly, navigate to http://host:port/applicationcontext/spring_security_login. The following screen opens:

    All objects should be checked (this is default). Click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

    For more information on the importer tool, see Importer.

    Note

    As long as you use the default H2 database, you need to run the importer tool each time you test the portal project.

  3. Open the portal example

    Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/doctest in a browser. You should see a page with a log out link, the user name admin and a widget. You can drag the widget to another location on the page.

  4. Open Backbase Portal Manager

    Open the following URL: http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/dashboard.

    Note

    You might notice that several file locations and parameters concerning Backbase Portal Manager use the term Dashboard. Dashboard is a synonym for Backbase Portal Manager.

Note

For more information on the URLs of Backbase Portal, see the REST API. There are a number of third-party tools to directly communicate to the REST interface. For more information, see Third-party Tools.
