9.1 Migrating from 5.3.0 to 5.3.1

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.3.0 to version 5.3.1, you need to make the following changes:

  • Configuration settings change name

    The configuration settings foundation.foundation.cache.web.enabled and foundation.foundation.cache.web.pagesToCacheList in backbase.properties have been renamed to foundation.cachingFilter.cache.web.enabled and foundation.cachingFilter.cache.web.pagesToCacheList respectively.

  • Upgrade web.xml

    The web.xml has changed. Follow these steps to update it:

    • Remove the mdcFilter definition and the mdcFilter mapping.

Top

9.2 Migrating from 5.2.5 to 5.3.0

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.5 to version 5.3.0, you need to make the following changes:

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Clear application server cache

    Clear your application server cache, see Solving Problems.

  • Environment entries (JBoss and Apache Tomcat)

    Configuration settings are now managed centrally and some environment entries are not needed anymore. If you specified the portalserver/config or the portalserver/contentproxy/config environment entries, remove them as follows:

    • JBoss: edit the portalserver-service.xml file on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation and remove the relevant <jndi:binding> elements. Replace portalserver with your Backbase Portal Foundation application context.

    • Apache Tomcat: edit the context.xml file on the classpath of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation and remove the relevant <Environment> elements.

    No changes are necessary for WebSphere installations. You can specify the location of the proxy configuration files in the backbase.properties file, For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Add master page support to your portals (optional)

    Version 5.3.0 supports master pages. These are pages in the server and portal catalog. Normal pages extend a master page and inherit its page template and any layouts or widgets present on the master page. You can add master page support to your existing portals, see Master Page Support.

  • New properties

    Update your import files and templates to reflect these new properties:

    Table 9.1. Property Changes

    Object

    New property in 5.3.0

    Mandatory

    Description

    Link

    SecuritySameAsParent

    -

    Links now inherit rights the same way as other objects. To enable this, the link has a new property SecuritySameAsParent. For more information, see Rights Inheritance.

    Container

    autoExtend

    -

    When a page extends a master page, it can also extend the children of the master page. A new property autoExtend regulates whether a page extends the child when extending its parent master page. By default, the manageable area container has this property set to TRUE, but other containers or widgets do not have this property, so the page does not extend these objects. This ensures that when the master page designer changes containers or widgets on the master page, these changes are always reflected on the page.

    Widget

    autoExtend

    -

9.2.1 Database Migration

Backbase Portal Foundation

Follow the steps below to migrate the Backbase Portal Foundation database to Backbase Portal version 5.3.0:

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop your application server.

  3. Go to the configuration/portalserver/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.3.0.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (e.g. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade_5_2_5_to_5_3_0 folder and run the pre-dml-upgrade-5.2.5-to-5.3.0.ddl script.

  4. Run the upgrade-5.2.5-to-5.3.0.dml script.

  5. Deploy the new version of Backbase Portal Foundation as described in Install Backbase Portal Foundation and restart the application server.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Orchestrator

Follow the steps below to migrate the Orchestrator database to Backbase Portal version 5.3.0:

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop Orchestrator.

  3. Go to the configuration/orchestrator/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.3.0.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (e.g. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade-5.2.1-to-5.3.0 folder and run the upgrade-5.2.1-to-5.3.0.ddl script on the Orchestrator database.

  4. Deploy the new version of Orchestrator as described in Install Orchestrator and restart the application server.

Top

9.2.2 Master Page Support

Follow these steps to add master page support to a portal. Perform these steps on an environment with Backbase Portal Manager.

Method 1: REST API

  1. New group

    Make sure a group named master page designer exists with the role MANAGER. If it doesn't exist, you can create the group in Backbase Portal Manager. In the start screen, go to Groups and click the + button.

  2. Copy import file

    Copy the the 5.3.0 import file to your project or unpacked WAR file:

    • If you work with the Maven project:

      Copy the src/main/coreResources/import/importPortal.xml file in your portal project to src/main/resources/import. Rebuild the project:

      Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

      mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

    • If you work with a deployed WAR file:

      Copy the WEB-INF/classes/import/importPortal.xml file in the portal-dev-5.3.0.x.war in the installation package (Backbase_Portal_5.3.1.0.zip) to WEB-INF/classes/import/importPortal.xml in the unpacked WAR file.

  3. Run importer tool

    Open the import tool to import the latest additions in the bundles. Please note that existing templates and catalog items will not be overwritten. For master page support you need the following objects:

    • Manageable_Area — part of catalog-containers-adminDesignerOnly.xml in the Aurora bundle.

    • blankMasterPage — part of catalog-pages.xml in the Nexus bundle.

    You can find these import files in importPortal.xml:

    <!-- ** SERVER CATALOG CONTAINERS ** -->
<!-- Nexus / Navigation -->
<containers>
    <file>backbase.com.2012.nexus/catalog-pages.xml</file>
</containers>
...
<!-- Aurora -->
...
<containers>
    <file>backbase.com.2012.aurora/catalog-containers-adminDesignerOnly.xml</file>
</containers>

    To run the import tool, open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 9.2. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Log in as administrator. Check at least the two objects listed above and click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

  4. Add master page support

    Now you can do the REST API call to add master page support to a portal. Make sure you are logged in as administrator. Do a PUT call to http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/portal_name/addmasterpagessupport. The body of the call should include the following XML code that specifies the groups that are allowed to manage master pages:

    <rights>
    <itemRight>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
        <sid>group_admin</sid>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
        <sid>group_master page designer</sid>
    </itemRight>
</rights>

    Repeat this step for each portal for which you want master pages support.

  5. Migrate existing pages (optional)

    Now when you add pages to your portal in Backbase Portal Manager, they will extend the blank master page. Users belonging to the master page group can change the page template and appearance of the blank master page or create a new one.

    You may want to migrate your existing pages to extend the master page. To do so, add the name of the master page to their extendedItemName field and remove any properties that you want the page to inherit from the master page, like the TemplateName property.

Method 2: Importer Tool

  1. New group

    Make sure a group named master page designer exists with the role MANAGER. If it doesn't exist, you can create the group in Backbase Portal Manager. In the start screen, go to Groups and click the + button.

  2. Create import file

    Create a file importPortal.xml and place it in your project or unpacked WAR file:

    • If you work with the Maven project:

      Place the file in src/main/resources/import in your portal project.

    • If you work with a deployed WAR file:

      Place the file in WEB-INF/classes/import in the unpacked WAR file.

    For master page support you need the Manageable_Area container that is part of catalog-containers-adminDesignerOnly.xml in the Aurora bundle. You also need to add a root link with special rights to each portal. Add the following content to the importPortal.xml file:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes" ?>
<backbase-portal-import>
    <!-- ** SERVER CATALOG CONTAINERS ** -->
    <!-- Aurora -->
    <containers>
        <file>backbase.com.2012.aurora/catalog-containers-adminDesignerOnly.xml</file>
    </containers>

    <!-- ** PORTALS ** -->
    <portal-import>
        <name>Your Portal</name>
        <file>migration/yourportal/portal.xml</file>
        <links>
            <file>migration/yourportal/links.xml</file>
            <rights-file>migration/masterpage-link-rights.xml</rights-file>
        </links>
    </portal-import>
</backbase-portal-import>

    Copy the portal-import section for each portal for which you want master pages support. Replace yourportal with the name of the portal.

  3. Create rights file

    Create a folder named migration in src/main/resources/import in your portal project or WEB-INF/classes/import in the unpacked WAR file. In this folder, create a file named masterpage-link-rights.xml with the following content:

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<rights>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_admin</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_master page designer</sid>
        <securityProfile>ADMIN</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_manager</sid>
        <securityProfile>NONE</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>group_user</sid>
        <securityProfile>NONE</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
    <itemRight>
        <sid>role_anonymous</sid>
        <securityProfile>NONE</securityProfile>
    </itemRight>
</rights>

  4. Create import files

    Repeat the following steps for each portal for which you want master pages support. Replace yourportal with the name of the portal.

    1. Create folder

      Create a folder named yourportal in the migration folder.

    2. Portal

      In the yourportal folder, create a file named portal.xml with the following content:

      <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<portal>
    <name>yourportal</name>
</portal>

    3. Root link

      In the yourportal folder, create a file named links.xml with the following content:

      <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<links>
    <!-- This is the root link for master pages -->
    <link>
        <name>masterpage_root</name>
        <contextItemName>yourportal</contextItemName>
        <parentItemName>yourportal</parentItemName>
        <properties>
            <property name="title">
                <value type="string">Master Pages</value>
            </property>
            <property name="Order"><value type="string">3</value></property>
            <property name="itemType">
                <value type="string">menuHeader</value>
            </property>
        </properties>
    </link>
</links>

  5. Run importer tool

    If you work with the Maven project, you need to rebuild the project:

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

    To run the import tool, open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 9.3. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Log in as administrator. Select all items and click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

  6. Add manageable area container to portal catalog

    For each portal for which you want master pages support, you need to add the manageable area container to portal catalog. Open Backbase Portal Manager and log in as administrator. Go to Your Portal > Catalog > Layouts and check Manageable Area.

  7. Migrate existing pages (optional)

    Now you can create a master page in Backbase Portal Manager. Log in as administrator or as master page designer. Go to Your Portal > Pages > Master Pages and click the + button. Enter a name and select a page template. When you add pages to your portal in Backbase Portal Manager, they will extend the new master page.

    You may want to migrate your existing pages to extend the master page. To do so, add the name of the master page to their extendedItemName field and remove any properties that you want the page to inherit from the master page, like the TemplateName property.

  8. Assign publisher role to master page designer

    Edit the Orchestrator configuration file and assign publisher role to the master page designer group. For more information, see Publishing Configuration and Authentication and Authorization.

Top

9.3 Migrating from 5.2.4 to 5.2.5

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.4 to version 5.2.5, you need to make the following changes:

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Clear application server cache

    Clear your application server cache, see Solving Problems.

  • Set import file property

    1. Decompress the WAR file

      Decompress the 5.2.5 Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file.

    2. Change property

      Open application.properties in WEB-INF/classes in the unpacked WAR file. Change the value of the portal.import.file property to importPortal.xml.

    3. Re-compress the WAR file

      From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

      jar -cvf portalserver.war *

      Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

9.3.1 Database Migration

Follow the steps below to migrate the Backbase Portal Foundation database to Backbase Portal version 5.2.5:

  1. Backup your database.

  2. Stop your application server.

  3. Go to the configuration/portalserver/scripts folder in the Backbase_Portal_5.2.5.zip archive and open the folder corresponding to your database engine (e.g. db2 for the DB2 database). Open the upgrade_5_2_2_to_5_2_5 folder and run the pre-dml-upgrade-5.2.2-to-5.2.5.ddl.

  4. Run the upgrade-5.2.2-to-5.2.5.dml script.

  5. Deploy the new version of Backbase Portal Foundation as described in Install Backbase Portal Foundation and restart the application server.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

9.4 Migrating from 5.2.2 to 5.2.4

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.2 to version 5.2.4, you need to make the following changes:

  • Clear application server cache

    Clear your application server cache, see Solving Problems.

  • Set import file property

    1. Decompress the WAR file

      Decompress the 5.2.4 Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file.

    2. Change property

      Open application.properties in WEB-INF/classes in the unpacked WAR file. Change the value of the portal.import.file property to importPortal.xml.

    3. Re-compress the WAR file

      From the command line, change to the directory of the decompressed WAR file and run the following command:

      jar -cvf portalserver.war *

      Note that WAR/JAR files are built on the ZIP file format, so an easy alternative way to re-pack a WAR file is by zipping it and changing its extension to .war.

  • Update web.xml

    The web.xml has changed. Follow these steps to update it:

    • Add the following line to the file list to the contextConfigLocation context parameter:

      classpath:/META-INF/spring/backbase-portal-presentation-ssr.xml

    • Add the backbasePageCachingFilter filter after urlFilter:

      <filter>
    <filter-name>backbasePageCachingFilter</filter-name>
    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy</filter-class>
    <init-param>
        <param-name>suppressStackTrace</param-name>
        <param-value>false</param-value>
    </init-param>
    <init-param>
        <param-name>cacheName</param-name>
        <param-value>webCache</param-value>
    </init-param>
    <init-param>
        <param-name>targetFilterLifecycle</param-name>
        <param-value>true</param-value>
    </init-param>
</filter>

    • Add mapping for the backbasePageCachingFilter filter after the mapping for springSecurityFilterChain:

      <filter-mapping>
    <filter-name>backbasePageCachingFilter</filter-name>
    <servlet-name>Portal Foundation Spring MVC</servlet-name>
</filter-mapping>

  • Modify ehcache.xml

    1. Open the archive named configuration-5.2.4.0.jar in WEB-INF/lib in the unpacked Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file.

    2. Edit the ehcache.xml file and add the following lines:

      <cache name="webCache"
    maxElementsInMemory="10000"
    eternal="false"
    timeToIdleSeconds="300"
    timeToLiveSeconds="600"
    overflowToDisk="true"
    maxElementsOnDisk="10000000"
    diskPersistent="false"
    diskExpiryThreadIntervalSeconds="120"
    memoryStoreEvictionPolicy="LRU"/>

    The values above are examples, replace them with values appropriate to your system.

9.5 Migrating from 5.2.1 to 5.2.2

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.1 to version 5.2.2, you need to make the following changes:

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Cache configuration

    If you are using Maven, upgrade the cache configuration as follows:.

    1. Open the configuration-5.x.jar file in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file.

    2. Create a file named ehcache-persistence.xml in the JAR file.

    3. Open the ehcache.xml file in the JAR file. Copy the cache elements named org.hibernate.cache.StandardQueryCache and org.hibernate.cache.UpdateTimestampsCache, paste them into the ehcache-persistence.xml file you created before, and delete them from the ehcache.xml file.

    4. Copy the cache element named defaultCache from the ehcache.xml file and paste it into the ehcache-persistence.xml file. Do not remove it from the ehcache.xml file.

  • Update web.xml

    The web.xml file has changed. Follow these steps to update it:

    • Add the contextInitializerClasses context parameter:

      <context-param>
    <param-name>contextInitializerClasses</param-name>
    <param-value>com.backbase.portal.foundation.integration.context.BackbaseContextInitializer</param-value>
</context-param>

    • Add the PTC Servlet after the PortalDispatcherServlet declaration:

      <servlet>
    <servlet-name>PTC Servlet</servlet-name>
    <servlet-class>
    com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.renderer.PtcServlet
    </servlet-class>
    <load-on-startup>2</load-on-startup>
</servlet>
<servlet-mapping>
    <servlet-name>PTC Servlet</servlet-name>
    <url-pattern>/proxy/*</url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

9.6 Migrating from 5.2.0 to 5.2.1

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.2.0 to version 5.2.1, you need to make the following changes:

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Widget object in widget definitions

    Replace __GADGET__ in your widget definitions with __WIDGET__.

  • MySQL on Unix

    If you are running MySQL on Unix, disable identifier case sensitivity. You can skip the following steps if you are running Microsoft Windows:

    1. Open the /etc/mysql/my.cnf file.

    2. Add the following line under the [mysqld] group definition:

      lower_case_table_names=2

    3. Restart MySQL.

    To test that the change had the desired effect, log in MySQL and check that the following does not return an error:

    CREATE SCHEMA CaSeInSenSiTiVe;
USE caseinsensitive;

  • Update web.xml

    The web.xml file has changed. Follow these steps to update it:

    • If you are going to use Backbase Portal Manager, add the following lines after the other context parameters:

      <context-param>
    <param-name>com.backbase.portal.ptc.web.PROPERTIES_FILE</param-name>
    <param-value>classpath:/ice-config.properties,jndi:java:comp/env/portalmanager/ice-config</param-value>
</context-param>
<env-entry>
    <env-entry-name>portalmanager/ice-config</env-entry-name>
    <env-entry-type>java.lang.String</env-entry-type>
</env-entry>

    • Change the uAgentInfoGatheringFilter to the following:

      <filter>
    <filter-name>uAgentInfoGatheringFilter</filter-name>
    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy
    </filter-class>
</filter>

    • Add the urlFilter after springSecurityFilterChain filter:

      <filter>
    <filter-name>urlFilter</filter-name>
    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy
    </filter-class>
</filter>

    • Add the urlFilter mapping after the springSecurityFilterChain mapping:

      <filter-mapping>
    <filter-name>urlFilter</filter-name>
    <servlet-name>Portal Foundation Spring MVC</servlet-name>
</filter-mapping>

    • Remove the following lines:

      <!-- Handles PTC requests -->
<servlet>
    <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
    <servlet-class>com.backbase.portal.ptc.ProxyServlet</servlet-class>
    <load-on-startup>2</load-on-startup>
</servlet>

<servlet-mapping>
    <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
    <url-pattern>/proxy/*</url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

  • Update portal.tld

    The tag library definition has changed. Add the following lines at the bottom of the portal.tld file:

    <tag>
    <name>tabContainerInit</name>
    <tag-class>com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.renderer.TabContainerInitTag
    </tag-class>
    <body-content>empty</body-content>
    <attribute>
        <name>src</name>
        <required>true</required>
        <rtexprvalue>true</rtexprvalue>
    </attribute>
</tag>
<tag>
    <name>areaSort</name>
    <tag-class>com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.renderer.AreaSortTag
    </tag-class>
    <body-content>empty</body-content>
    <attribute>
        <name>src</name>
        <required>true</required>
        <rtexprvalue>true</rtexprvalue>
    </attribute>
</tag>

  • Changed profile configuration

    Run your application server with the following parameter or add it to the JAVA_OPTS environment variable:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-database_server,ptc-[local|remote]

    1. Replace database_server with the database of Backbase Portal Foundation:

      Table 9.4. Database Parameters

      Database

      Parameter

      MySQL

      mysql

      Oracle

      oracle

      IBM DB2

      db2

      Microsoft SQL Server

      sqlserver

      H2

      h2

      If you do not specify the ps-database_server profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to H2.


    2. Set [local|remote] to local if you want to use Mashup Services embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. Set it to remote if you have installed Mashup Services stand-alone. If you do not specify the ptc-[local|remote] profile, Backbase Portal Foundation defaults to local.

      Note that if you set the profile to ptc-remote, the embedded instance of Mashup Services is disabled.

    For example, the parameter for MySQL and Mashup Services stand-alone is as follows:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=ps-mysql,ptc-remote

    Warning

    If Orchestrator runs on the same application server as Backbase Portal Foundation, spring.profiles.active should also include a profile for Orchestrator: orchestrator-database_server. For more information, see Install Orchestrator.

    Warning

    Either specify all profiles or none. If you specify some of the profiles, you will get an error, because the profiles you have not set will have no active profile. If you don't set the spring.profiles.active parameter, the default profiles will be active.

9.6.1 Database Migration

Follow the steps below to migrate the Backbase Portal Foundation database to Backbase Portal version 5.2.1:

  1. Backup your database.

  4. Skip this step if you already created the sys2sys user in Backbase Portal 5.2.0. If you did not create it, run the add_sys2sys.ddl script.

  5. Run the upgrade-5.2.0-to-5.2.1.dml script.

  6. Deploy the new version of Backbase Portal Foundation as described in Install Backbase Portal Foundation and restart the application server.

Note that each database folder contains a readme.txt file with further instructions.

Top

9.7 Migrating from 5.1 to 5.2

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.1 to version 5.2, you need to make the following changes:

  • Embedded Mashup Services installation changed

    Mashup Services is now always embedded in Backbase Portal Foundation. To accommodate this change, follow these steps:

    1. Open your POM file in the root folder of your portal project and remove the following dependency:

      <dependency>
    <groupId>com.backbase.services.mashup</groupId>
    <artifactId>mashup-embedded</artifactId>
    <version>${portal.mashup.version}</version>
</dependency>

    2. Open the web.xml file in src/main/webapp/WEB-INF in your portal project and add the following servlet:

          <!-- Handles PTC requests -->
    <servlet>
        <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
        <servlet-class>com.backbase.portal.ptc.ProxyServlet</servlet-class>
        <load-on-startup>2</load-on-startup>
    </servlet>

    <servlet-mapping>
        <servlet-name>ProxyServlet</servlet-name>
        <url-pattern>/proxy/*</url-pattern>
    </servlet-mapping>

  • Database

    Run database migration scripts, see Database Migration.

  • Bundles

    Backbase Portal has implemented a best practice for ordering files and folders within a portal project. A bundle consists of import files, templates, JavaScript, media and styling. For more information, see Bundles.

  • Including Backbase Portal Client

    Instead of calling the JS script of Backbase Portal Client, you can now include the following JSP template:

    <jsp:include page="../../common/portalclient-libs.jsp"/>

    This template checks whether the page is being edited in Backbase Portal Manager (development mode), and adds the necessary scripts.

  • Backbase Portal Client initialization

    The function to initialize Backbase Portal Client has changed. The script in the page template header portal.init().fetchPage(); is replaced by a script in the body tag:

    <body onload="b$.portal.startup('main')">

    The parameter in the startup function is the id of the HTML element in which Backbase Portal Client will render the page.

  • Custom client-side layouts

    The new Backbase Portal Client has no default client-side layouts. Instead, it offers the ability to create custom layouts. You can register a container client template that defines a custom layout, see How to Implement a Custom Layout. Also the bundles contain layouts you can use, see Bundles.

  • Drop areas

    The class that Backbase Portal Client recognizes as drop area has changed from portal-area to bp-area.

  • Class ssr

    This class is no longer necessary for server-side rendered widgets.

  • New device recognition configuration

    Added a configuration for device recognition, see Device Recognition Configuration.

  • New configuration key in uiEditingOptions.js

    Added mobile functionality to create and preview pages tailored for mobile and tablet devices in Backbase Portal Manager. You can configure this functionality in the portalDevices key in the Backbase Portal Manager Configuration.

9.8 Migrating from 5.0.4 to 5.1

If you are upgrading Backbase Portal from version 5.0.4 to version 5.1, follow the instructions in the following sections.

Top

9.8.1 Server-side Rendering

For server-side rendering to work in version 5.1, follow these steps:

  1. Add property to server-side rendered objects

    Server-side rendered pages, containers and/or widgets need the new property RenderAtServer set to true. You can do this by adding the following lines to the import file of the page, container and/or widget:

    <property name="RenderAtServer">
    <value type="boolean">true</value>
</property>

  2. Add class to templates

    For server-side rendered widgets, the containing <div> tag in a container template must have a class attribute set to ssr. For example, the following code from the default container shipped with Backbase Portal 5.0.4 renders a container and its children in the <div>:

    <div class="portal-area">
    <c:forEach items="${my_items.children}" var="child">
        <c:if test='${child.propertyDefinitions["area"].value.value == "1"}'>
            <b:include src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/${child}"/>
        </c:if>
    </c:forEach>
</div>

    The <div> tag must now change to:

    <div class="portal-area ssr">

Top

9.8.2 Migrating Page Templates

Add Class

With release 5.1, the HTML element that contains the page must have a class attribute set to pageContainer. The portal.init function refers to this HTML element. In this example, Backbase Portal Client will render the page in the HTML element with id="mycontentarea": 

portal.init('${item.contextItemName}').fetchPage('${item.name}',
    '#mycontentarea');

The page template in the documentation for Backbase Portal version 5.0.4 defined the <div> tag as follows:

<div id="mycontentarea">
</div>

With the new version, this must change to:

<div id="mycontentarea" class="pageContainer">
</div>
Remove Redundant Script

The script below was necessary to run Backbase Portal Client, but is now redundant. Remove it from your page templates.

<script type="text/javascript">
 /* <![CDATA[ */
        b$ = {};
        b$.browser = (function() {
            var browser = {};
            // Simple browser detection - Internet Explorer
            if (document.all && !navigator.userAgent.match(/opera/i)
                && !navigator.appVersion.match(/mac/i)){
                browser.ie = true;
                browser.version = parseFloat(navigator.appVersion.substr(
                    navigator.appVersion.indexOf('MSIE ')+5, 3) );
                (function (){
                    try {
                        //PRE MSXML <3 support for example Windows 98/2000 machines
                        var oXml = new ActiveXObject('MSXML2.XSLTemplate');
                    } catch(oError) {
                        browser.ie = false;
                    }
                })();
            }
            return browser;
        })();
        /* ]]> */
    </script>

For more information, see Page Template.

10 Solving Problems

10.1. Checklist
10.2. Known Issues

10.1 Checklist

Consider the following checklist when installing or upgrading Backbase Portal:

  • Clear application server cache

    Before re-installing a module or upgrading to a newer version, clear the application server cache:

    • Apache Tomcat: remove the work, temp, and conf/Catalina/localhost folders within the Apache Tomcat installation.

    • JBoss: remove the work and temp folders from the server/server folder. Replace server with the appropriate folder in your installation.

    • WebSphere: remove the temp and wstemp folders from the profiles/AppSrv01 within the WebSphere installation. On Microsoft Windows, also clear the contents of C:/Documents and Settings/user_name/Local Settings/Application Data/IBM/IBM Information Server console.

    For all the application servers, remove the directory containing the exploded WAR file.

  • Check installation

    Check the installation procedure or development setup of the module. Every step is mandatory, except for the Development Setup: only the first step is mandatory, the other steps add Backbase Portal Manager and bundles to the project.

  • Clear browser cache

    Changes to Backbase Portal may not be visible, because your browser has cached data. Sometimes refreshing the page is not enough. Try clearing your browser cache:

    • Google Chrome

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Empty the cache and click Clear browsing data.

    • Mozilla Firefox

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Cache and click Clear Now.

    • Microsoft Internet Explorer

      Press Ctrl+Shift+Del to open the dialog, check Temporary Internet files and click Delete.

    • Apple Safari

      Press Option+Command+E (or go to Safari|Empty Cache... in the menu) to open the dialog and click Empty.

    • Opera

      Go to Settings|Delete Private Data... in the menu to open the dialog, select Delete entire cache and click Delete.

  • Perform migration actions

    When you have upgraded Backbase Portal, perform the migration actions, like running migration scripts, listed in Migration.

  • Same version across modules

    Using different versions of Backbase Portal modules may cause problems. Upgrade the modules to the shipped versions, see Package Contents. Perform the migration steps listed in Migration.

  • Upgrade Maven project from artifact

    When upgrading Backbase Portal, also upgrade the Maven project from the artifact, see Create Project.

  • Clean Maven .m2 directory

    Remove the backbase folder in .m2/repository/com. In Unix, this is located under /home/user. In Microsoft Windows, under C:\Users\user.

  • Content Services drop tables

    If you want to delete the content of Content Services, you need to drop the tables configuration, content and resource and then also delete the folder C:\.backbase\contentservices on Microsoft Windows or /usr/home/user_name/.backbase/contentservices on Unix.

    Then recreate the tables, see Databases.

  • Content Services temporary folder

    Content Services needs the temporary folder of the application server, e.g. tomcat_install_dir/temp. If this folder is missing, adding content to Content Services from Backbase Portal Manager fails.

  • Change session cookie name

    Running multiple instances of Backbase Portal Foundation with the same application context - but different port numbers - on the same machine can cause problems in user session handling. To solve this, change the session cookie name for each application server on the machine:

    • Apache Tomcat: add the following parameter to your JAVA_OPTS variable:

      -Dorg.apache.catalina.SESSION_COOKIE_NAME=session_name

      Replace session_name with any session cookie name you may prefere.

    • JBoss: for each application server, set the org.apache.catalina.JSESSIONID system property to any session cookie name you may prefere. For example, add the following to the standalone.xml file:

      <system-properties>
    <property name="org.apache.catalina.JSESSIONID" value="MYID"/>
</system-properties>

    • WebSphere: in the administrative console, go to Servers > Application Servers > your_server > Server Infrastructure > Java and Process Management > Process Definition > Java Virtual Machine > Custom Properties > New.

      Name the property HttpSessionIdReuse, and set its value to true. Save you changes and restart the application server.

  • Disable Compatibility View in Microsoft Internet Explorer

    Microsoft Internet Explorer may incorrectly render Backbase Portal if Compatibility View is enabled. Disable it in the Developer Tools screen.

Top

10.2 Known Issues

This is a list of some of the current known issues that you may encounter when using Backbase Portal:

  • Deploying Backbase Portal Foundation version 5.3 may return a Context initialization failed exception if the following two conditions are met:

    • The foundation.auditing property is set to true

    • The application server is passed a JVM parameter with a Spring profile (i.e. -Dspring.profiles.active=some_profile)

    As a workaround, append the following to the Spring profile parameter:

    ,auditing,ps-database_server

    Replace database_server with the database Audit Trails is using:

    Table 10.1. Database Parameters

    Database

    Parameter

    MySQL

    mysql

    Oracle

    oracle

    IBM DB2

    db2

    Microsoft SQL Server

    sqlserver

    H2

    h2


    For example, if Audit Trails is using MySQL, pass the following JVM parameter to your application server:

    -Dspring.profiles.active=some_profile,auditing,ps-mysql

  • Deploying Orchestrator on JBoss may return the following error:

    ERROR o.h.util.JDBCExceptionReporter - Unable to get managed connection for jdbc/orchestratorDS; - nested throwable: (javax.resource.ResourceException: Unable to get managed connection for jdbc/orchestratorDS)
...
Caused by: javax.resource.ResourceException: Unable to get managed connection for jdbc/orchestratorDS

    Orchestrator should still deploy correctly and return the following message:

    INFO  [[/orchestrator]] Initializing Spring FrameworkServlet 'dispatcher'

    Test the Orchestrator installation as explained in Install Orchestrator.

  • Upgrading from version 5.2.x to 5.3.0 deletes all publishing messages in the PUBLISHING dashboard.

    You can still access the messages in the tb_work_package_logs table of the Orchestrator database.

  • Extending pages in version 5.2.5 returns an error. This bug is being worked on in issue MAINT-670. Please upgrade to a more recent version.

Top

1 Overview

1.1. Features
1.2. Package Contents

Backbase Portal offers a flexible way to manage web portals. Its architecture is based on a rich presentation layer and a loosely coupled Web-Oriented Architecture, and combines content and interaction in one solution. This is most evident with widgets, independent web applications that form the portal building blocks.

With Backbase Portal, end-users can personalize the online environments, the information and the applications they need. They can also add content, adjust visualisation preferences, and rearrange layouts.

The following figure shows the main modules of Backbase Portal:

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client shows the portal and enables interaction with the widgets. It communicates with Backbase Portal Foundation on the background to store the changes the end-user makes to the portal.

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation is the main engine that receives requests from clients, retrieves objects from the data store, sends responses back to the client and stores changes in the data store. It can serve multiple portal instances. For more information, see Portal.

Mashup Services.  Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Mashup Services.

Content Services.  Content Services, an optional module, delivers local and remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. For more information, see Content Services.

1.1 Features

Backbase Portal Foundation

  • Multi-tenancy—Backbase Portal Foundation is capable of hosting multiple portals.

  • Data Storage—a single data store stores all portal instances (and their personalization data), Access Control List mappings, and (optionally) user credentials. This combination provides the foundation for a robust and flexible authorization and authentication mechanism.

  • Personalization—changes made by end-users to their personal Backbase Portal space are persisted from one application session to the next. The storage of personalizations is based on storing only the changes made to the original object. This method makes the data store very efficient.

  • Authentication—the use of Spring Security allows custom integration with a variety of authentication services. Backbase Portal relies on a single identity store to serve all portal instances, and can be configured to use either an external identity store or one that resides in the Backbase Portal data store. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Authorization—support for both role-based and resource-based authorization delivers a robust and flexible access control mechanism. In both cases, authorization is governed by the combination of the authenticated end-user, permissions (as defined by the groups to which an end-user belongs), and the Backbase Portal object the end-user is trying to access. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist objects, users, groups and preferences to several supported databases.

  • Portal and Page Management—a REST interface is available for managing Backbase Portal Foundation and and the portal instances it hosts. For more information, please refer to the REST API.

  • Widget Compatibility—Backbase Portal supports multiple widget formats, including Backbase Portal 4 gadgets.

  • Widget Library—out-of-the-box widgets are available for common end-user tasks, including a login page.

Content Services

  • Content Aggregation—data imported from remote content sources is stored in the Content Services content repository.

  • Installation—Content Services is delivered as a web application (WAR file) that can be deployed to one or more J2EE application servers.

  • Integration—CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) and WebDAV interfaces for working with content.

  • Administration—JMX (Java Management Extensions) interface for managing and monitoring the delivery service.

  • Scalability—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for a variety of backend technologies, including enterprise-level databases and JCR (Java Content Repository).

  • Performance—support for clustering means that Content Services instances can be configured for optimal delivery.

  • Failover—support for clustering means that requests can be routed to different Content Services instances if one instance is unavailable.

  • Importers—an optional Content Services component for importing external feeds.

  • Schedulers—for automated import of content.

  • Persistence—uses Hibernate to persist content to several supported databases.

Mashup Services

  • Proxy Service—proxying is needed to overcome the same-origin security policy that modern browsers apply to AJAX calls. To request resources (such as an XML file or application) from other intranet or Internet domains, Proxy Services proxies the request to the remote resource.

  • Transformation Service—provides filters and transformers that act on the request/response workflow.

  • Caching Service—improves performance by writing requested resources to cache. The default caching mechanism is implemented using Ehcache.

1 Architecture

1.1. Distributed Environment
1.2. Release Management
1.3. Object Model
1.4. Authentication and Authorization
1.5. Caches
1.6. Third-party Dependencies

Backbase Portal has a different setup on editorial environments or staging/live environments. The main difference is that editorial environments contain Backbase Portal Manager and the other environments don't. For more information on environments, see Release Management. Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers, see Distributed Environment.

Editorial Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in an editorial environment is as follows:

Here follows a brief description of the items in the diagram.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following tasks:

    • Authentication and Authorization

    • Server-side rendering

    • Persist changes to pages (and other objects) on the data store. For more information, see Object Model.

    • Audit Trails (optional)

      Audit Trails logs data about successful CRUD operations executed in editorial environments. The records include the user, the timestamp, the affected item, and the type of operation. Audit Trails is optional and uses a secured database that runs along the Backbase Portal Foundation database on the same server. ADMIN users can access the logs from the Audit Trail app in Backbase Portal Manager.

      For more information, see Install Audit Trails and Audit Trails.

  • Mashup Services

    Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter and transform HTTP requests and responses. For more information, see Mashup Services.

  • Content Services

    Content Services is a content delivery platform. It can store content to its own database and can harvest remote content, for example from CMIS repositories. For more information, see Content Services.

  • Orchestrator

    Orchestrator publishes database objects and content from Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services. It performs the following tasks:

    • It locks items after a publishing request.

    • It creates, sends, retrieves, archives, and unpacks publish packages.

    • It waits for approval of an authorized user before publishing.

    For more information, see Publishing.

  • Backbase Portal Manager

    Backbase Portal Manager is an application that allows business users to manage and design pages in the portal and publish the changes to another environment, e.g. from editorial to staging. Backbase Portal Manager communicates with Backbase Portal to store changes and with Orchestrator to publish changes.

    For more information, see Backbase Portal Manager.

  • Templates

    Developers create templates that define how a page (and containers and widgets on the page) are rendered.

    For more information, see Customization.

  • Backbase Portal Client

    Backbase Portal Client performs the following tasks:

    • Client-side rendering

    • Handle interaction on the page and communicate changes to Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • REST client

    Backbase Portal Foundation has a REST interface and you can use any REST client to communicate with it. Data is conveyed via XML. For more information, see Communication.

Staging/Live Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in staging or live environments is similar to the editorial environment, except that it does not include Backbase Portal Manager. Only the live environment is accessible for end-users.

1.1 Distributed Environment

Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers:

Take the following actions when moving a module to a different server:

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Edit the ice-config.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the server running Mashup Services. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation data store

    Edit the database configuration of Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the portalDS datasource

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Mashup Services (stand-alone)

    Edit the -DPORTALSERVER_PROXY_URL=mashup_services_url parameter either in the JAVA_OPTS environment variable or in the start up script of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services

    1. Edit the ice-config.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the server running Mashup Services.

    2. Edit the following properties in the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation:

      • foundation.content.proxy.destination

      • foundation.content.proxy.username

      • foundation.content.proxy.password

      For more information, see Configuration.

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services database

    Edit the database configuration of Content Services:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the content-ds, configuration-ds and resource-ds datasources

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Content Services file system

    Set contentservices.repository.configuration.fileLocation in the backbase.properties file to a shared folder located on a different machine. For more information, see Content Services Settings.

  • Orchestrator

    Edit the following properties in the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.destination

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.username

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.password

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Orchestrator database

    Edit the database configuration of Orchestrator:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the orchestratorDS datasource

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

1.2 Release Management

Overview

Release management in Backbase Portal requires a DTAP route and a publishing route. The DTAP (development, test, acceptance and production) route handles the release of files. The publishing (editorial, staging, live) route handles the release of database objects.

Staging and live environments do not contain Backbase Portal Manager. For Backbase Portal Foundation, development environments are Maven projects. Test, accept, and production environments are deployed WAR files.

DTAP Route

For Backbase Portal Foundation, files in the portal project are released via DTAP. Make sure to follow the best practice of using Bundles. You can either package a bundle and unpack it in another environment, or package the portal project in a WAR file and deploy the WAR to another environment.

For Mashup Services and Content Services, only an upgrade of the WAR file and configuration files are released via the DTAP route.

Publishing Route

Database objects of Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services and the content repository of Content Services are released via publishing. Mashup Services is not part of publishing.

1.3 Object Model

This section explains the object model of Backbase Portal Foundation:

Backbase Portal Objects

These are the main objects in Backbase Portal:

  • Portals, pages, containers, widgets, and links

    These objects form the portal website, see Customization.

  • Users and groups

    Needed for Authentication and Authorization.

  • Templates

    Determine how pages, containers, and widgets are rendered, see Customization.

  • Catalogs

Inheritance

The Backbase Portal object model uses inheritance extensively. When a business user places a widget on a page from the catalog, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the widget in the catalog. The new widget inherits all elements from the extended widget.

Similarly, when an end-user personalizes an object, Backbase Portal Foundation extends the original object and applies the personalization. An example of a personalization is moving a widget to another location on the page.

Both in the case of extensions and personalizations, Backbase Portal only saves changes and not the inherited elements. This makes the Backbase Portal object model scalable and efficient.

Rights can either be set for a particulart object, or inherited as follows:

  • Abstract objects in the server catalog inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • Abstract objects in a portal catalog inherit the rights from the portal.

  • Instantiated objects inherit the rights from their parent (either a portal, a page, or a container).

If any part of the rights of an object is set, all inherited rights are copied to the object.

State, Scope, and Role

Each object has a state that combines two security aspects of the object:

  • Who can access this object?

    Backbase Portal supports multi-tenancy: you can manage multiple portals with one installation. Objects exist within one of three scopes and only administrators can access objects with the highest scope. This way, managers and users of a portal cannot access objects on another portal.

  • Is the object defined or instantiated?

    A defined object has no parent. An instantiated object has a parent, which is either a portal, a page, or a container. This means that only an instantiated object is visible on the portal website.

    For example, when a widget is created, it has a defined state and no parent. When someone drags it on a page, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the defined widget. The new widget will have an instantiated state and the page as parent.

Deleting Objects

Deleting an object in Backbase Portal has the following impact:

  • Children

    Some objects can have children (see Children above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always cascade, i.e. children are deleted as well.

    For example, if you delete a page, its containers and widgets are also deleted.

  • Inheritance

    Backbase Portal extends objects to make the object model efficient (see Inheritance above). Deletions in Backbase Portal propagate, meaning that objects inheriting from the deleted object are deleted as well. For example, if you delete a catalog widget, its widget instances are also deleted. However, it is not possible to delete master pages that other pages extend. Backbase Portal Manager offers an easy method to delete master pages, because a pop-up asks you to select a different master page for pages that inherit from the master page you are trying to delete.

  • Link references

    Deleting a link also deletes the page the link refers to. This is the page referred to by the link ItemRef property. If other links refer to the same page, the following applies:

    • If another link refers to the same page, the page is not deleted.

    • If a state link refers to the same page, the page is deleted and the state link is also deleted.

Only users with the ADMIN role can delete objects.

If enabled, Audit Trails logs DELETE operations. For more information, see Architecture.

Note

Deletions in Backbase Portal cannot be undone.

Deleting Properties

It is possible to delete object properties by setting the MarkedForDeletion attribute to true in a PUT call. For more information, see propertyType.

If enabled, Audit Trails logs PUT operations. For more information, see Architecture.

Rights

Backbase Portal objects have an Access Control List called rights. Each right maps a security item (a group or role) to a permission. The Spring Security configuration determines how security items (groups and roles) map to permissions.

Rights are enforced on objects and on properties of objects. Accordingly, there is an element for each right type: itemRight and propertyRight.

Rights Inheritance

Objects either inherit their rights or have their own rights:

  • Not inherit

    The itemRight element has an inherited attribute. If an administrator sets the rights of an object, Backbase Portal Foundation sets the inherited attribute tofalse and saves the new rights for the object.

  • Inherit

    If the inherited attribute is true, the object inherits rights as follows:

    • Abstract objects (without a parent):

      • Objects in the server scope inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

      • Objects in a portal scope inherit the rights from the portal.

    • Instantiated objects (with a parent) inherit the rights from the parent.

Note that links inherit rights in the same way, but the property SecuritySameAsParent determines whether the link inherits its rights or not. Backbase Portal Foundation also sets the inherited attribute on the itemRight object, but the SecuritySameAsParent property is leading.

Backbase Portal Objects

The main objects in Backbase Portal are templates, catalogs, portals, pages, containers, widgets, and links.

For more information, see Object Model.

Exposing URLs

You may want to limit access to some URLs of the public portal to avoid end users seeing 'not authorized' messages instead of 'not available' messages. You cannot limit access to the following URLs, because they are necessary for functionality of Backbase Portal:

  • All portal, page, container and widget URLs belonging to REST Interface

  • /proxy — only when integrating with Mashup Services

  • /content — only when integrating with Content Services

Other URLs are eligible to limit access to:

  • /import

  • /caches

  • /groups

  • /users

  • /templates

  • /orchestrator

  • /configuration

  • /publishing

1.5 Caches

Backbase Portal Foundation uses the following caches to improve response time:

Table 1.8. Caches

Name

Description

globalModelCache

Caches the object model that Backbase Portal Foundation retrieves from the database.

retrievedWidgetCache

Caches the widget definitions that Backbase Portal Foundation retrieves from the server.

widgetCache

Caches the widget chromes that Backbase Portal Foundation retrieves from the server.

webCache

Caches fully rendered pages including children according to the configuration, see Backbase Portal Foundation Settings. This is useful for landing pages that require fast response time. Only use this cache for pages that are exactly the same for every user. None of the layouts or widgets on the page may be personalized and the security settings should be the same for every role and group, including anonymous users.


For testing, you can clean the caches with REST calls, see Caches.

Change Cache Settings

If you want to change the caching settings, you need to unpack the com.backbase.portal.foundation-configuration-5.3.1.1.jar located in target/your_project/WEB-INF/lib in your portal project or WEB-INF/lib in the unpacked WAR file. You can do this by renaming the file to *.zip. Open the ehcache.xml file located in the unpacked JAR. Each cache has the following format:

<cache name="name"
    attribute="value"
    attribute="value"
    ...
    />

Only change caches mentioned in the table above. Do not change caches with a different name. The table below lists the most used attributes. After changing the settings, rezip the files and rename to ZIP to JAR.

The following table lists the most used attributes supported by Ehcache. For more information, please refer to Ehcache configuration.

Parameter

Data Type

Description

  • The idle time before an element expires.

  • The default amount of time to idle for an element from its last accessed or modified date.

The parameter is only needed if the element is not eternal. To define an infinite idle time, set the value to 0.

long

2 Publishing

2.1. What Gets Published?
2.2. Publishing Process
2.3. Publishing States
2.4. Security

Backbase Portal supports publishing pages and content to different environments in a controlled manner. A typical setup has an editorial, staging and live environment:

  • Editorial environment

    Editors work with Backbase Portal Manager to make changes to pages and publish these changes (see Publishing Pages). The editorial environment requires Backbase Portal Manager and an Orchestrator in editorial mode.

    Editorial environments support the optional Audit Trails feature. For more information, see Architecture.

  • Staging environment

    A business user previews the changes on the staging environment, then approves or rejects them via Backbase Portal Manager (running on the editorial environment). You can manage the whole publishing flow from Backbase Portal Manager, see Publishing Pages. Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the staging environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The staging environment requires an Orchestrator to process publish packages from the editorial Orchestrator.

  • Live environment

    End-users can access the portal on the live environment (e.g. via the Internet). Backbase Portal Manager should not run on the live environment to prevent directly changing this environment. The live environment requires an Orchestrator to process publishing packages from the editorial Orchestrator.

2.1 What Gets Published?

Backbase Portal can publish objects present in the data store (see Object Model) and content from Content Services. It is not possible to publish files used by the portal (e.g. widget definitions, template files, configuration files).

For more information, see Which Route?.

When publishing within an environment, as explained in Publishing Within an Environment, friendly URLs are not published.

Inheritance

Objects in Backbase Portal Foundation can inherit from other objects. If you publish an object that inherits from another object, Orchestrator also publishes the base object. For example, if you publish a widget derived from a catalog widget, Orchestrator also publishes the catalog widget.

This rule does not apply to:

  • Objects in server scope, such as templates and items in the server catalog: these objects are never published.

  • Master pages: publish master pages before publishing normal pages. Backbase Portal does not allow publishing pages without a master page. For more information, see Publishing States.

For a broader overview of inheritance in Backbase Portal see Object Model.

Children

Orchestrator publishes the requested objects and their parents. Publishing a container tab, for example, automatically causes the parent page to be published as well. Likewise, publishing a link will cause all its parents up to the root link to be published. The pages referenced by the parent links, however, are not published.

For example, a page is part of a two-level navigation tree. When you publish the page, Orchestrator publishes the page, its link, and the parent link. The page associated with the parent link is not published. The parent link on the staging environment will be a header link.

This way, the navigation tree stays consistent even if it is only partially published, but prevents pages from being published unless explicitly requested.

Unpublishing an object causes its children to be unpublished as well.

Top

2.2 Publishing Process

Orchestrator and the Publishing Chain

The Orchestrator module is in charge of the publishing process. It must be present on all environments alongside Backbase Portal Foundation, but uses an independent database. Orchestrator locks data, sends and retrieves packages, manages approvals, and unlocks data.

These actions are part of the publishing chain:

  1. An editor modifies a page in the portal or content in Content Services. Examples of changes are: adding a widget, changing the position of a widget, changing the layout of a page, editing a text.

  2. The editor publishes the changes in Backbase Portal Manager.

  3. The editorial Orchestrator locks the data (making further modifications impossible), creates a package, archives it on the file system, and sends it to a staging environment.

  4. The Orchestrator in the staging environment unpacks the data and publishes them to Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services.

  5. An approver previews the portal on the staging environment.

    • If the approver rejects the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data for further modifications.

    • If the approver accepts the changes:

      1. The editorial Orchestrator sends the package to the live environment.

      2. The Orchestrator in the live environment unpacks the package and publishes it to the outside world.

      3. The editorial Orchestrator unlocks the data.

Backbase Portal ships with these publishing chains. Currently, other publishing chains are not supported.

  • Direct

    This chain has no staging environment, so a published page is immediately visible on the live environment.

  • Approval on Package

    The approver can approve or reject the package. A rejected package will not continue to the live environment.

  • Approval on Pages

    The approver needs to approve every single page in the package. If he rejects one or more pages, the package will not continue to the live environment.

For more information about configuring the publishing chain, see Publishing Configuration.

Publishing Within an Environment

For testing and demo purposes, Backbase Portal can also publish within one environment. In this scenario, publishing takes place across different portals instead of environments. This allows the use of publishing functionality without installing Backbase Portal on multiple machines. Content is not published in this scenario. This means that the editorial portal uses the same content in Content Services as the live portal.

For example, Orchestrator publishes from the editorial portal to the staging portal and from there to the live portal:

Publishing within an environment is an optional feature configurable in the Orchestrator configuration file, see Publishing Configuration.

Unpublishing

Unpublishing means removing pages from a portal. On staging or live environments, unpublished pages are removed from the local data store. On editorial environments, pages continue to exist in the data store of the editorial environment so that they are still available for future publishing, if needed. If you want to delete a published item, you first need to unpublish it.

Before you can unpublish a page, it needs to have completed the publishing chain. For example, if a page follows the Approval on Pages publishing chain explained above, it cannot be unpublished until it has reached the live environment, or until an approver has rejected the publishing request.

It is not possible to unpublish master pages if their derived pages are still published. To unpublish a master page, unpublish first their derived pages.

Warning

When unpublishing a page, make sure you select the correct publishing chain. For example, if a page was published to a live environment through a Approval on Pages publishing chain, unpublishing it through a Direct publishing chain will return an error.

Republishing

If you published some pages and subsequently modified them in the editorial environment, you can republish those pages with one button click in Backbase Portal Manager. This republishes all modified pages that have already been published to other environments.

The links and CMIS content related to the pages are republished as well. Republishing has the same effect as manually selecting the individual pages, but can save time and is less error-prone.

Top

2.3 Publishing States

Backbase Portal Manager uses colored icons to signal the state of an item as it is published along a publishing chain. Icons vary in color depending on the values of the <publishState> element of the page, its links, and master page.

The following table summarizes the meaning of each icon:

Table 2.1. Publishing States

Icon

Link

Orange

The publishing chain for the page, its links, and the master page was completed, but there are local modifications.

Orange

The link was unpublished and the page has local modifications. This is only possible when a page has aliases.

The link was unpublished, but the page is still published and reachable via its hierarchical URL. This happens when unpublishing a parent page automatically unpublishes the children links.

The page was unpublished but the link is still published. This happens automatically to preserve the integrity of the navigation tree.

For more information on the <publishState> element, see itemType.

Top

2.4 Security

Orchestrator has two roles that you can map to groups in Backbase Portal Foundation:

  • publisher

    Allows users to submit publish requests.

  • approver

    Allows Approvers to approve or reject publish requests.

For example, you can create an approver group in Backbase Portal Foundation, assign users to this group, and then map the group to the approver role in the configuration of Orchestrator as explained in Publishing Configuration. Members of the approver group now can approve publish requests in Backbase Portal Manager.

Note that Backbase Portal enforces the four-eye principle: a user who submits a publish request may not approve it.

3.2.1 Content Template

The content template for the Image and Text widget in the ICE bundle is a Mustache template. The shipped templates are located in the target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate folder in your portal project or static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate in the unpacked WAR file.

You can use CSS to change the layout of the template. Simply adjust the CSS file referenced in the page template. You can also create your own content template as follows:

  1. Copy default template

    Create the src/main/webapp/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate folder in your portal project. Copy AdvancedImageText.html or AdvancedImageText2.html from target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate to the folder you just created. Use either of these files as an example to customize.

  2. Change the file name

    Change the file name to mycontenttemplate.html.

  3. Edit the template

    Adjust the template, see How To Change the Content Template.

  4. Copy widget definition

    Create the folder src/main/webapp/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/widgets/AdvanceContentTemplate in your portal project. Copy index.html from target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/widgets/AdvanceContentTemplate to the folder you just created.

  5. Add content template to preference selection

    Add your template to the enumeration list of the templateUrl preference in the widget definition as follows:

    <g:preference name="templateUrl" label="Content Template" type="select-one">
    <g:enumeration label="Backbase Advanced template" value="$(contextRoot)/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate/AdvancedImageText.html"/>
    <g:enumeration label="Backbase Advanced template 2" value="$(contextRoot)/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate/AdvancedImageText2.html"/>
    <g:enumeration label="My Template" value="$(contextRoot)/static/backbase.com.2011.ice/html/ContentTemplate/mycontenttemplate.html"/>
</g:preference>

    When editing the preferences of this widget, the drop-down box will now include your template.

  6. Restart the project

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

  7. Run the importer

    If you use the embedded H2 database, you need to run the importer tool. Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 3.14. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

  8. Open Backbase Portal Manager

    Open the following URL: http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/dashboard. If you edit an Image and Text widget, the Content Template drop-down box will now contain My Template.

How To Change the Content Template

The default content templates consist of image(s) and a rich text element. Changing the content template requires the following:

  • Adding images and rich text elements

  • Changing the order of the image(s) the rich text element(s)

  • Adding classes to the image(s) and to the rich text element

  • Removing optional sub elements, e.g. the title from a rich text element or the alternative text from an image.

How to Add or Edit an Image.  To add an image, copy the following code to your custom template: 

<div class='bd-imageContent-dropArea'>
    <img data-parentId="id" {{id.content}} title="{{id.bb:title}}"
     subtitle="{{id.bb:subtitle}}" alt="{{id.bb:altText}}"/>
</div>

The navigation templates are Mustache templates. The shipped templates are located at target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav/navTemplate in your portal project or static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav/navTemplate in the unpacked WAR file.

Follow these steps to create your own navigation template for the AdvancedNav widget definition:

  1. Copy default template

    Create the src/main/webapp/static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav/navTemplate/mynavigation folder in your portal project. Copy all files from a shipped template folder: target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav/navTemplate/a-shipped-template, to the folder you just created. Use these files as an example to customize.

  2. Edit the template

    Adjust the template. You can use the following Mustache tags:

    • {{Url}} — the link Url property. For more information, see link.

    • {{title}} — the link title property.

    • {{#links}} ... {{/links}} — loops over the links within a portal.

    • {{#children}} ... {{/children}} — loops over the children of a link.

  3. Copy widget definition

    Copy index.html from target/your_project/static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav to the src/main/webapp/static/backbase.com.2012.nexus/widgets/AdvancedNav folder in your portal project.

</g:preference>

    When editing the preferences of this widget, the drop-down box will now include your template.

  5. Restart the project

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war
