This chapter describes how to customize a portal. The main building blocks for a portal are a page, links, containers and widgets. Backbase Portal renders these building blocks according to their templates. The building blocks (objects) together with their templates determine how pages in the portal look.

This is a schematic overview of a page in a portal:

Portals contain the following elements:

  • Page

    Typical Pages contain a header, a navigation bar, one or more containers, and a footer. The page template determines how the page is rendered.

  • Link

    Links store pointers to pages or containers or to external URLs. They form the navigation of the portal. See Custom Navigation Widgets.

  • Container

    Containers contain the widgets. The container and its template determine the layout of the widgets on the page.

  • Widget

    Widgets are autonomous mini-applications or content units.

Click on the image to learn more about the elements in a page.

4.1 Client-side and Server-side Rendering

Model-view-controller Pattern

Backbase Portal is based on the Spring MVC framework and implements the model-view-controller pattern. When a client requests an object (page, container, or widget), the rendering of the object model stored in the data store to the visible view happens either client-side or server-side: in the former case the controller is Backbase Portal Client, in the latter it is Backbase Portal Foundation.

A page in Backbase Portal is always server-side rendered. The Page Template loads Backbase Portal Client that can then render the containers and widgets on the page, but Backbase Portal Foundation can also render these server-side. See the flow chart below and the two scenarios are described in detail in the following sections.

Note

Green arrows show server-side rendering

Red arrows show client-side rendering

Relative Merits

Each rendering mode has advantages over the other. See the following list for an overview:

  • Cost: the computing and memory resources needed to render objects on the server are limited and come at a cost. Implementing client-side rendering reduces the pressure on the available servers.

  • Bandwidth usage: in client-side rendering only the model is exchanged - in XML format - with minimal bandwidth usage. Serving the full HTML code is much more resource-consuming.

  • Required skills: client-side rendering is based on JavaScript, while server-side rendering uses JavaServer Pages. The skills available in-house play a role in balancing between the two modes.

  • Rendering speed: objects are generally rendered faster client-side. In client-side rendering, the server and client only exchange the model XML code instead of the HTML for the whole page, so changes are rendered quickly.

  • Speed at first load: perhaps contradicting the previous point, objects like pages and containers are loaded faster server-side the first time. Client-side, objects need to load all related resources (like JavaScript files) before they can be rendered, providing a slower user experience.

  • Search Engine Optimization (SEO): client-side scripting often scores badly in search rankings. If SEO is a requirement, server-side rendering is the better alternative.

  • Accessibility: dynamic content is often not accessible by users with disabilities. If accessibility is a requirement, developers should consider server-side rendering.

  • Security: client-side rendering tends to be more secure because the attack surface is limited to the REST API, while server-side rendering also needs the HTML API.

  • Simplicity: the model-view-controller pattern for client-side rendering only involves one controller - the JavaScript code. Server-side rendering also needs JavaServer Pages, and is conceptually more complex.

Top

4.1.1 Server-side Rendering

If a client requests a server-side rendered object, the server renders the HTML according to the JavaServer Pages template of the object. Backbase Portal Client handles interaction, e.g. when the user moves a widget. It sends changes to the model back to the server as XML through the REST API. The flow chart below shows server-side rendering.

Note

The black lines show how Backbase Portal renders a requested page

The red lines show what happens upon user interaction (e.g. drag and drop of widgets)

The green objects list the properties that are necessary to render the object

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following actions server-side:

  1. Page

    Backbase Portal Foundation renders the page according to the Page Template referenced by the TemplateName property in the page object. The b:include tag includes the children of the page (containers or widgets).

  2. Container

    Backbase Portal Foundation renders the container according to the Container Server Template referenced by the TemplateName property in the container object. The b:include tag includes the children of the containers (widgets). Most layouts contain with multiple areas that include the widgets based on the value of their area property.

  3. Widget

    1. Backbase Portal Foundation renders the widget according to the Widget Template referenced by the TemplateName property in the widget object. The body of the widget template should only contain the b:widget tag.

    2. Backbase Portal Foundation renders the widget chrome, i.e. title bar, border and content area, according to the Widget Chrome Template referenced by the widgetChrome property in the widget object. The content area should include the widget definition with the {{{widgetContent}}} place holder.

    3. Backbase Portal Foundation retrieves the widget definition referenced by the src property in the widget object and inserts the content from the body of the widget definition in the content area of the widget chrome.

  4. Include model in response

    Backbase Portal Foundation includes the page, container and widget objects as XML in the <xmp> tag in the response.

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client performs the following actions client-side:

  1. Initialize

    The b$.portal.startup() function in the page template body tag initializes Backbase Portal Client.

  2. Page

    The page template contains an HTML element with the data-pid attribute that matches the name of the page object, so Backbase Portal Client knows the page is server-side rendered.

    Backbase Portal Client recognizes elements with the bp-area class as areas.

  3. Container

    The container server template contains an HTML element with the data-pid attribute that matches the name of the container object, so Backbase Portal Client knows the container is server-side rendered.

    Backbase Portal Client recognizes elements with the bp-area class as areas.

  4. Widget

    The widget chrome contains an HTML element with the data-pid attribute that matches the name of the widget object, so Backbase Portal Client knows the widget is server-side rendered.

    Backbase Portal Client recognizes the element with the bp-ui-dragGrip class as the element suitable for dragging, usually the title bar.

  5. Handle interaction

    When the visitor of the portal drags and drops widgets or changes preferences, Backbase Portal Client adjusts the HTML and also updates the XML model and communicates the changes to Backbase Portal Foundation via the REST API. If necessary, Backbase Portal Client re-renders containers and widgets, see Client-side Rendering below.

JSP File Selection

Each object (page, container, widget) has a template referenced in its TemplateName property. The template can reference multiple JSP files in its properties. The selection of the JSP file uses one of these methods (in order of precedence):

  1. Portal default device

    The portal DefaultDevice property overrules all other selection methods including the device recognition configuration. Whatever device made the request, the portal DefaultDevice property will select the JSP file to render the object. When you change the Optimized for field in Backbase Portal Manager, this portal property changes. This setting is useful for responsive design templates or for specialized mobile portals. If the template does not have a property that corresponds to the portal DefaultDevice property, then Backbase Portal Foundation tries the next method.

    For example, if the portal DefaultDevice property is mobile, Backbase Portal Foundation checks if the template has a property with the name mobile. If that property exists, Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the template mobile property.

  2. Device recognition configuration — device type

    Backbase Portal Foundation matches the User-Agent in the HTTP request header with the Device Recognition Configuration configuration. The type attribute of the matching device tag selects the JSP file to render the object. If the template does not have a property that corresponds to the type attribute, then Backbase Portal Foundation tries the next method.

    For example, if the User-Agent in the HTTP request header matches with the <device type="Samsung_Galaxy" fallbackTypes="mobile"> tag in the device recognition configuration, Backbase Portal Foundation checks if the template has a property with the name Samsung_Galaxy. If that property exists, Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the template Samsung_Galaxy property.

  3. Device recognition configuration — device fallback type

    Backbase Portal Foundation matches the User-Agent in the HTTP request header with the Device Recognition Configuration configuration. The entries in the fallbackTypes attribute of the matching device tag select the JSP file to render the object. If the template does not have a property that corresponds to any of the entries in the fallbackTypes attribute, then Backbase Portal Foundation tries the next method.

    For example, the User-Agent in the HTTP request header matched with the <device type="Samsung_Galaxy" fallbackTypes="mobile"> tag in the device recognition configuration, but no Samsung_Galaxy property exists in the template. In this case, Backbase Portal Foundation checks if the template has a property with the name mobile. If that property exists, Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the template mobile property.

  4. Template default device

    The template DefaultDevice property is the final method to select the JSP file. If the template does not have a property that corresponds to the template DefaultDevice property, then Backbase Portal Foundation throws an error.

    For example, all selection methods did not match a template property. The template DefaultDevice property has the value Web. Backbase Portal Foundation checks if the template has a property with the name Web. If that property exists, Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the template Web property.

Top

4.1.2 Client-side Rendering

If an object is client-side rendered, Backbase Portal Client renders the HTML code based on the model included in the server response. Backbase Portal Client handles interaction, e.g. when the user moves a widget. It sends changes to the model back to the server as XML through the REST API. The flow chart below shows client-side rendering:

Note

The black lines show how Backbase Portal renders a requested page

The red lines show what happens upon user interaction (e.g. drag and drop of widgets)

The green objects list the properties that are necessary to render the object

Backbase Portal Foundation.  Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following actions server-side:

  1. Page

    Backbase Portal Foundation renders the page according to the Page Template referenced by the TemplateName property in the page object.

  2. Include model in response

    Backbase Portal Foundation includes the page, container and widget objects as XML in the <xmp> tag in the response.

Backbase Portal Client.  Backbase Portal Client performs the following actions client-side:

  1. Initialize

    The b$.portal.startup() function in the page template body tag initializes Backbase Portal Client.

  2. Page

    The data-pid attribute is missing or does not match the name of the page object, so Backbase Portal Client renders the children of the page in the HTML element with the id that matches the parameter of the b$.portal.startup() function.

  3. Container

    Backbase Portal Client renders the container according to the Container Client Template referenced by the TemplateName property in the container object. Most layouts contain with multiple areas that include the widgets based on the value of their area property.

  4. Widget

    Backbase Portal Client renders the widget according to the Widget Chrome Template referenced by the widgetChrome property in the widget object.

    For Backbase widgets, Backbase Portal Client includes the Widget Definition referenced in the src property.

  5. Handle interaction

    When the visitor of the portal drags and drops widgets or changes preferences, Backbase Portal Client adjusts the HTML and also updates the XML model and communicates the changes to Backbase Portal Foundation via the REST API.

Top

4.2 Pages

Top

4.2.1 Page Template

Page templates define the structure of master pages. They are JavaServer Pages templates that define how Backbase Portal Foundation renders page objects.

A page template needs to perform the following actions:

  • Load external libraries

  • Load Backbase Portal Client

  • Define a content area for the page children (containers and widgets)

  • Set the DOCTYPE and the encoding

Note that if a template is not XHTML-compliant, an error will be logged by the application server, but Backbase Portal will try to use it anyway.

Client-side Rendering

The following example shows a page template that loads Backbase Portal Client and allows it to render the children of the page client-side. You can find a detailed explanation of the template below the code:

<%@ taglib prefix="c" uri="http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/core" %>
<%@ taglib prefix="sec" uri="http://www.springframework.org/security/tags" %>
<%@ taglib prefix="b" uri="http://www.backbase.com/taglib" %>
<%@ taglib prefix="fn" uri="http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/functions" %>
<%@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=UTF-8" pageEncoding="UTF-8" %>
<%@ page import="com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.util.BidiUtils"%>
<%
    String portalContextRoot = request.getContextPath();
    String direction = BidiUtils.getDirValue(request);
    pageContext.setAttribute("direction", direction);
%>
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">

<c:choose>
    <c:when test="${param.designmode == 'true'}">
        <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" class="bd-designMode-true" dir="${direction}">
    </c:when>
    <c:otherwise>
        <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" class="bd-designMode-null" dir="${direction}">
    </c:otherwise>
</c:choose>

<head>
    <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
    <title><c:out value="${item.propertyDefinitions['title'].value.value}"/></title>

    <%-- Sets meta data tags based on the tags in the page --%>
    <c:if test="${fn:length(item.itemTags)>0}">
        <c:set var="tags" value="" />
        <c:forEach items="${item.itemTags}" var="tag">
            <c:set var="tags" value="${tags} ${tag.name}"/>
        </c:forEach>
        <c:set var="tags" value="${fn:trim(tags)}"/>
        <meta name="robots" content="${tags}"></meta>
        <meta name="keywords" content="${tags}"></meta>
        <meta name="Description" content="${tags}"></meta>
    </c:if>

    <%-- Backbase Portal Client --%>
    <jsp:include page="../../common/portalclient-libs.jsp"/>

    <%-- Aurora styling --%>
    <jsp:include page="../../backbase.com.2012.aurora/common/aurora-libs.jsp"/>
    <%-- Aurora bidirectional styling --%>
    <c:if test="${direction eq 'RTL'}">
        <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"  href="/portalserver/doc-center/manuals/portal/<c:url value="/static/backbase.com.2012.aurora/css/bidi.css"/>"/>
    </c:if>

    <script src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/<%=portalContextRoot%>/static/backbase.com.2012.aurora/containers/containers.js"></script>

    <style type="text/css">
        .bp-area {height:80px; min-width:80px; border:1px solid grey}
    </style>
</head>

<body onload="b$.portal.startup('main')">
<sec:authorize ifNotGranted="role_anonymous"><a
 href="/portalserver/doc-center/manuals/portal/<c:url value="/j_spring_security_logout"/>">logout</a></sec:authorize>
<sec:authentication property="name"/>

<div class="pageContainer">
    <div id="main">
    </div>
</div>

</body>
</html>

Sets the class to designMode-true if the page is displayed within Backbase Portal Manager, or designMode-null if displayed in a browser.

Sets the encoding to UTF-8.

Fills <title> with the content of the page title property.

The following lines fill the <meta> elements with the page tags.

Include Backbase Portal Client.

Include the styling from the Aurora bundle (optional).

This script registers the layouts from the Aurora bundle to Backbase Portal Client. Without this script, Backbase Portal Client cannot render the container templates client-side. If you want server-side rendered containers, you don't need this script here (because the container server template includes it).

This styling is useful for test purposes. It gives the drop areas a minimum width and height and a grey border.

Start Backbase Portal Client with the b$.portal.startup('main') function. The parameter in the function refers to the id attribute of an HTML element. In this case, Backbase Portal Client will render the page in the HTML element with id="main".

Displays a logout link if the user is authenticated, and displays nothing is the user is anonymous.

Displays the user name.

The id attribute is set to main, which corresponds to the parameter in the b$.portal.startup() function. This means that Backbase Portal Client will render the page in this div.

Note that the ${item} variable refers to the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Page object (see Javadoc API). When a user requests a page by opening it in a browser, Backbase Portal replaces ${item} with the actual values of the requested page.

For more information, see Client-side and Server-side Rendering.

Server-side Rendering

For server-side rendering, use the same page template as for client-side rendering and follow these steps:

  1. Replace the <div id="main"></div> section with the following code:

        <div id="main" data-pid="${item.name}" class="bp-page bp-area">
        <b:areaSort src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/${item}" />
        <c:forEach items="${item.children}" var="child">
            <b:include src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/${child}"/>
        </c:forEach>
    </div>

    By setting the data-pid attribute in the <div> tag to the name of the current object, you signal to Backbase Portal Client that the object will be server-side rendered. Within the forEach loop, the b:include tag specifies the children of ${item} that Backbase Portal will render.

    For more information, see Client-side and Server-side Rendering.

  2. Remove the following script and other scripts with a Container Client Template if they are present:

    <script src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/<%=portalContextRoot%>/static/backbase.com.2012.aurora/containers/containers.js"></script>

    These scripts register layouts to Backbase Portal Client. Without them, Backbase Portal Client cannot render the container templates client-side. If you want server-side rendered containers, you don't need these scripts here (because the container server template includes it).

4.2.2 Event Listeners

Pages do not fire events that we cover in this documentation. But by default pages have the following event listeners in their behaviors property:

  • be.perspective.Manager — handles maximization and minimization of widgets

  • be.portalClientExt.PortalManagerPreferencesForm — activates the Settings menu where users can personalize widgets and containers.

These are part of the JavaScript library from the Aurora bundle. All shipped page templates contain this library through the following JSP include in their head tag:

<jsp:include page="../../backbase.com.2012.aurora/common/aurora-libs.jsp"/>

Both event listeners listen to events fired not by the page but by the widgets and containers on the page. This is not default behavior, because event listeners in the behaviors property only attach to the object itself, not its children. The JavaScript library in the Aurora bundle attaches the event listeners to the children of the page.

Currently, the JavaScript API does not allow you to attach event listeners to objects in your own code. Please add your event listeners to the behaviors property of the container or widget directly, see Layout Event Listeners and Widget Event Listeners.

4.3 Containers

Containers form the layout of the widgets on a page. You can render containers client-side or server-side.

Container Server Template

Container server templates define the (server-side rendered) layout within the content area of a page. They are JavaServer Pages templates that define how Backbase Portal Foundation renders container objects. If you use client-side rendering, container server templates are not used (or they are overwritten). The layout can consist of multiple areas, e.g. <table> or <div> elements, that load the widgets and other children of the container.

A container server template should set the DOCTYPE and encoding. Note that if a template is not XHTML-compliant, an error will be logged by the application server, but Backbase Portal will try to use it anyway.

Note

When you use server-side rendering, you still need a container client template for Backbase Portal Client to understand the structure of the page. Backbase Portal Client is needed to handle interaction like dragging and dropping of widgets.

Note

All <script> and <link> elements in the <head> section of a container server template are moved to the head of the page template as part of the server-side rendering process.

For information on how to create a custom layout, see How to Implement a Custom Layout.

Container Client Template

Container client templates define the (client-side rendered) layout within the content area of a page. Backbase Portal Client uses them to render container objects.

If you use server-side rendering for the container, you will need a matching container client template to handle drag and drop and other user interaction.

For information on how to create a custom layout, see How to Implement a Custom Layout.

4.3.1 How to Implement a Custom Layout

    Adjust the example to your wishes with the following guidelines in mind:

    • Set the data-pid attribute of the top container to ${item.name}.

4.3.2 Event Listeners

Layouts fire events for dragging and dropping. You can add event listeners via the behaviors property. Use the dragEnter, drag, dragLeave and dragDrop events. The start drag event is fired by the widget, see Drag and Drop. For more information, see the b$.bdom.events description of JSDoc API.

Follow these steps to implement the example:

  1. Set the behaviors property of the container to doctestLayout for this example to work. For example, add the following lines to the container import file:

    <property name="behaviors">
    <value type="string">doctestLayout</value>
</property>

  2. Create a folder named containers in src/main/webapp/static/doctest. In this folder, create a JavaScript file named behaviorsLayout.js. Copy the JavaScript code below to this file.

  3. Link the JavaScript file to the page template or container template. If your portal renders the containers/layouts server-side, you can use the container template, otherwise use the page template. Add the following tag to the head of the template:

    <script src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/<c:url value="/static/doctest/containers/behaviorsLayout.js"/>" type="text/javascript"></script>

Put the following code in the JavaScript file:

doctestLayout = {
    getDropArea: function(event) {
        var dropArea = -1;
        for (var i=0; i<event.target.htmlAreas.length;i++) {
            var offset = jQuery(event.target.htmlAreas[i]).offset();
            if (event.clientX>=offset.left &&
                event.clientY>=offset.top &&
                event.clientX<=(offset.left+event.target.htmlAreas[i].offsetWidth) &&
                event.clientY<=(offset.top+event.target.htmlAreas[i].offsetHeight)) {
                dropArea = i;
                break;
            }
        }
        return dropArea;
    },
    behaviors: {
        'drag': function(event) {
            for (var i=0; i<event.target.htmlAreas.length;i++) {
                event.target.htmlAreas[i].style.backgroundColor="transparent";
            }
            var dropArea = doctestLayout.getDropArea(event);
            if (dropArea>-1)
                event.target.htmlAreas[dropArea].style.backgroundColor="yellow";
        },
        'dragEnter': function(event) {
            //console.dir("Enter object");
        },
        'dragLeave': function(event) {
            //console.dir("Leave object");
        },
        'dragDrop': function(event) {
            var dropArea = doctestLayout.getDropArea(event);
            if (dropArea>-1)
                event.target.htmlAreas[dropArea].style.backgroundColor="red";
        }
    }
}

A layout usually has more than one area that can hold children. This function calculates the current area based on the X and Y coordinates of the drag event and of the areas.

On mouse over, this function resets the background color of each area to transparent and then sets the background color of the current area to yellow.

Because a layout usually has more than one area, the dragEnter and dragLeave events are not relevant in the current example. The layout fires these events when the dragged object enters or leaves the entire layout.

On mouse down, this function sets the background color of the current area to red.

4.4 Widgets

Widgets are autonomous mini-applications or content units. A widget can be developed stand-alone using all commonly-used or known web technologies, including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, JSP, and PHP, in the same way as any other web application. You can render widgets client-side or server-side.

  • Widget Template — server-side rendering of the widget

  • Widget Chrome Template — the widget chrome (both client-side and server-side)

  • Widget Definition — the widget content (both client-side and server-side)

Add Custom Properties to store preferences of the widget.

Top

4.4.1 Widget Template

A widget template is a JavaServer Pages template that is necessary for server-side rendered widgets, but has limited functionality. If you use client-side rendering, widget templates are not used (or they are overwritten).

The body of the widget template should only contain the b:widget tag, see below. The Widget Chrome Template will render the border and title bar and the Widget Definition contains the widget content.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<%@ taglib prefix="b" uri="http://www.backbase.com/taglib" %>
<%@ taglib prefix="c" uri="http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/core" %>
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
<head>
    <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8"/>
    <title><c:out value="${item.propertyDefinitions['title'].value.value}"/></title>
</head>
<body>
    <b:widget src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/${item}"/>
</body>
</html>

For W3C widgets, replace the b:widget tag with the following:

<b:w3cwidget src='${item}'/>

4.4.2 Widget Chrome Template

The widget chrome template is a Mustache template that defines the following elements:

  • Title bar:

    • Title

    • Buttons (edit, minimize, maximize and close)

  • Border

  • Content area that loads the widget definition

Only the content area is mandatory, so a chromeless widget is possible.

4.4.3 Widget Definition

The widget definition is an XHTML file that defines the widget content. When Backbase Portal receives a request for a widget, it takes the widget definition and adjusts it according to the user settings.

Note that if a layout is not XHTML-compliant, an error will be logged by the application server, but Backbase Portal will try to use it anyway.

The following paragraphs explain the basics of creating a widget.

Most Simple Widget

The most simple widget is as follows:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <p>Hello World</p>
    </body>
</html>

Every widget needs these features:

  • XHTML document type:

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">

  • XHTML namespace:

    <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">

  • UTF-8 character set support:

    <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
Widget with User Preferences

An important benefit of Backbase Portal is that the end-user can personalize the portal. For example, you want to allow the end-user to change the background color of the widget. Create a preference for the selected background color and Backbase Portal Client will store the preference as a property in the widget object on the server. The next time the end-user opens the portal, the same background color will appear, because the preference/property has been stored.

Follow these steps to add a preference to your widget definition:

  1. Add the Widget Namespace

  2. Define the preference using the g:preferences tag, see preferences

  3. Write a JavaScript function to implement the user preference

  4. Call the function upon loading the widget

An API exists that a developer can use to allow the widget to use Backbase Portal functionality. For more information, please refer to the JSDoc API.

The following example shows the steps in more detail:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
        <g:preferences>
            <g:preference name="FontSize" type="range" min="8" max="24" step="2"
             default="12" label="Font size" onchange="applyFontSize(__WIDGET__)" />
        </g:preferences>
        <script type="text/javascript">
            function applyFontSize(oGadget) {
                oGadget.body.style.fontSize =
                    oGadget.getPreference('FontSize') + 'px';
            }
        </script>
    </head>
    <body g:onload="applyFontSize(__WIDGET__)">
        <p>Hello World</p>
    </body>
</html>

Add this namespace to use tags starting with g:.

This code defines a preference named FontSize of the type range. This type produces a drop-down box. The min, max, step and default parameters determine the possible values and the default value.

The onchange parameter refers to a JavaScript function that implements the changes, see next step. Backbase Portal replaces __WIDGET__ with the widget object of data type backbase.com.2012.portalView.backbaseWidget. This object includes any personalizations of the user that sent the request.

For more information, see preference.

This JavaScript function changes the font size of the current widget instance based on the value of the FontSize preference.

This code will call the JavaScript function upon loading the widget. Backbase Portal replaces __WIDGET__ with the widget object of data type backbase.com.2012.portalView.backbaseWidget.

4.4.4 Custom Navigation Widgets

Creating custom navigation widgets does not fundamentally differ from creating generic widgets as explained in Widgets, however navigation widget definitions make use of the <g:model> tag and its children. Backbase Portal ships with pre-defined navigation widgets that one can use as examples. For more information, see Nexus.

Follow these steps to create custom navigation widgets:

  1. Create widget definition

    Create a widget definition as explained in Widget Definition. You can add JavaScript or CSS to the <head> section.

  2. Add <g:model> tag

    Put the <g:model> tag in the body of the widget definition to create the navigation tree. For more information, see model.

  3. Add <g:filter> tag

    The g:model tag has a child g:filter that contains a query to select the root of the navigation tree. For example, you can select the default root as follows:

    <g:filter name="name" operator="eq" value="navroot_mainmenu"/>

    For more information, see filter.

  4. Add <g:template> tag

    The g:model tag has a child g:template that refers to a widget property. This widget property should contain the path to the template that renders the navigation tree. For more information, see template.

  5. Create navigation template (optional)

    You can create a custom template to render the navigation tree using the following Mustache tags:

    • {{Url}} — the link Url property. For more information, see link.

    • {{title}} — the link title property.

    • {{#links}} ... {{/links}} — loops over the links within a portal.

    • {{#children}} ... {{/children}} — loops over the children of a link.

    Save the template in the widget folder: src/main/webapp/static/your_bundle_name/widgets/your_widget_name/navTemplate.

  6. Set the navigation template

    Any widget that will use this widget definition needs to have the property that corresponds to the g:template tag defined in Step 4. This property should contain the path to the navigation Mustache template that renders the navigation tree. Use a custom template or a shipped template (see Nexus). For example:

    <property name="navTemplate">
    <value type="string">$(contextRoot)/static/doctest/widgets/navWidget/navTemplate/template.html</value>
</property>

  7. Implement the widget definition as explained in How to Implement a Custom Widget Definition.

4.4.5 Custom Properties

The Backbase Portal object model offers the possibility to store information about objects in custom properties. For example, you could let users set the background color of a widget by changing the backgroundcolor property from transparent to white.

Follow these steps to add a custom property to a widget:

  1. Add the property to the model

    Add a property to the model in one of the following ways:

    • Backbase Portal Explorer

      Log into Backbase Portal Manager and open Backbase Portal Explorer. Select the widget, click on the Properties tab, and add a property. Give backgroundcolor as Property Name.

    • Import file

      Add the property to a widget import file, for example the widgets.xml or catalog.xml files from Portal Example. Name the property backgroundcolor:

      <widgets>
    <widget>
        <name>Widget_Example</name>
        ...
        <properties>
            <property name="backgroundcolor">
                <value type="string">transparent</value>
            </property>
            ...
        <properties>
        ...
    </widget>
</widgets>

      For more information, see Importer.

    • Widget definition

      Add a g:preference named backgroundcolor to the <head> section of the widget definition, for example:

      <g:preference name="backgroundcolor" default="transparent"/>

      After importing the definition, Backbase Portal creates a property based on the g:preference. For more information, see Widget with User Preferences.

    Note that if you add a property both in the database and in the widget definition, the property values in the database take precedence.

  2. Make the property modifiable from within the user interface (optional)

    You can allow users to modify a property in the Settings panel when they click on the icon in the widget chrome. Make the property modifiable in one of the following ways:

    • Backbase Portal Explorer

      Log into Backbase Portal Manager and open Backbase Portal Explorer. Select the widget, go to the Properties tab, and fill out the viewHint field as described in viewHint. For example, the following string shows the property in a text field accessible by USER roles:

      user,text-input

    • Import file

      Add the viewHint attribute to the property in the widget import file, for example the widgets.xml or catalog.xml files from Portal Example. See viewHint for a list of accepted values. For example:

      <widgets>
    <widget>
        <name>Widget_Example</name>
        ...
        <properties>
            <property name="backgroundcolor" viewHint="user,text-input" label="Background color">
                <value type="string">transparent</value>
            </property>
            ...
        <properties>
        ...
    </widget>
</widgets>

      For more information, see Importer.

    • Add a type attribute to the g:preference in the widget definition. See Type for a list of accepted values. For example, the following g:preference appears as a text area in the Settings panel:

      <g:preference name="backgroundcolor" label="Background color" type="textarea" default="transparent"/>

      After importing the definition, Backbase Portal creates a property based on the g:preference. For more information, see Widget with User Preferences.

    Note that if you add a property both in the database and in the widget definition, the property values in the database take precedence.

4.4.6 Event Listeners

You can add event listeners to a widget with the following methods:

  • The behaviors property

  • The g: events

The method you can use differs per event as explained in the sections with examples below. The examples are widget definitions. To implement one, see How to Implement a Custom Widget Definition. The __WIDGET__ string in the examples is a place holder that Backbase Portal replaces with the widget object of data type backbase.com.2012.portalView.backbaseWidget. This object includes any personalizations of the user that sent the request.

Top

4.4.6.1 Loading

You can only attach an event listener for this event via g:onload. The following example loads the widget content from a property. Add a property named text to the widget for this example to work. For example, add the following lines to the widget import file:

<property name="text" viewHint="none,text-input">
    <value type="string">Hello World</value>
</property>

This is the example widget definition:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
        doctestWidget = {
            setContents: function(oWidget) {
                if(oWidget.getPreference != null){
                    oWidget.body.innerHTML = "<p>" + String(oWidget.getPreference("text")) + "</p>";
                }
                else {
                    oWidget.body.innerHTML = "<p>Error loading contents</p>";
                }
            }
        };
        </script>
    </head>
    <body g:onload="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__)"
    g:onPrefModified="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__)">
    </body>
</html>

4.4.6.2 Perspective Changes

A widget can have the following perspective states:

  • Maximized

  • Widget — this is the default state. Perspective states are not persisted, so the widget always loads in this perspective.

  • Minimized — this state is part of the Aurora bundle.

You can listen to changes in perspective with both methods, but the g: method does not include a listener for the minimized state, since it only exists if you use the JavaScript library from the Aurora bundle (included in all shipped page templates).

Example via g: events

Use the g:onmaximize and g:onrestore events for perspective changes. You can find these events in Widget Namespace. The following example changes the text of the widget body to show the new perspective value.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
        doctestWidget = {
            setContents: function(oWidget, sPerspective) {
                oWidget.body.innerHTML = "<p>" + sPerspective + "</p>";
            }
        };
        </script>
    </head>
    <body g:onload="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__, 'Widget')"
    g:onmaximize="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__, ' Maximized')"
    g:onrestore="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__, ' Widget')">
    </body>
</html>
Example via behaviors property

Set the behaviors property of the widget to doctestWidget for this example to work. For example, add the following lines to the widget import file:

<property name="behaviors">
    <value type="string">doctestWidget</value>
</property>

The event name you have to enter in your behaviors object is PerspectiveModified. You can find these event names in the b$.bdom.events description of JSDoc API. The event.newValue property contains the new perspective, see the list above for the possible values. The following example changes the text of the widget body to show the new perspective value.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
        doctestWidget = {
            setContents: function(oWidget, sPerspective) {
                oWidget.body.innerHTML = "<p>" + sPerspective + "</p>";
            },
            behaviors: {
                'PerspectiveModified': function(event) {
                    doctestWidget.setContents(event.target, event.newValue);
                }
            }
        };
        </script>
    </head>
    <body g:onload="doctestWidget.setContents(__WIDGET__, 'Widget')">
    </body>
</html>

4.4.6.3 Preference Changes

Both methods have an event listener for this event: g:onPrefModified and PrefModified. For more information, see Widget Namespace and the b$.bdom.events description of JSDoc API. However, the PrefModified event is fired on the model of the object, which complicates the use with the behaviors property. Therefore, it is recommended to use g:onPrefModified for this event.

4.4.6.4 Drag and Drop

Use the dragStart event via the behaviors property. The other drag events are fired by the layout, see Layout Event Listeners. For more information, see the b$.bdom.events description of JSDoc API.

Set the behaviors property of the widget to doctestWidget for this example to work. For example, add the following lines to the widget import file:

<property name="behaviors">
    <value type="string">doctestWidget</value>
</property>

The following example changes the text of the widget body to show what keys are pressed during drag:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
        doctestWidget = {
            setContents: function(oWidget, sDragText) {
                oWidget.body.innerHTML = "<p>" + sDragText + "</p>";
            },
            behaviors: {
                'dragStart': function(event) {
                    doctestWidget.setContents(event.target, "Ctrl pressed: " + event.ctrlKey + "<br/>Alt pressed: " + event.altKey + "<br/>Shift pressed: " + event.shiftKey);
                }
            }
        }
        </script>
    </head>
    <body>
    	<p>Please drag this widget</p>
    </body>
</html>

              padding: 20px;
            }

            #aboutBox{
              padding: 20px;
              box-shadow: 2px 2px 10px #444;
              border-radius: 15px;
              background-color: #ECEDCF;
              text-align:center;
            }
        </style>
        <script>
          // example that generates an about box
          // using metadata from a widget's configuration document.
          function makeAboutBox(){
              var storeLink = document.getElementById("storeLink");
              storeLink = storeLink.setAttribute("href", widget.id);

              var icon = document.getElementById("icon");
              icon.setAttribute("alt", widget.shortName);

              var title = document.getElementById("name");
              title.innerHTML = widget.name;

              var version = document.getElementById("version");
              var prodKey = widget.preferences["productKey"];
              version.innerHTML += widget.version + " (" + prodKey + ")";

              var description = document.getElementById("description");
              description.innerHTML = widget.description;

              var author = document.getElementById("author");
              author.innerHTML += widget.author;
          }
        </script>
        <script src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/W3CAPIWrapper.js" />
        <script src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/init.js" />
    </head>
    <body onload="makeAboutBox(); SetIframeDimensions(); attachPreferenceModifiedEventHandler();">
        <div id="aboutBox">
            <h1><a id="storeLink"><img src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/icon.png" id="icon"></a></h1>
            <h1 id="name">Name</h1>
            <p id="version">Version: </p>
            <hr>
            <p id="description">...</p>
            <hr>
            <p id="author">© </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>

    The makeAboutBox() function reads the widget properties and prints out the values. Note that it looks for a non-existing prodKey property. This is a mistake in the specification example and should be changed to apikey.

    Include the W3CAPIWrapper.js library. This library populates the W3C Widget API with Backbase Portal property values.

    Include the init.js library. This library sets the widget size and handles interaction.

    Add the SetIframeDimensions() and attachPreferenceModifiedEventHandler() functions to the <body> onload event. These funtions set the widget size and handle interaction.

  5. Import widget

    Open the importPortal.xml file in the src/main/resources/import folder.

    Add the following content in the <backbase-portal-import> section:

    <widgets>
    <file>W3C/widgets.xml</file>
    <rights-file>backbase.com.2011.spitfire/rights/widget-property-rights.xml
    </rights-file>
</widgets>

  6. Run the project

    Run the project and import the new widget as explained in Test.

    If the import was successful, you should be able to use the W3C widget in Backbase Portal Manager.

Top

4.5 Links

The link item stores pointers to other items or external URLs. Navigation widgets use links to build navigation trees.

Link Types

Links can be of the following types. The technical type is the itemType property.

Table 4.7. Link Types

External Link

Displays a menu header in the navigation tree. Does not refer to a page itself, but can have children that do.

Alias

Refers to a page that already has an associated link.

-

Refers to a page state. The tab layout from the Nexus bundle uses this link type.


Backbase Portal Manager creates a link for every new page and creates a navigation tree as shown in the image below:

Page link

Root Links

Backbase Portal Manager expects the following links of type menuHeader in a portal:

  • navroot_mainmenu: contains links that show up in the navigation tree. By default, this root link has the title Main Navigation.

  • navroot_notinmenu: contains links that do not show up in the navigation tree. The pages that these links refer to are floating pages, for example landing pages for a marketing campaign.

    By default, this root link has the title Not In Navigation.

  • masterpage_root: contains links that of master pages. By default, this root link has the title Master Pages.

Backbase Portal Manager automatically adds the links above to new portals.

The following image shows the root links in Backbase Portal Manager:

Properties

The following table shows what the link types expect as values for the ItemRef and Url properties in the link object:

Link Type

ItemRef

Url

The friendly URL (optional).

Note

Links inherit permissions differently than other items. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

URLs

Backbase Portal supports several URL types for links:

  • Friendly URLs are easy-to-remember optional addresses that the user can enter when creating a page in Backbase Portal Manager. For example:

    /portalserver/about

    Friendly URLs are directly appended to the application context (default portalserver). This has the implication that friendly URLs need to be unique across portals within a Backbase Portal implementation. Two pages may not have the same friendly URL even if they are part of different portals.

    The Url property of the link stores the friendly URL. The finalUrl element of the link also contains the friendly URL. If the friendly URL is not set, finalUrl contains the hierarchical URL.

    Note

    Friendly URLs may not contain any of the following reserved words: portals, pages, containers, widgets, includes, links, catalog, templates, and portalserver.

    Additionally, friendly URLs can only contain characters deemed "safe" in RFC 1738. The slash ("/") and dot (".") are valid.

  • Hierarchical URLs are automatically generated readable addresses that reflect the link hierarchy. They follow this syntax:

    /applicationcontext/portal/[parent_link]/[parent_link]/link_section_name

    The hierarchical URL includes all parent links, except Root Links.

    The generatedUrl property stores the entire hierarchical URL and the sectionName property stores the link_section_name part of the URL. The finalUrl element of the link also contains the hierarchical URL, except if the friendly URL is set.

    Backbase Portal Manager derives the link_section_name from the title or label the user enters when creating the page, but the user can also change it. For example, when you enter About Us as Menu Label, Backbase Portal Manager will generate about-us as link_section_name. The About Us link has a parent Company, so the hierarchical URL is as follows:

    /portalserver/myportal/company/about-us

    Because hierarchical URLs include the parent links, the link_section_name only needs to be unique within the context of the parent link. Unlike friendly URLs that need to be unique across all portals within the server.

Note

Further reading: Configuring URL Rewriting

5.3. Third-party Tools

Backbase Portal includes Backbase Portal Manager and Backbase Portal Explorer that provide a graphical user interface to communicate with Backbase Portal Foundation. This chapter is aimed at developers and explains how to communicate with Backbase Portal Foundation with low-level tools.

The importer tool for developers can quickly import portal objects. For more information on how to work with the importer, see Importer.

It is possible to run queries about objects by adding URL modifiers. For more information, see URL Modifiers

Using third-party tools, it is possible to directly communicate with the REST interface. For more information, see Third-party Tools.

5.1 Importer

The importer is a setup and development tool to communicate with Backbase Portal Foundation. It allows you to import Backbase Portal objects to the data store. To use the importer, follow these steps:

  1. Create Backbase Portal objects to import

    Create XML files with the objects you want to import. You can import Backbase Portal objects to the server scope (available for multiple portals) and to the portal scope (available for a particular portal).

    You can import the following Backbase Portal objects to the server scope:

    • UsersUsers

    • Groups

    • Templates

    • Containers

    • Widgets

    • Portals

    In the portal scope, you can import the following Backbase Portal objects:

    • Pages

    • Containers

    • Widgets

    • Catalog

    The format of the XML files (including examples) is described in the XSD Reference.

    Save the XML files to the src/main/resources/import folder in your portal project or the WEB-INF/classes/import folder in the unpacked WAR file.

  2. Create import file

    The import file lists the objects you want to import.

    Open the file src/main/resources/import/importPortal.xml in your portal project or WEB-INF/classes/import/importPortal.xml in the unpacked WAR file. If the file does not exist, please create it.

    Adjust the file to include the object files created in the previous step, see Import File.

    Important

    Do not remove the following lines that import the default templates:

    <templates>
    <file>../defaultImportData/templates.xml</file>
</templates>

    Backbase Portal falls back to these objects as defaults.

    Important

    The order of the objects matters: objects cannot refer to other objects that have not yet been created. Therefore, place templates before pages, containers and widgets (that use the templates). Check the example in Import File for the correct order of objects.

  3. Restart the portal

    Open a command shell and go to the project folder. Execute the following commands: 

    mvn -P with-dashboard clean install
mvn jetty:run-war

    If Backbase Portal is deployed as a WAR file, restart the application server.

  4. Start the import

    Open http://host:port/applicationcontext/import in a browser. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 5.1. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    Log in with the administrator user name admin and password admin. The following screen opens:

    Check the objects you want to import and click Import. If the import was successful, no message is shown.

    The check box Delete before import is visible when a portal is included in the import file. Check this box to delete the existing portal and recreate it according to the import file.

Top

5.1.1 Import File

The import file lists the objects you want to import. For each object, it refers to the XML file that describes the object.

Important

Do not remove the following lines that import the default templates:

<templates>
    <file>../defaultImportData/templates.xml</file>
</templates>

Backbase Portal falls back to these objects as defaults.

Important

The order of the objects matters: objects cannot refer to other objects that have not yet been created. Therefore, place templates before pages, containers and widgets (that use the templates). Check the example below for the correct order of objects.

The tags in the import file are described in the following topics:

  • backbase-portal-import — the root element

  • portal-import — the portal element

  • importFileInfo — the data type of other elements

This is an example of an import file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes" ?>
<!-- Copyright (c) 2011 Backbase B.V. -->
<backbase-portal-import>
    <!-- ** USER AND GROUPS ** -->
    <!-- ** TEMPLATES ** -->
    <!--  Default -->
    <templates>
        <file>../defaultImportData/templates.xml</file>
    </templates>
    <!-- BundleName -->
    <templates>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/template-widgets.xml</file>
        <rights-file>mycompany.com.bundlename/rights/defaultRights.xml</rights-file>
    </templates>
    <templates>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/template-containers.xml</file>
        <rights-file>mycompany.com.bundlename/rights/defaultRights.xml</rights-file>
    </templates>
    <templates>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/template-pages.xml</file>
        <rights-file>mycompany.com.bundlename/rights/defaultRights.xml</rights-file>
    </templates>
    <!-- ** SERVER CATALOG CONTAINERS ** -->
    <!-- BundleName -->
    <containers>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/catalog-containers.xml</file>
    </containers>
    <!-- ** SERVER CATALOG WIDGETS ** -->
    <!-- BundleName -->
    <widgets>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/catalog-widgets.xml</file>
    </widgets>
    <!-- ** PORTALS ** -->
    <!-- BundleName -->
    <portal-import>
        <name>myportal</name>
        <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/instance-portal.xml</file>
        <rights-file>mycompany.com.bundlename/rights/defaultRights.xml</rights-file>
        <containers>
            <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/instance-containers.xml</file>
        </containers>
        <widgets>
            <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/instance-widgets.xml</file>
        </widgets>
        <links>
            <file>mycompany.com.bundlename/instance-links.xml</file>
        </links>
    </portal-import>
</backbase-portal-import>

Top

5.2 URL Modifiers

You can format HTTP responses with URL modifiers and parameters. To add a modifier to a URL, type a question mark character (?) followed by the modifier statement. Separate multiple statements with an ampersand (&) sign:

http://host:port/portalserver/path_to_object?modifier1=value1&modifier2=value2

You can see what URL modifiers are available for every object in URL Modifiers.

Top

5.2.1 Filtering Modifiers

You can filter HTTP responses by field or by property. Use the following syntax to filter on a field:

?f=field_name(operator)value

Use the following syntax to filter on a property:

?f=property.property_name(operator)value

These are the available operators:

Table 5.5. Filter Operators

Operator

Description

lt

Less than

gt

Greater than

eq

Equal to

not

Not equal to. It cannot be used when filtering tags.

like

Returns fields or properties containing the specified string. For example, the following filter returns pages whose itemName contains the string 'back': 

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/portalname/pages?f=property.itemName(like)back

eq

Equal to


The following two requests demonstrate the difference between field and property filtering. This example returns portals whose DefaultLandingPage property is 'index': 

http://host:port/portalserver/portals?f=property.DefaultLandingPage(eq)index

This example returns page templates (templates for which the field type is page):

http://host:port/portalserver/templates?f=type(eq)page

The filtering modifier has a number of limitations. In particular:

  • Filtering by the publishState field is not supported.

  • Filtering catalogs and templates by type only accepts an object type (i.e. portal, page, container, or widget) as argument, and returns no results for all other values. Instead, filtering other objects accepts any string.

  • It is not possible to filter by more than one property, but it is possible to filter by any number of fields.

  • Filtering groups by role only accepts equal to (eq) as operator and only accepts complete role names as (i.e. admin, manager, user, and anonymous).

Top

5.2.2 Paging Modifiers

Use the paging modifiers to distribute the responses on multiple pages:

Table 5.6. Paging Modifiers

Modifier

Description

ps

Page size: the number of results in the response. On the /auditevents URI, ?ps=-1 returns all results.

of

Page number: the first result number (offset) in the response.


For example, the following request returns the first ten templates whose name contains campaign. i.e. the first page with ten items:

http://host:port/portalserver/templates?f=name(like)campaign&ps=10

This example returns the third page with ten templates whose name contains campaign:

http://host:port/portalserver/templates?f=name(like)campaign&of=20&ps=10

Page size and offset can be used independently of each other. If no page size or offset are specified, their respective values fall back onto a default specified in the configuration, see Controller Properties.

Top

5.2.3 Sorting Modifiers

You can sort query results by field with the s URL modifier.

Note

Sorting by property is not supported.

The s modifier only accepts two paramenters: asc and dsc, meaning ascending and descending order respectively. The usage syntax is as follows: 

s=field_name(asc|dsc)

The following line extends the example used for the ps and of modifiers with a sorting modifier:

http://host:port/portalserver/templates?f=name(like)Weat&f=name(like)Wea&of=20&ps=10&s=name(asc)

Note

Sorting by the publishState field is not supported.

Top

5.2.4 Processing Children

The pc and depth parameters specify how item children are processed.

The pc (process children) parameter accepts boolean values and is applicable to GET requests on individual items. If set to true, the results will include the object children. If the parameter is omitted, the default value is true.

The following request returns the index page without its children:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/myportal/pages/index?pc=false

The depth modifier specifies the number of children levels to be displayed. It applies to GET requests on the /pages, /containers, /templates, /widgets, and /links URIs. The level numbering is one-based, i.e. the root level is number one.

To return all pages in a portal up to two levels below the root, set depth to three: 

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/myportal/pages?depth=3

Additionally, the depth parameter specifies the number of link levels to be displayed in GET calls on single links. For example, the following request will return the root link and its immediate children:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/myportal/links/mylink?depth=2

If depth is omitted, the default values are used: all children are displayed for all items, but no children are displayed for pages to avoid lengthy responses.

One can override the default values in the backbase.properties file as explained in Controller Properties.

Set depth to 0 to retrieve all children:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/myportal/pages?depth=0

Top

5.2.5 Filtering by Tag

Some objects support tags, i.e. metadata and keywords about the object in question. In particular, Pages, Containers, Widgets and Templates can have tag elements.

Filtering objects by tag happens at the object type URI, e.g. /portals/portal_name/pages and requires a tag.name parameter as shown in the syntax below: 

../portals/portal_name/item_name?f=tag.name(operator)value

The following request, for example, returns pages with a tag containing the 'custom' substring:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/portal_name/pages?f=tag.name(like)custom

Note

It is not possible to sort results by tag.

To find out what tags you can use, retrieve the tag list for the entire portal as follows:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/portal_name/tags

For more information, see tags.

Top

5.2.6 Deleting Tags

The portals/[portal_name]/tags/[tag_name] URI supports the type URL modifier. type uniquely applies to DELETE calls on tags and specifies the tagType of a specified tag.

For example, a GET call on the http://localhost:8080/portalserver/portals/example/tags.xml URI returns the following XML:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<tags totalSize="3">
    <tag type="small">shipment</tag>
    <tag type="medium">shipment</tag>
    <tag type="large">shipment</tag>
</tags>

As you can see, there are three tags of the same name, but different type. The following DELETE call only deletes the shipment tag of type="small", but not the two tags of different type:

http://localhost:8080/portalserver/portals/example/tags/shipment?type=small

Top

5.2.7 Logical Operators

It is possible to combine filtering statements with logical operators. The & symbol is the logical AND and concatenates statements. The %7 symbol (stands for |) is the logical OR. It cannot link statements, but only values.

This example shows how to use the & symbol. This request returns templates that have 'Thomas' or 'Tom' in their name. The result list shows 10 results per page, starting from result number 20, sorted ascending by name:

http://host:port/portalserver/portals/<replaceable>myportal</replaceable>/pages?f=name(like)Thomas&f=type(eq)page&of=20&ps=10&s=name(asc)

This example shows how to use the %7 symbol on values. This request returns portals with default landing page named index or named page1:

host:port/portalserver/portals?f=property.DefaultLandingPage(eq)index%7page1

The following request is not valid, because you cannot use the %7 symbol between statements, only between values:

host:port/portalserver/portals?f=property.DefaultLandingPage(eq)index%7f=name(eq)myportal

Top

5.2.8 Bi-Directional Support

Backbase Portal displays text in left-to-right direction by default. To display text in right-to-left direction in widgets, layouts, and templates provided by Backbase, append the lang=xx modifier to the item URL, where xx is the ISO 639-1 Two Digit Language Code of a right-to-left language. These are the supported right-to-left languages:

Table 5.7. Right-to-left Languages

Language

ISO 639-1 Code

Arabic

ar

Hebrew

iw, he

Divehi (Dhivehi, Maldivian)

dv

Hausa

ha

Farsi

fa

Pashto

ps

Urdu

ur

Yiddish

yi, ji


To display text in the default, left-to-right direction again, append the lang modifier with any value other than those reported in the table above.

For example, the following URL will display the text on the page and all its children in right-to-left direction:

http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portalname/pagename?lang=he

Changing the value of the lang modifier diplays text in the other direction:

http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portalname/pagename?lang=any-value-at-all

The Java class responsible for language direction display is com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.util.BidiUtils. Import it in the template file headers to add bi-directional support:

<%@ page import="com.backbase.portal.foundation.presentation.util.BidiUtils"%>

Add the following lines to read the value of the lang modifier:

<%
   String portalContextRoot = request.getContextPath();
   String direction = BidiUtils.getDirValue(request);
   pageContext.setAttribute("direction", direction);
%>

Pass the chosen direction as an attribute to the relevant tag, for example:

<html class="your_classes" dir="${direction}">

You can find examples of layouts offering bi-directional support in the target/your_project/WEB-INF/backbase.com.2012.sabre/pages folder.

Top

5.2.9 Filtering Audit Events

If Audit Trails is enabled, a GET call on the /auditevents URI returns a list of REST calls on the server. For more information, see Architecture and AuditEvents.

The following modifiers uniquely apply to audit events:

Table 5.8. Audit Events Modifiers

Modifier

Description

context

The name of the portal on the server. For example:

/auditevents?context=myTestPortal

user

The name of the user or users who made the REST calls. The list members are separated by a logical OR, i.e. ||. For example:

/auditevents?user=myUserName||someOtherUserName

item

The name of the item on which REST calls have been made.

/auditevents?item=Border_Layout

itemtype

A list of item types on which REST calls have been made. These are the accepted values:

  • PORTAL

  • PAGE

  • CONTAINER

  • WIDGET

  • CATALOG

  • TEMPLATE

  • LINK

Multiple values must be comma-separated.

This example returns all records of calls on PAGE and CONTAINER items:

/auditevents?itemtype=PAGE,CONTAINER

itemTitle

The Title of the item on which REST calls have been made. Note that the value is case-insensitive.

This example returns all records of calls on the portal named PortalTEST1:

/auditevents?itemTitle=portaltest1

from

The starting date of the query, written in yyyymmdd format. For example:

/auditevents?from=20120630

to

The ending date of the query, written in yyyymmdd format. For example:

/auditevents?to=20123112

action

The type of operation. Expected values are:

  • CREATE

  • UPDATE

  • DELETE

Multiple values must be comma-separated.

This example returns all records of CREATE and UPDATE calls:

/auditevents?action=CREATE,UPDATE

dates

Whether <auditDates> are displayed. If set to true or omitted, <auditDates> are displayed. Otherwise, they are hidden.

This example hides <auditDates>:

/auditevents?dates=false

The ps and of paging modifiers discussed above apply to audit events as well; only on the /auditevents URI, ?ps=-1 returns all results.

The Audit Trail app provides a graphical interface to the filtering possibilities discussed above.

5.3 Third-party Tools

Several third-party REST clients are available, for instance:

  • WizTools RESTClient, a fully-featured REST client. Documentation and tutorials are available on the project home page.

  • Several Mozilla Firefox plug-ins, among which the Firefox RESTClient plugin. This is a complete REST client with a clean and intuitive user interface that compensates for the lack of documentation.

  • cURL, a powerful command-line tool that supports multiple protocols including HTTP. Documentation is available here.

Working with a REST client

Most graphical REST clients have a similar look and feel and can be learned in a matter of minutes. The following section shows how to access the REST API with the WizTools RESTClient, mentioned above, but should be of help for any REST client.

  1. Install the WizTools RESTClient

    The WizTools RESTClient is a Java program contained in a .jar file. Download it and run it on a Java Virtual Machine.

  2. Set up the REST client

    Start WizTools RESTClient and follow the steps below:

    1. Open the Auth tab and set the Authorization Type to Basic. Enter user name and password (defaults are admin and admin, respectively) in the relevant fields as shown below:

      Note that unauthenticated HTTP requests return a 403 HTTP status code.

    2. Open then the Body tab, click on the Edit Content-type & Charset button and, in the pop-up, make sure Content-type is set to text/xml and Charset is set to UTF-8:

    3. In the URL: bar, enter the portal URI on the host running Backbase Portal, for example http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals:

  3. Create a new portal

    Open the Method tab and select the POST HTTP method. Then switch to the Body tab, copy the following XML portal declaration and paste it into the Body text area:

    <portal>
    <name>testPortal</name>
</portal>

    Click on the GO button next to the URL bar to sent the POST request. You should receive a 201 HTTP status code and the XML definition of the testPortal portal in response in the HTTP Response panel as shown in the picture below:

    Note that the XML definition you received lists more properties than we specified in the POST call. This is because Backbase Portal fills out the structure of new items with default properties. For more information, see portal.

  4. Create a new page

    1. Enter the pages URL (e.g. http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals/testPortal/pages) in the URL field:

    2. Switch to the Body tab, copy the following XML page declaration and paste it into the Body text area:

      <page>
    <name>testPage1</name>
</page>

      For more information, see Pages.

      Even though you just created a portal with a page, pointing a browser to the portal URL (e.g. http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals/testPortal) will return an error because no DefaultLandingPage is set.

  5. Set default landing page

    1. Enter the testPortal URL in the URL bar, for instance http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals/testPortal:

    2. Go to the Method tab and select the PUT method, then open the Body tab, enter the following text and click on the GO button:

      <portal>
    <name>testPortal</name>
    <properties>
        <property name="DefaultLandingPage">
            <value type="string">testPage1</value>
        </property>
    </properties>
</portal>

      If the call succeeds, you should receive a 204 HTTP status code and no XML in response. You can inspect the portal XML structure by calling a GET method on the http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals/testPortal.xml URL (note the .xml suffix):

  6. Open the portal in your browser

    If you now open the testPortal URL in a browser (e.g. http://localhost:7777/portalserver/portals/testPortal), you should see the testPage1 page.

Concluding, graphical REST clients allow you to call HTTP methods on Backbase Portal object URIs and display the server responses. Different objects may support different methods: for an overview, consult the REST API.

6.1 Backbase Portal Properties

The backbase.properties file overrides the default settings for the different modules. You can set the file location in the backbase/config environment entry. On Microsoft Windows, use forward slashes / instead of backslashes \. For more information, see How to Set an Environment Entry.
