6.2 Publishing

One can install Backbase Portal in editorial or staging/live environments, each requiring different Orchestrator configurations. For an overview of publishing concepts, see Publishing.

To configure publishing, create a configuration file and enter its location in the orchestrator.configuration.location setting in the backbase.properties file, see Orchestrator Settings.

Top

6.2.1 Basic Configuration

The Orchestrator configuration file is composed of these sections:

  • A section with general settings for Orchestrator.

  • A <host> element with settings for Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • A <cmsHost> element with settings for the CMIS implementation, such as Content Services or Content Management System.

The Orchestrator on the editorial environment has additional settings, see Editorial Environment Configuration.

This is the basic configuration file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<configuration>
    <name>orchestrator_name</name>
    <description>description</description>
    <editorial>[true|false]</editorial>
    <fileStoreLocation>path/to/filestore</fileStoreLocation>
    <bundleStreamBufferSize>buffer_size</bundleStreamBufferSize>
    <username>user_name</username>
    <password>password</password>
    <approvalGroups>
        <approvalGroup>admin</approvalGroup>
    </approvalGroups>
    <publishGroups>
        <publishGroup>admin</publishGroup>
        <publishGroup>manager</publishGroup>
        <publishGroup>master page designer</publishGroup>
    </publishGroups>

    <hosts>
        <host>
            <name>host_name</name>
            <hostType>PORTAL_SERVER</hostType>
            <address>host</address>
            <port>port</port>
            <contextPath>applicationcontext</contextPath>
            <user>user_name</user>
            <password>password</password>
        </host>
    </hosts>

    <cmsHost>
       <name>cms_hostname</name>
        <hostType>CONTENT_SERVICES</hostType>
        <address>host</address>
        <port>port</port>
        <contextPath>cmis_context/atom</contextPath>
        <user>user_name</user>
        <password>password</password>
        <repositoryId>repository_name</repositoryId>
        <lockStrategy>strategy</lockStrategy>
    </cmsHost>

</configuration>

A user-defined name for the current instance of Orchestrator.

<editorial> must be set to true if the current host is the editorial environment, and to false for the staging and live environments. There can only be one editorial environment in a publishing chain.

The path to the folder you created when installing Orchestrator. For more information, see Install Orchestrator.

A buffer for content streams, measured in bytes. The default value is 1024.

The Orchestrator user name. It must be the same as the one specified in the proxy properties file you created in Install Orchestrator.

The Orchestrator password. It must be the same as the one specified in the proxy properties file you created in Install Orchestrator.

A list of groups in Backbase Portal Foundation with approver role, i.e. who can approve publishing requests.

A list of Backbase Portal Foundation groups with publisher role in Orchestrator. Users in these groups can submit publishing requests.

It is recommended to give publisher role to the master page designer group as shown in the example.

Describes the host on which Backbase Portal is running. It can only have one <host> element.

Within the <hosts> section, <hostType> is always set to PORTAL_SERVER.

The name or IP address of the host. Entering localhost causes the Publishing App to malfunction. Use the hostname or IP address instead.

The Backbase Portal Foundation application context. This is usually the name of the Backbase Portal Foundation WAR file deployed on the application server, e.g. portalserver. For more information, see Application Servers.

The user name and password of a user member of a group with SYS2SYS role; a user named sys2sys with password sys2sys is available after installing Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Authentication and Authorization.

Specify the URL and other settings regarding Content Services. Instead of Content Services, you can specify any Atom-enabled CMIS implementation.

Within the <cmsHost> section, <hostType> is always set to CONTENT_SERVICES.

The name or IP address of the host. Entering localhost causes the Publishing App to malfunction. Use the hostname or IP address instead.

The application context of Content Services. The default is contentservices. This value usually reflects the name of the Content Services WAR file.

The name of the CMIS repository storing content used by Backbase Portal. If using Content Services, this is usually contentRepository.

The locking strategy for a document that is committed for publishing. The possible values are:

  • nooplocking — no strategy is adopted and one can still modify content earmarked for publishing.

  • checkoutlocking — makes use of CMIS Versioning Services. It calls a checkOut service to lock a document, and a cancelCheckOut to unlock it.

6.2.2 Editorial Environment Configuration

Orchestrators in editorial environments need additional configuration. Add the <targetOrchestrators> and <publishChains> tags to the <configuration> root element as explained below:

  • <targetOrchestrators>

    The <targetOrchestrators> element lists all the Orchestrators on the network. The following example shows the contents of the <targetOrchestrators> element:

    <targetOrchestrators>
    <host>
        <name>OrchestratorStaging</name>
        <hostType>ORCHESTRATOR</hostType>
        <address>host</address>
        <port>port</port>
        <contextPath>Orchestrator-staging</contextPath>
        <user>admin</user>
        <password>admin</password>
    </host>
    <host>
        <name>OrchestratorLive</name>
        <hostType>ORCHESTRATOR</hostType>
        <address>host</address>
        <port>port</port>
        <contextPath>Orchestrator-live</contextPath>
        <user>user_name</user>
        <password>password</password>
    </host>
</targetOrchestrators>

    Contains one <host> element for every non-editorial host environment present in the network. Enter this as a child of the <config> root element.

    Describes a staging Orchestrator.

    Within the <targetOrchestrators> section, <hostType> is always set to ORCHESTRATOR.

    The name or IP address of the host. Entering localhost causes the Publishing App to malfunction. Use the hostname or IP address instead.

    The application context of the remote Orchestrator.

    Describes a live Orchestrator.

  • <publishChains>

    The <publishChains> element lists the steps in the publishing chain. Add a <publishChainElement> element to <publishChains> for each Orchestrator in the network, and specify whether each step requires approval as shown in the example below:

    <publishChains>
    <publishChain>
        <publishChainName>chain_name</publishChainName>
        <publishChainElements>
            <publishChainElement>
                <targetOrchestrator>OrchestratorStaging</targetOrchestrator>
                <requiresApproval>[true|false]</requiresApproval>
                <publishChainElements>
                    <publishChainElement>
                        <targetOrchestrator>OrchestratorLive</targetOrchestrator>
                    </publishChainElement>
                </publishChainElements>
            </publishChainElement>
        </publishChainElements>
    </publishChain>
</publishChains>

    Lists the available publishing chains. Enter this as a child of the <config> root element.

    The name of the current publishing chain.

    The first step in the publishing chain.

    Whether the step in the publishing chain requires approval. If <requiresApproval> is omitted, the step does not require approval.

    The following step in the publishing chain. Note that successive <publishChainElements> are nested into each other.

Top

6.2.3 Publishing Within an Environment

Publishing within an environment is an optional feature that allows to publish across portals, rather than environments. For more information, see Publishing.

Follow these steps to configure the portals in a publishing chain:

  1. Add target Orchestrator

    Add the local Orchestrator as a target:

    <targetOrchestrators>
    <host>
        <name>OrchestratorEditorial</name>
        <hostType>ORCHESTRATOR</hostType>
        <address>host</address>
        <port>port</port>
        <contextPath>OrchestratorEditorial</contextPath>
        <user>admin</user>
        <password>admin</password>
    </host>
</targetOrchestrators>

    A user-defined name for the current instance of Orchestrator. It must match the <name> tag at the top of the file.

    Within the <targetOrchestrators> section, <hostType> is always set to ORCHESTRATOR.

    The name or IP address of the host. Entering localhost causes the Publishing App to malfunction. Use the hostname or IP address instead.

    The application context of the local Orchestrator.

  2. Define publishing chain

    Define the publishing chain by adding a <portalMappings> element as child of a <publishChainElement>:

    <publishChain>
    <publishChainName>Self - Direct</publishChainName>
    <publishChainElements>
        <publishChainElement>
            <targetOrchestrator>orchestrator_name</targetOrchestrator>
            <requiresApproval>[true|false]</requiresApproval>
            <portalMappings>
                <portalMapping>
                    <sourcePortal>portal_A</sourcePortal>
                    <targetPortal>portal_B</targetPortal>
                </portalMapping>
            </portalMappings>
        </publishChainElement>
    </publishChainElements>
</publishChain>

    A <portalMappings> element may contain any number of <portalMapping> tags, each mapping a source to a target portal.

    For example, the following chain publishes pages across three portals on the same environment, named myportal, myportal_staging, and myportal_live, respectively:

    <publishChain>
    <publishChainName>WithinEnvironments - Approval on Package</publishChainName>
    <publishChainElements>
        <publishChainElement>
            <targetOrchestrator>editorialOrchestrator</targetOrchestrator>
            <requiresApproval>false</requiresApproval>
            <portalMappings>
                <portalMapping>
                    <sourcePortal>myportal</sourcePortal>
                    <targetPortal>myportal_staging</targetPortal>
                </portalMapping>
            </portalMappings>
            <publishChainElements>
                <publishChainElement>
                    <targetOrchestrator>editorialOrchestrator</targetOrchestrator>
                    <requiresApproval>false</requiresApproval>
                    <portalMappings>
                        <portalMapping>
                            <sourcePortal>myportal</sourcePortal>
                            <targetPortal>myportal_live</targetPortal>
                        </portalMapping>
                    </portalMappings>
                </publishChainElement>
            </publishChainElements>
        </publishChainElement>
    </publishChainElements>
</publishChain>

    The name of the current publishing chain.

    Describes the first publishing step.

    The target Orchestrator. Set a target Orchestrator at each step of the chain, even if only one environment is involved.

    Whether approval should happen on the page (true) or package (false) level. If <requiresApproval> is omitted, approval happens at a package level.

    Maps the portals in the first publishing step.

    Step 1: pages are published from the editorial to the staging portal.

    Maps the portals in the second publishing step.

    Step 2: pages are published from editorial to live.

Top

6.3 Device Recognition

Backbase Portal can automatically recognize different client devices and use a different JSP file for rendering. For example, a company might want a portal to render differently on an Apple iPhone running Apple Safari, a tablet running a WebKit browser, or a desktop PC. Backbase Portal matches the device recognition configuration against the User-Agent string in the HTTP request header.

The device recognition configuration is only one of the methods to select a JSP file for rendering. For more information, see JSP File Selection.

To configure device recognition, create a configuration file and enter its location in the foundation.device.config.location setting in the backbase.properties file. The configuration file overwrites the default settings. For more information, see Backbase Portal Foundation Settings.

This is an example of the configuration file:

<config>
    <device-config>
        <device type="iPhone" fallbackTypes="mobile Web">
            <match>
                <match text="iphone">
                    <match text="AppleWebKit" />
                </match>
                <match text="ipod">
                    <match text="AppleWebKit" />
                </match>
            </match>
        </device>
        <device>
            ...
        </device>
        ...
    <device-config>
</config>

This device will match with User-Agent strings containing "iphone" and "AppleWebKit", or "ipod" and "AppleWebKit".

Nested <match> tags evaluate their respective values with an AND operator, while sibling <match> tags evaluate the values with an OR operator.

Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the template iPhone property. If this property does not exist, Backbase Portal Foundation will try to find a template property that matches an entry in fallbackTypes.

You can define multiple devices.

Available Attributes

The following table lists the available attributes of the <device> element:

Table 6.8. Device Attributes

Attribute

Data Type

Mandatory

Description

type

string

-

Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in the corresponding template property. See the explanation in the beginning of this topic.

fallbackTypes

List of string

-

If the template has no property corresponding to the type, Backbase Portal Foundation will try to find a template property that matches an entry in fallbackTypes. If a fallback type matches, Backbase Portal Foundation will render the object with the JSP file referenced in that template property.

7 Backbase Portal Manager

7.1. Backbase Portal Explorer
7.2. Publishing Pages
7.3. Device-specific Previewing
7.4. Special Pages
7.5. Audit Trails
7.6. Configuration
7.7. Global Constants

7.1 Backbase Portal Explorer

You can intuitively manage portals and their structure in Backbase Portal Explorer graphical interface. Backbase Portal Explorer ships with Backbase Portal Manager and provides an alternative to XML declarations to create and modify portals. Here you can find a summary of the features of Backbase Portal Explorer.

You can open Backbase Portal Explorer as follows:

  1. Open the following URL: http://host:port/applicationcontext/portals/dashboard. The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 7.1. Backbase Portal Foundation URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Backbase Portal Foundation.

    port

    Jetty: 7777

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    When running the portal project, it uses an (embedded) Jetty server. You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    portalserver

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


  2. Click Explorer.

The following sections describe the main concepts and features of Backbase Portal Explorer:

Tree Menu Navigation

Backbase Portal Explorer uses a tree menu to navigate the objects in Backbase Portal. The top level contains the portals, server catalog and templates. Open a portal to navigate to the portal catalog, templates, pages, and links. Click on the plus icon in the tree menu to create portals, pages, containers, widgets, templates, and links. After selecting an existing object, you can inspect it and modify it.

Drag-and-drop

Objects can be moved, copied or extended by dragging their icons around the tree menu. Holding one of the following keys down while dragging, changes the behavior:

  • Shift — move

    This is the default action. The object is moved to the new location. This action changes the parentItemName and/or contextItemName of the object.

    For example, move a widget by dragging it to a different container with the Shift key down.

  • Ctrl — copy

    The object is copied to the new location. This action changes the parentItemName and/or contextItemName of the new object.

    For example, copy a container with its children by dragging it to a different page with the Ctrl key down.

  • Alt — extend

    A new object is created on the new location that extends the original object. This action changes the extendedItemName, the parentItemName and/or contextItemName of the object.

    For example, extend an abstract widget by dragging it from a catalog into a container with the Alt key down.

Manipulating Object Properties

Selecting an object in the menu tree displays its details on the screen. From here you can change its properties. For more information, see the XSD Reference.

The Properties tab shows which properties are inherited with a blue color:

Rights and Permissions

You can set roles and rights for every object and object property from within Backbase Portal Explorer. For more information on rights and permissions, see Authentication and Authorization.

Inheritance Relationships

The Backbase Portal Object Model makes extensive use of inheritance. For example, objects within a catalog element are abstract and can be extended to instantiate portal objects. Instantiated portal objects may also inherit from each other. Selecting an object in the menu tree displays its inheritance relationships.

Top

7.2 Publishing Pages

Backbase Portal Manager manages the publishing process: editors can request approval for publishing from the portal dashboard, while approvers can grant or reject approvals from the PUBLISHING dashboard.

  1. Mark each individual page for publishing by clicking on the icon under the MAIN NAVIGATION menu. A icon shows up next to the selected pages to signal that they are locked.

  2. Once all pages are selected, click on the button. This will open the CREATE PACKAGE dialog.

  3. In the CREATE PACKAGE dialog you can see an overview of the pages marked for publishing, specify the desired publishing chain, and add an optional Publication Name and Comment.

    Backbase Portal Manager confirms whether the publishing request was successful.

  4. In the PUBLISHING dashboard, a new entry is added in the Approval menu. An approver can highlight the entry and approve or reject it:

    • If you chose a publishing chain with Approval on pages, click on either of the icons to approve or reject each individual item, or click on either of the icons to approve or reject the whole package.

    • If you chose a publishing chain with Approval on packages, click on either of the icons to approve or reject the whole package.

    Note that Backbase Portal employs the four-eye principle: the editor and the approver must be different individuals, so one cannot approve his own requests.

The Publishing menu in the PUBLISHING dashboard contains a list of all publishing messages. Click on each message for more details.

Top

7.3 Device-specific Previewing

Backbase Portal Manager supports previewing pages in the portal as it would look on a certain device, e.g. a phone or tablet. Follow these steps to enable this functionality:

  1. Create a new portal or edit an existing portal.

  2. Select or in the Optimized for field. These settings turn on device-specific previewing by default.

    If you select another device (Mixed usage or Desktop usage), you can turn on device-specific previewing manually.

  3. Select a brand and model in the drop-down menu and click Save.

  4. When editing a page in the Pages dashlet, Backbase Portal Manager will mimic the mobile device you selected.

  5. Via the bar in the top of the screen (in the Pages dashlet), you can access other brands and models to preview the portal on. Change the available devices in Backbase Portal Manager Configuration.

Top

7.4 Special Pages

In the overview page of your portal, you can click on the Special Pages tab. In this tab you can set special pages:

Table 7.2. Special Page

Special Page

Description

Default Landing Page

The page that opens when you open the URL of the portal without specifying a page. Select an existing page from the drop-down box.

Access Denied Page

Backbase Portal shows this page when the user tries to open a page that he does not have permission to see.

You can specify any custom web page or a page or link from the portal. The benefit of a custom web page is that it is not dependent on a database, but the downside is you cannot publish it. Enter an absolute URL or a relative URL without the application context (this is usually portalserver):

  • Custom page (local) — /localpath/somepage.html

  • Custom page (remote) — http://www.example.com/somepage.html

  • Page — /portals/portal_name/pages/page_name

  • Link friendly URL — /friendly_url

  • Link hierarchical URL — /portal/[parent_link]/[parent_link]/link_section_name

Backbase Portal ships with a set of login, logout and error pages located in the target/your_project/login folder in your portal project or the login folder in the unpacked WAR file.

Logout Page

Backbase Portal shows this page after logging out. See Access Denied Page for what to enter here.

Error Page

Backbase Portal shows this page when the user tries to open a page that does not exist. See Access Denied Page for what to enter here.

Login Page

This page is the log in screen. See Access Denied Page for what to enter here.

Authentication Failure Page

Backbase Portal shows this page when a log in action has failed. See Access Denied Page for what to enter here.


Top

7.5 Audit Trails

Administrators can access the Audit Trails app in Backbase Portal Manager. This app displays records of successful CRUD operations in the editorial environment. The logs include the user, the timestamp, the affected items, and the type of operation. You can filter the records by user, by portal, item, item type, and by date interval.

For more information, see Architecture and URL Modifiers.

Top

7.6 Configuration

The uiEditingOptions.js file defines the look and feel of the user interface in Backbase Portal Manager. The file is located in target/your_project/static/conf in your portal project and is written in the JSON format.

To change the configuration:

  1. Create a folder named src/main/webapp/static/conf in your portal project.

  2. Copy there the target/your_project/static/conf/uiEditingOptions.js file and modify it.

  3. Build your project.

This table shows the keys for each object in uiEditingOptions.js:

  • widgetPreferenceSelections

    Table 7.3. WidgetPreferenceSelections

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    widgetChrome

    object

    The key/value pairs specify, respectively, the name and the file location of the Widget Chrome Template. The file location starts with $(contextRoot), i.e. the src/main/webapp folder in your portal project.

    The Widget Chrome drop-down menu is present in all widgets in the Edit Preferences - Settings tab and activates and deactivates the widget chrome.


  • catalog

    Table 7.4. catalog

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    itemsPerRequest

    integer

    The maximum number of items returned by the catalog web-service per each request.


  • usersAndGroups

    Table 7.5. UsersAndGroups

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    allowManagement

    boolean

    Whether to enable user and group management in Backbase Portal Manager. If set to false, users and groups are visible in Backbase Portal Manager, but adding and editing them is disabled.


  • defaultPageTemplates

    Table 7.6. defaultPageTemplates

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    tablet

    string

    The technical name of the default page template for portals optimized for tablet devices. The default is a page template from the Veltro bundle.

    mobile

    string

    The technical name of the default page template for portals optimized for mobile devices. The default is a page template from the Veltro bundle.

    smart

    string

    The technical name of the default page template for portals optimized for mixed devices. The default is a page template from the Sabre bundle.

    web

    string

    The technical name of the default page template for portals optimized for desktop devices. The default is a page template from the Sabre bundle.


  • portalDevices

    These entries define the Optimized for field present in the Create new portal dialog and also the Device-specific Previewing functionality of Backbase Portal Manager. This configuration has no effect on the rendering of pages. For consistency, please keep the devices in sync with the Device Recognition Configuration.

    Table 7.7. portalDevices

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    desktop

    object

    A list of key/value pairs specifying the desktop devices listed in the Desktop usage drop-down menu in the Optimized for field. Specify for each device the name, width, height, and rotatable attributes.

    mobile

    object

    A list of key/value pairs specifying the desktop devices listed in the Mobile usage drop-down menu in the Optimized for field. Specify for each device the name, width, height, and rotatable attributes.

    tablet

    object

    A list of key/value pairs specifying the desktop devices listed in the Tablet usage drop-down menu in the Optimized for field. Specify for each device the name, width, height, and rotatable attributes.


  • customStyles

    Table 7.8. CustomStyles

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    A collection of objects

    object

    Each object contains a collection of key/value pairs specifying, respectively, a CSS class name and a CSS selector. CSS styles for the Rich Content widget are available in the Class name... drop-down menu. The objects are passed to the JavaScript class CustomStyleSelector, which accepts the first listed object by default. Currently the bbTemplate and Sample objects are offered. The CSS declaration is stored in a separate CSS file.


  • cmisTypeData

    Table 7.9. cmisTypeData

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    A collection of objects

    object

    A list of key/value pairs specifying, respectively, a MIME type and the corresponding custom CMIS object type in the Content Services object model. For more information, see CMIS Object Model.


  • repositoryBrowser

    Table 7.10. RepositoryBrowser

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    fullCRUDtoManagerRole

    boolean

    Whether managers should have full CRUD privileges in the Repository Browser. If set to true, managers will be granted full CRUD privileges. If false, only administrators will have full CRUD privileges.

    maxFileLoadedPerTime

    integer

    The number of files loaded in the Repository Browser. If more files exist, a button appears to load the remaining files.

    autoLoadFile

    boolean

    Do not change this setting.

    filesType

    string

    A list of MIME types of the files to be displayed in the Repository Browser. If set to '', all files are displayed.

    metaDataList

    object

    A list of key/value pairs specifying, respectively, a CMIS property and the corresponding label displayed in the Repository Browser.


  • pageDesigner

    Table 7.11. PageDesigner

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    enableDNDForContainers

    boolean

    Do not change this setting. Value should be true.


  • editorPlugins

    Table 7.12. EditorPlugins

    Key

    Data Type

    Description

    iconsPath

    string

    The path to the icons in the floating panel. You can concatenate the path with the bd.contextRoot variable that defines the application context, i.e. the src/main/webapp folder in your portal project. For example: bd.contextRoot+ '/static/dashboard/media/rte/nicEditorIcons.png'.

    iconsList

    array of string

    Comma-separated list of key/value pairs with button names as keys and icon numbers as values. The key/value pairs link the icon number from the iconsPath picture to a button name. For example, "italic":2 means that second icon in the picture depicts the italic button.

    tabs

    array of objects

    Each object specifies a tab in the floating panel. For a list of accepted key/value pairs for the tabs objects, see Defining Tabs.


Defining Tabs

tabs objects accept the following values:

Table 7.13. Keys for Tabs Objects

Key

Data Type

Description

string

The tab title.

boolean

Whether the current tab is the default tab. Only one tab can be the default for a widget.

Whether the floating panel is blank, in which case it will show the text specified in content.

If the floating panel is blank, it displays this text to inform the user why there are no formatting tabs. For example, if content editing for this element is disabled, the text is 'No editing available.'.

  • Image Viewer — bd-image

  • Image and Text

    bd-notEditable — not-editable content

    bd-headerArea — title and subtitle

    bd-contentArea — content

    bd-linkArea — link

    bd-imgArea — image

Comma-separated list of buttons in the tab. For the possible values, see Button List.

Button

7.7 Global Constants

The global-constants.js file contains constants that apply to Backbase Portal Manager. The file is located in the target/your_project/static/conf in your portal project.

If you want to edit the file, you have to copy it from the target folder to the src folder. First create the folder src/main/webapp/static/conf in your portal project. Then copy the file from target/your_project/static/conf to the created folder.

Table 7.15. Global Constants

Constant

Description

enabled

Whether the session handler is enabled.

timeoutMinutes

The time in minutes without user activity before the session times out.

offsetMinutes

Optional. The time in minutes Backbase Portal Manager will subtract from timeoutMinutes to avoid synchronization issues.

countDownSeconds

The time in seconds before a dialog warns of impending session time out.

pingRefreshSeconds

The time in seconds before Backbase Portal Manager resets the session timeout counter during user activity.

cookieName

The name of the cookie used to synchronize session handler events across browser windows, tabs, or page frames.

loginUrl

The URL of the log in page.

logoutUrl

The URL of the page shown when the session has timed out.

pingUrl

The URL of a dummy request that Backbase Portal Manager sends every pingRefreshSeconds during user activity to reset the session timeout counter.

8 Glossary

A

Approver

A user authorized to approve changes made on portals by editors.

Archiving

Storing publish packages on the file system for future reference and compliance with legal standards.

Audit Trails

An optional feature of Backbase Portal Foundation that records successful CRUD operations made in editorial environments. The Audit Trail app is a Backbase Portal Manager app that displays these records. Only administrators can access it.

B

Backbase Portal Client

A jQuery-based JavaScript library that renders items client-side, handles interaction on the page, and communicates changes to Backbase Portal Foundation.

Backbase Portal Foundation

The main module of Backbase Portal. It is in charge of authentication, authorization, server-side rendering of the items, persisting the model, providing web services, and co-ordinating the other modules.

Backbase Portal Manager

The Backbase Portal graphical user-interface. It quickly and easily creates portals, manages pushing processes, inspects and modify items, and manages user and group authorization.

C

Catalog

A collection of abstract items. There are server-level and portal-level catalogs, with different authorization levels. Catalogs are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Catalog class and can contain any object extending the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.conceptual.Item class.

Client-side rendering

Backbase Portal Client creates an HTML view within a client browser of the XML model transmitted by Backbase Portal Foundation.

Container

A section of a web page. Containers are a Backbase Portal object and are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Container class. Containers are children of pages or other containers, and can contain widgets. For more information, see Containers.

Content

Any piece of information stored in a content repository.

Content repository

A store of content with associated methods for data management, search, and access.

Content Services

The module of Backbase Portal offering a mostly CMIS-compliant content repository solution.

CRUD operations

CREATE, READ, UPDATE, and DELETE operations performed on objects or content.

D

DTAP

Development-Testing-Acceptance-Production. A common pattern in software development cycles.

E

Editor

A user authorized to create and modify portals on an editorial environment.

Editorial environment

A Backbase Portal installation not accessible to the public and used by editors to develop portals. Changes made in editorial environments need to be approved before being published to a stage or live environment.

Events

Pages, layouts and widget can fire events client-side. For example when the user maximizes a widget, the widget fires a perspective change event. You can create event listeners in JavaScript to associate behavior with an event. For more information, see Page Event Listeners, Layout Event Listeners and Widget Event Listeners.

F

Four-eye principle

This principle is a control mechanism designed to achieve a high level of security for especially critical material or operations. Under this rule all access and actions requires the presence of two authorized people at all times.

G

Group

A collection of users. Groups map to the Spring Security GrantedAuthority class and determine the permission level of the users belonging to them. Groups are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Group class.

L

Link

A Backbase Portal item storing pointers to other objects or external URLs. There are different types of links depending on the referred object:

  • Page links: links pointing to pages.

  • Aliases: links pointing to pages which already have a page link assigned.

  • External links: links pointing to external URLs.

  • Dividers: empty links only displaying a divider in navigation trees.

  • Headers: links pointing to other links.

  • State links: links referring to different states of an item.

Links are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Link class. For more information, see Links.

Live environment

A Backbase Portal installation accessible for end-users and ready for production.

Locking

Items for which a publishing request has been sent are locked, i.e. they cannot be modified until the request is processed. The lockState element of a locked item is set to LOCKED.

M

Mashup Services

The module of Backbase Portal in charge of proxying, caching, and transforming HTTP requests and responses. It runs embedded with Backbase Portal Foundation by default, but it can also run independently on a separate server.

Master page

A blueprint for a page including layouts, widgets and the page template. The master page designer sets certain areas of the page as editable for the manager. The other areas are only editable for the master page designer.

Master pages are stored in the server or portal catalog. A normal page extends the master page and inherits its properties, template, and children (containers and widgets).

Model-view-controller

A pattern in software development that separates the representation of information from the interaction with it. Backbase Portal implements this pattern as follows:

  • Model: the Backbase Portal object model.

  • View: the HTML representation displayed by the client application.

  • Controller: server-side, an instance of Backbase Portal Foundation. Client-side, the Backbase Portal Client libraries.

O

Orchestrator

The module of Backbase Portal in charge of the publishing process.

P

Page

A page in the portal website. Pages are a Backbase Portal object and are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Page class. The page template determines the look-and-feel of a page. Pages can extend a master page and inherit its page template and children.

Portal

A secure, unified access point for integrating information, people, and processes across organizational boundaries. Portals are a Backbase Portal object and are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Portal class. Portals have pages as children.

Publishing

Moving objects to a staging or live environment according to a publishing chain.

Publishing chain

A sequence of environments or portals an item has to be published to. Each publishing step may or may not require approval from an approver. For more information, see Publishing Configuration.

Publish package

A zipped archive containing pages to be published.

R

Re-publishing

Re-publishing all pages previously published to a staging or live environment.

Right

A mapping of a security item (a group or role) to a permission. Rights are enforced on objects (e.g. portals, pages, widgets) and on properties of objects.

Role

A set of permissions assigned to a group. Roles are mapped to the Spring Security GrantedAuthority class.

S

Scope

The context within the Backbase Portal object model where an object resides. In each scope, objects can be defined (that is, abstract) or instantiated. Each scope requires a different authorization level. For more information, see Object Model.

Server-side rendering

Backbase Portal Foundation creates an HTML view of the XML model and transmits it to the requesting client browser.

Staging environment

A Backbase Portal installation not accessible for end-users and used to simulate a live environment.

State

Whether an object is defined (that is, abstract), or instantiated. See also Scope.

T

Template

A JSP file that defines how Backbase Portal Foundation renders a page, a container, or a widget server-side. For more information, see Page Template, Containers and Widget Template.

U

Unpublishing

Removing pages previously published to a staging or live environment.

URL

Backbase Portal supports the following URL types:

  • Friendly URLs: easy-to-remember, optional addresses of links, see URLs

  • Hierarchical URLs: automatically generated addresses of links that reflect the link hierarchy, see URLs

  • Internal URLs: automatically generated addresses of pages, containers and widgets, see REST Interface

User

Any person or software accessing a portal. Users are members of groups, from which they derive roles. Different roles have different rights on particular objects. The user object is an instance of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.User class.

W

Widget

A small application that can be integrated in a web page. Widgets are Backbase Portal object and are instances of the com.backbase.portal.foundation.domain.model.Widget class. They are children of containers or pages. For more information, see Widgets.

Widget definition

An HTML file defining the widget content. For more information, see Widgets.

Backbase Portal has a different setup on editorial environments or staging/live environments. The main difference is that editorial environments contain Backbase Portal Manager and the other environments don't. For more information on environments, see Release Management. Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers, see Distributed Environment.

Editorial Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in an editorial environment is as follows:

Here follows a brief description of the items in the diagram.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Backbase Portal Foundation performs the following tasks:

    • Authentication and Authorization

    • Server-side rendering

    • Persist changes to pages (and other objects) on the data store. For more information, see Object Model.

    • Audit Trails (optional)

      Audit Trails logs data about successful CRUD operations executed in editorial environments. The records include the user, the timestamp, the affected item, and the type of operation. Audit Trails is optional and uses a secured database that runs along the Backbase Portal Foundation database on the same server. ADMIN users can access the logs from the Audit Trail app in Backbase Portal Manager.

      For more information, see Install Audit Trails and Audit Trails.

  • Mashup Services

    Mashup Services delivers remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter and transform HTTP requests and responses. For more information, see Mashup Services.

  • Content Services

    Content Services is a content delivery platform. It can store content to its own database and can harvest remote content, for example from CMIS repositories. For more information, see Content Services.

  • Orchestrator

    Orchestrator publishes database objects and content from Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services. It performs the following tasks:

    • It locks items after a publishing request.

    • It creates, sends, retrieves, archives, and unpacks publish packages.

    • It waits for approval of an authorized user before publishing.

    For more information, see Publishing.

  • Backbase Portal Manager

    Backbase Portal Manager is an application that allows business users to manage and design pages in the portal and publish the changes to another environment, e.g. from editorial to staging. Backbase Portal Manager communicates with Backbase Portal to store changes and with Orchestrator to publish changes.

    For more information, see Backbase Portal Manager.

  • Templates

    Developers create templates that define how a page (and containers and widgets on the page) are rendered.

    For more information, see Customization.

  • Backbase Portal Client

    Backbase Portal Client performs the following tasks:

    • Client-side rendering

    • Handle interaction on the page and communicate changes to Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • REST client

    Backbase Portal Foundation has a REST interface and you can use any REST client to communicate with it. Data is conveyed via XML. For more information, see Communication.

Staging/Live Environments

The setup of Backbase Portal in staging or live environments is similar to the editorial environment, except that it does not include Backbase Portal Manager. Only the live environment is accessible for end-users.

1.1 Distributed Environment

Within one environment, the modules of Backbase Portal can run on different servers:

Take the following actions when moving a module to a different server:

  • Backbase Portal Foundation

    Edit the ice-config.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the server running Mashup Services. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Backbase Portal Foundation data store

    Edit the database configuration of Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the portalDS datasource

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Mashup Services (stand-alone)

    Edit the -DPORTALSERVER_PROXY_URL=mashup_services_url parameter either in the JAVA_OPTS environment variable or in the start up script of the application server running Backbase Portal Foundation. For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services

    1. Edit the ice-config.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation, or if Mashup Services runs stand-alone, on the server running Mashup Services.

    2. Edit the following properties in the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation:

      • foundation.content.proxy.destination

      • foundation.content.proxy.username

      • foundation.content.proxy.password

      For more information, see Configuration.

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Content Services database

    Edit the database configuration of Content Services:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the content-ds, configuration-ds and resource-ds datasources

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

  • Content Services file system

    Set contentservices.repository.configuration.fileLocation in the backbase.properties file to a shared folder located on a different machine. For more information, see Content Services Settings.

  • Orchestrator

    Edit the following properties in the backbase.properties file on the server running Backbase Portal Foundation:

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.destination

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.username

    • foundation.orchestrator.proxy.password

    For more information, see Proxy Configuration.

  • Orchestrator database

    Edit the database configuration of Orchestrator:

    • Apache Tomcat — the tomcat_install_dir/conf/context.xml file

    • WebSphere — the orchestratorDS datasource

    • JBoss — the jboss_install_dir/server/default/deploy/database-type-ds.xml file

    For more information, see Application Servers.

1.2 Release Management

Overview

Release management in Backbase Portal requires a DTAP route and a publishing route. The DTAP (development, test, acceptance and production) route handles the release of files. The publishing (editorial, staging, live) route handles the release of database objects.

Staging and live environments do not contain Backbase Portal Manager. For Backbase Portal Foundation, development environments are Maven projects. Test, accept, and production environments are deployed WAR files.

DTAP Route

For Backbase Portal Foundation, files in the portal project are released via DTAP. Make sure to follow the best practice of using Bundles. You can either package a bundle and unpack it in another environment, or package the portal project in a WAR file and deploy the WAR to another environment.

For Mashup Services and Content Services, only an upgrade of the WAR file and configuration files are released via the DTAP route.

Publishing Route

Database objects of Backbase Portal Foundation and Content Services and the content repository of Content Services are released via publishing. Mashup Services is not part of publishing.

Inheritance

The Backbase Portal object model uses inheritance extensively. When a business user places a widget on a page from the catalog, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the widget in the catalog. The new widget inherits all elements from the extended widget.

Similarly, when an end-user personalizes an object, Backbase Portal Foundation extends the original object and applies the personalization. An example of a personalization is moving a widget to another location on the page.

Both in the case of extensions and personalizations, Backbase Portal only saves changes and not the inherited elements. This makes the Backbase Portal object model scalable and efficient.

Rights can either be set for a particulart object, or inherited as follows:

  • Abstract objects in the server catalog inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

  • Abstract objects in a portal catalog inherit the rights from the portal.

  • Instantiated objects inherit the rights from their parent (either a portal, a page, or a container).

If any part of the rights of an object is set, all inherited rights are copied to the object.

State, Scope, and Role

Each object has a state that combines two security aspects of the object:

  • Who can access this object?

    Backbase Portal supports multi-tenancy: you can manage multiple portals with one installation. Objects exist within one of three scopes and only administrators can access objects with the highest scope. This way, managers and users of a portal cannot access objects on another portal.

  • Is the object defined or instantiated?

    A defined object has no parent. An instantiated object has a parent, which is either a portal, a page, or a container. This means that only an instantiated object is visible on the portal website.

    For example, when a widget is created, it has a defined state and no parent. When someone drags it on a page, Backbase Portal Foundation creates a new widget that extends the defined widget. The new widget will have an instantiated state and the page as parent.

Deleting Objects

Deleting an object in Backbase Portal has the following impact:

  • Children

    Some objects can have children (see Children above). Deletions in Backbase Portal always cascade, i.e. children are deleted as well.

    For example, if you delete a page, its containers and widgets are also deleted.

  • Inheritance

    Backbase Portal extends objects to make the object model efficient (see Inheritance above). Deletions in Backbase Portal propagate, meaning that objects inheriting from the deleted object are deleted as well. For example, if you delete a catalog widget, its widget instances are also deleted. However, it is not possible to delete master pages that other pages extend. Backbase Portal Manager offers an easy method to delete master pages, because a pop-up asks you to select a different master page for pages that inherit from the master page you are trying to delete.

  • Link references

    Deleting a link also deletes the page the link refers to. This is the page referred to by the link ItemRef property. If other links refer to the same page, the following applies:

    • If another link refers to the same page, the page is not deleted.

    • If a state link refers to the same page, the page is deleted and the state link is also deleted.

Only users with the ADMIN role can delete objects.

If enabled, Audit Trails logs DELETE operations. For more information, see Architecture.

Note

Deletions in Backbase Portal cannot be undone.

Deleting Properties

It is possible to delete object properties by setting the MarkedForDeletion attribute to true in a PUT call. For more information, see propertyType.

If enabled, Audit Trails logs PUT operations. For more information, see Architecture.

Backbase Portal objects have an Access Control List called rights. Each right maps a security item (a group or role) to a permission. The Spring Security configuration determines how security items (groups and roles) map to permissions.

Rights Inheritance

Objects either inherit their rights or have their own rights:

  • Not inherit

    The itemRight element has an inherited attribute. If an administrator sets the rights of an object, Backbase Portal Foundation sets the inherited attribute tofalse and saves the new rights for the object.

  • Inherit

    If the inherited attribute is true, the object inherits rights as follows:

    • Abstract objects (without a parent):

      • Objects in the server scope inherit the rights from Backbase Portal Foundation.

      • Objects in a portal scope inherit the rights from the portal.

    • Instantiated objects (with a parent) inherit the rights from the parent.

Note that links inherit rights in the same way, but the property SecuritySameAsParent determines whether the link inherits its rights or not. Backbase Portal Foundation also sets the inherited attribute on the itemRight object, but the SecuritySameAsParent property is leading.

Backbase Portal Objects

The main objects in Backbase Portal are templates, catalogs, portals, pages, containers, widgets, and links.

For more information, see Object Model.

Exposing URLs

You may want to limit access to some URLs of the public portal to avoid end users seeing 'not authorized' messages instead of 'not available' messages. You cannot limit access to the following URLs, because they are necessary for functionality of Backbase Portal:

  • All portal, page, container and widget URLs belonging to REST Interface

  • /proxy — only when integrating with Mashup Services

  • /content — only when integrating with Content Services

Other URLs are eligible to limit access to:

  • /import

  • /caches

  • /groups

  • /users

  • /templates

  • /orchestrator

1.5 Caches

Backbase Portal Foundation uses the following caches to improve response time:

Name

Description

Caches the widget chromes that Backbase Portal Foundation retrieves from the server.

Caches fully rendered pages including children according to the configuration, see Backbase Portal Foundation Settings. This is useful for landing pages that require fast response time. Change Cache Settings

If you want to change the caching settings, you need to unpack the com.backbase.portal.foundation-configuration-5.3.1.1.jar located in target/your_project/WEB-INF/lib in your portal project or WEB-INF/lib in the unpacked WAR file. 1 Overview

Content Services is a content delivery platform provided as a Backbase Portal optional module. It provides repository capabilities and relies on a library of importers to harvest content from sources like CMIS repositories or RSS and Atom feeds.

The following figure shows the elements composing Content Services:

Repositories

Content Services implements the CMIS Standard and relies on three repositories to manage content and configuration files:

  • contentRepository stores content used by Backbase Portal, like images, text, and content harvested from remote sources. One can navigate this repository from the Content Browser in Backbase Portal Manager. For more information, see Architecture.

  • configurationRepository stores configuration files for Importers.

  • resourcesRepository stores Backbase Portal resources.

Interfaces

Content Services is accessible via the following interfaces:

  • CMIS interface: enables interaction with any of the three repositories (contentRepository, configurationRepository, and resourcesRepository) at a very low level, for example down to metadata. You can establish connections using a CMIS client such as CMIS Workbench, a REST client, or by implementing a Mashup Services custom data provider. For more information, see Paging, Filtering, and Sorting and Custom Data Provider.

  • WebDAV interface: allows to manipulate objects and folders in Content Services repositories. WebDAV clients such as BitKinex and WebDAV-enabled applications such as Adobe Dreamweaver CS5 provide both file system and editing support. For file system operations alone, a WebDAV-enabled file manager like Microsoft Windows Explorer is sufficient. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

  • JMX interface: manages and monitors the content delivery service and is useful to configure and administer the Content Services server. For more information, see JMX Interface.

2 CMIS Object Model

2.1. CMIS Query
2.2. Paging, Filtering, and Sorting
2.3. Query Comparison Matrix
2.4. CMIS Services Comparison

The CMIS object model represents entities in CMIS repositories. The Content Services implementation of the CMIS model consists of the cmis:document and cmis:folder basic object types, to which repository objects belong. The two other standard object types, cmis:relationship and cmis:policy, are not implemented, see picture below. For an overview of the CMIS services implemented in Content Services, see CMIS Services Comparison.

CMIS object types have a queryable and a queryName attribute: queryable determines whether an object type should be queried, and queryName is used to identify the object type in the FROM clause of a SELECT statement. Similarly, object properties have a queryable attribute that is used in WHERE clauses.

Note

Content Services currently does not support the standard includedInSuperType attribute.

Each object type has a list of attributes and properties specific to that particular type: these are spelled out in the CMIS specification, which also details how to extend the basic object types and create new ones. For a more detailed explanation of the individual basic object types, please see the CMIS Standard.

Object Types

These are the object types in Content Services:

  • cmis:document

    The cmis:document object type represents pieces of content in the repository, like images, text or CSS files. Document objects may have content streams, i.e. files, associated with them, or may not. For example, the Content Services bb:link custom object type extends cmis:document and contains no content streams. If present, content streams are associated to a MIME type and can have Renditions.

  • cmis:folder

    cmis:folder objects are folders in the repository and contain cmis:document objects. They can only have one parent folder and can contain multiple cmis:document objects. Folder objects may have Renditions.

    Note

    Content Services currently does not support the cmis:allowedChildObjectTypeIds attribute in the cmis:folder object type.

  • bb:link

    Stores hyperlinks. This object type has no content stream. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:url: the link URL

    • bb:title: the link text

  • bb:richtext

    Stores rich text content for the Rich Text Editor widget. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:title: the title of the text item

    • bb:subTitle: the subtitle of the text item

    • bb:description: the description of the text item

  • bb:image

    Stores images. It extends cmis:document and adds the following properties:

    • bb:altText: the alternative text in case the image cannot be displayed

    • bb:height: the image height in pixels

    • bb:width: the image width in pixels

    • bb:tag: a comma-separated list of tags with meta data

    • bb:title: the title of the image

    • bb:lastPublishedDate: the last publishing date

    • bb:subTitle: the subtitle of the image

    • bb:description: the description of the image

2.1 CMIS Query

Content Services implements a subset of the query language specified in the CMIS Standard, itself an implementation of the SQL-92 standard. For a list of supported CMIS features, see Query Comparison Matrix. This topic describes the CMIS query language as used in Content Services. You can execute queries from a client like CMIS Workbench. For more information, see CMIS Workbench.

Query structure

Content Services implements the FROM, WHERE and ORDER BY clauses according to the SQL-92 specification, but does not implement the GROUP BY and HAVING clauses.

  • SELECT

    The SELECT statement specifies the columns to retrieve from the table specified in the FROM clause. Contrary to the CMIS specification, you can only use an asterisk (*, meaning all columns) in the SELECT statement in Content Services.

  • FROM

    The FROM clause specifies the object type.

  • WHERE

    The WHERE clause is optional and filters the results to match a condition.

    Note

    Content Services does not support the following operators in the WHERE conditional clause: NULL, quantified comparison operators (ANY, ALL and SOME) and BETWEEN.

    These are the supported operators:

    Table 2.1. CMIS Query Operators

    Operator

    Description

    =

    Equal to

    <>

    Unequal to

    <

    Less than

    >

    Greater than

    <=

    Less than or equal to

    >=

    Greater than or equal to

    IN

    Matches the value against a specified value list. For example, the following statement returns objects with the Backbase Object Types:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:objectTypeId IN ('bb:image', 'bb:richtext','bb:link')

    LIKE

    Matches the value against a specified pattern. Use a percent % and underscore _ to form patterns. The percent character represents zero or more of characters. The underscore character represents one character.

    For example, the following statement returns all documents with a name starting with j:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:name LIKE 'j%'

    This statement returns all XML files with a four-letter name starting with j:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:name LIKE 'j___.xml'

    Use the keywords OR and AND to combine conditional statements. AND takes precedence over OR.

  • ORDER BY

    The ORDER BY clause is optional and sorts the result list. Use ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC) order. The default order is ascending.

    For example, the following query returns all XML documents and orders them ascending by object ID:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:contentStreamMimeType = 'text/xml' ORDER BY cmis:objectId

    This query returns the same rows, but in descending order:

    SELECT * FROM cmis:document WHERE cmis:contentStreamMimeType = 'text/xml' ORDER BY cmis:objectId DESC

Top

2.2 Paging, Filtering, and Sorting

Content Services uses URL modifiers to filter, page, and sort responses to HTTP calls.

Filtering Properties

The filter URL modifier specifies the properties included in the HTTP response. The cmis:name, cmis:objectTypeId, and cmis:baseTypeId properties are required and cannot be filtered out.

For example, the following request returns the cmis:objectId property for the children of the object with the specified ID:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId

Separate multiple properties with a comma:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId,cmis:path
Remove Allowable Actions

By default, responses include the allowable actions, that is the actions allowed on each object. Add includeAllowableActions=false to filter them out:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=2eeb962f-0187-4cf0-aa2b-2e131c36612b&filter=cmis:objectId&includeAllowableActions=false
Paging

Paging modifiers display responses on multiple pages:

Table 2.2. Paging Modifiers

Modifier

Description

maxItems

The number of results in the response.

skipCount

The first result number in the response.


For example, the following request returns the first twelve results (the first page with twelve items):

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=0

The following request returns the third page with twelve items:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=24
Sorting

The orderBy modifier sorts results in ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC) order. Place a space encoded as %20 between the property and ASC or DESC. The following example sorts the results in ascending order by the cmis:name property, and in descending order by the cmis:path property:

GET http://host/path/contentRepository/children?id=92cf712b-043f-4e5b-a605-e1ca3834b4fb&maxItems=12&skipCount=0&orderBy=cmis:name%20ASC,cmis:path%20DESC

3 Importers

3.1. Feed Importers
3.2. CMIS Importers
3.3. Importer Jobs

This chapter explains how to create feed and CMIS importers, and how to schedule their execution.

3.1 Feed Importers

Feed importers fetch content from RSS or Atom sources and import it into contentRepository.

Follow these steps to configure an importer:

  1. Create folders

    Access configurationRepository. In the repository root create:

    • A folder named importers and a subfolder named feed

    • A folder named scheduler and a subfolder named jobs.

    For more information, see the Enabling WebDAV and CMIS Workbench.

  2. Create importer configuration

    Create an importer configuration file with the content below, save it with a .properties extension on the file system and and upload it as a cmis:document to the importers/feed folder you created in the step above:

    id=BloombergBlog
group=feedgroup
description=The Bloomberg Blog Feed
targetRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetFolderPath=/myfeeds
remoteLocation=http://inside.bloomberg.com/blog/atom.xml
defaultEncoding=utf-8

    The example above imports the Bloomberg Blog feed from http://inside.bloomberg.com/blog/atom.xml and stores the content in the myfeeds folder in contentRepository.

    For more information, see Importers.

    Note

    All importer configurations must have a .properties extension.

  3. Create job

    Create an importer job as explained in Importer Jobs.

  4. Create target folder

    In contentRepository create a folder named, for example, myfeeds.

  5. Restart Content Services

    Restart Content Services to make the changes effective. The myfeeds folder in contenRepository should contain the feed XML file.

The Feed Reader widget in the Sabre bundle turns RSS content into HTML. For more information, see Sabre.

Top

3.2 CMIS Importers

CMIS importers fetch content from remote repositories and import it into contentRepository.

Follow these steps to configure an importer:

  1. Create folders

    Access configurationRepository. In the repository root create:

    • A folder named importers and a subfolder named cmis

    • A folder named scheduler and a subfolder named jobs.

  2. Create importer configuration

    Create an importer configuration file with the content below, save it on the file system with a .properties extension, and upload it as a cmis:document to the importers/cmis folder you created in the step above:

    id=AlfrescoCmisImporter
group=cmisgroup
description=This Importer Fetches Content from the Alfresco 3.4 Public Repository

sourceCmisLocation=http://cmis.alfresco.com/service/cmis
sourceCmisRepositoryId=371554cd-ac06-40ba-98b8-e6b60275cca7
sourceCmisFolderPath=/TestFolder
sourceUserName=admin
sourcePassword=admin

targetCmisLocation=http://host:port/contentservices/atom
targetCmisRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetCmisFolderPath=/Alfresco
targetUserName=admin
targetPassword=admin

defaultEncoding=utf-8

    The example above imports content from /TestFolder in the Alfresco 3.4 CMIS Content Repository into the Alfresco folder in contentRepository. For more information, see Importers.

    Note

    All importer configurations must have a .properties extension.

  3. Create job

    Create an importer job as explained in Importer Jobs.

  4. Create target folder

    In contentRepository create a folder named, for example, Alfresco.

  5. Restart Content Services

    Restart Content Services to make the changes effective.

    The Alfresco folder should fill up with the content from Guest Home in the Alfresco repository.

Top

3.3 Importer Jobs

Content Services regularly runs importers according to cron expressions.

Follow these steps to configure an importer job:

  1. Enable importer jobs

    Importer jobs are disabled by default. To enable them, open the backbase.properties file and add the following line: 

    contentservices.repository.scheduler.enabled=true

  2. Create job folder

    Access contentRepository and create the scheduler/job folder.

  3. Create importer job configuration

    Create a file named, for example, myjob.properties. Fill it with the lines below, and upload it to the /scheduler/job folder as a cmis:document object:

    #this job runs the cmisgroup importer configurations every 5 minutes
id=myJob
jobGroup=cmisgroup
cron=* 0/5 * * * ?

    The myJob scheduler runs the importers in the cmisgroup every five minutes. For more information, please refer to Quartz 1.x Tutorials: crontrigger.

    Note

    All importer job configurations must have a .properties extension.

4.1. Mounting Repositories
4.2. Integrating Content Items
4.3. CMIS Workbench

4.1 Mounting Repositories

This section explains how to map a network drive under Microsoft Windows and how to mount a repository to a Unix file system.

Mapping a Network Drive under Microsoft Windows

Microsoft Windows provides a WebDAV client called WebDAV Mini Redirector. Follow these steps to map a network drive to a repository:

  1. Right-click on My Computer and select Map Network Drive....

  2. Enter the repository address in the form:

    http://host:port/applicationcontext/webdav/repositoryname/

    The URL consists of the following parts:

    Table 4.1. Content Services URL Parts

    URL Part

    Default

    Description

    host

    localhost

    The host name of the server that hosts Content Services.

    port

    Apache Tomcat: 8080

    WebSphere: 9080

    JBoss: 8080

    You can set the port in the application server settings.

    applicationcontext

    contentservices

    This value usually reflects the name of the deployed WAR file.


    repositoryname is one of contentRepository, configurationRepository or resourcesRepository.

  3. Login with user name and password admin, admin.

4.2 Integrating Content Items

To integrate content items in widget definitions and templates, retrieve the object ID as explained in CMIS Workbench and specify it when referring to the content item:

Example: Templates

The following example shows a div in a page template that displays a header and a logout link:

<div id="header" style="height:100px;
    background-image:url(http://localhost:8080/contentservices/atom/contentRepository/content/image.png?id=b15b33fd-6ad3-4ef4-9e2b-10b675fa6844)">
    <sec:authorize ifNotGranted="role_anonymous"><a
     href="/portalserver/doc-center/manuals/portal/<c:url value="/j_spring_security_logout"/>">logout</a></sec:authorize>
    <sec:authentication property="name"/>
</div>
Example: Widget Definitions

The following definition displays a repository image in the widget:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/>
        <title>Hello World</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <p>Hello World of Content Services</p>
        <img src="http://localhost:8080/contentservices/atom/contentRepository/content/image.png?id=b15b33fd-6ad3-4ef4-9e2b-10b675fa6844)" />
    </body>
</html>

Accessing Repositories

  2. Enter user name and password. The defaults are, respectively, admin and admin.

Uploading Content

5 Validators

Content Services can validate CRUD operations before executing them. For example, it can cancel the creation of an object if the required properties are not set.

Rules about CRUD operations in the repository are defined and enforced by validators:

A listener mechanism intercepts all CRUD events in the repository and calls a validator engine. The validator engine then calls all the registered validators: if an operation does not comply to a rule, the validator throws an exception and the operation is canceled. Otherwise, the validator engine returns control to the listener and to the repository service that carries out the requested operation.

Content Services currently ships with only the RepositorySchemaValidator validator, but one can create Custom Validators.

The RepositorySchemaValidator validator checks that an object complies to its type schema before a create/update operation. In other words, it ensures that all required properties are set and keeps all repository objects in valid state.

5.1 Custom Validators

Content Services makes it possible to easily create custom validators. In order to do so, follow these steps:

  1. Create a validator class that implements the RepositoryValidator interface and save it under WEB-INF/lib in the Content Services folder. For more information, please refer to the Content Services Javadoc API.

  2. Register the validator in the backbase.properties file. Validators are registered under the contentservices.validators key. Multiple validators should be comma-separated as shown below:

    contentservices.validators=com.backbase.portal.contentservices.validator.impl.RepositorySchemaValidator,
com.yourcompany.contentservices.validator.impl.YourOwnValidator

    Note

    The validator engine calls validators in the same order they appear in the configuration file. In other words, order matters.

  3. Restart the application server.

6 Renditions

6.1. Rendition Engines
6.2. Rendition Services
6.3. Thumbnail Rendition Engine

Content Services can create renditions of content items. CRUD events in the repository trigger a rendition service that invokes the relevant rendition engine. The engine carries out the necessary transformations and returns the rendition to the repository:

For more information, please refer to the CMIS Standard.

6.1 Rendition Engines

Rendition engines transform content items to create the specific renditions; they extend the RenditionEngine abstract class.

The main abstract methods in the RenditionEngine class, createRenditions and updateRenditions, return a list of one or more RenditionData objects.

These are the the properties of renditionData objects:

Table 6.1. Rendition Attributes

Property

Mandatory

Description

streamId

✓

The stream unique identifier.

mimeType

✓

The MIME type of the rendition stream.

length

-

The length of the rendition stream in bytes.

title

-

Human readable information about the rendition.

kind

✓

A categorization string associated with the rendition.

height

-

Typically used for 'image' renditions (expressed as pixels). SHOULD be present if kind = cmis:thumbnail.

width

-

Typically used for 'image' renditions (expressed as pixels). SHOULD be present if kind = cmis:thumbnail.

renditionDocumentId

-

If specified, then the rendition can also be accessed as a document object in the CMIS services. If not set, then the rendition can only be accessed via the rendition services. Referential integrity of this ID is repository-specific.


For more information, please refer to the CMIS Standard and the MIME media types.

Top

6.2 Rendition Services

Rendition services are triggered whenever a CRUD event occurs in the repository. They implement the RenditionService abstract class, which contains the executeCreate, executeUpdate, executeDelete, and executeMove methods.

executeCreate

Initiates creation of one or more renditions after a repository object is created.

  • Input

    Expects the following parameters:

    Table 6.2. executeCreate Parameters

    Input Parameter

    Data Type

    Description

    -

    ObjectData

    Object data.

    fsRootLocation

    string

    Same as the contentservices.repository.content.filelocation parameter in the backbase.properties file.


  • Output

    Returns the following value:

    Table 6.3. executeCreate Returns

    Data Type

6.3 Thumbnail Rendition Engine

Content Services ships with the thumbnail rendition engine that creates thumbnail renditions of repository objects:

The thumbnail size, default thumbnail directory, and default thumbnail image are specified in the bb-contentservices-repository-rendition.xml file, as shown below. 

<bean name="thumbnailRenditionEngine"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.engine.impl.ThumbnailRenditionEngine">
    <constructor-arg value=".renditions"/>
    <property name="folderImg" value="images/folderImg.jpeg"/>
</bean>
<bean name="thumbnailRenditionService100"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.service.impl.ThumbnailRenditionService">
    <constructor-arg ref="thumbnailRenditionEngine"/>
    <property name="formats">
        <list>
            <value>100</value>
        </list>
    </property>
    <property name="enabled" value="true"/>
</bean>

<bean name="renditionServiceManager"
      class="com.backbase.portal.contentservices.rendition.RenditionServiceManager">
    <constructor-arg>
        <list>
            <ref bean="thumbnailRenditionService100"/>
        </list>
    </constructor-arg>
</bean>

The location of the renditions folder. The path is relative to the object location in the repository. For instance, if the example.jpg file resides in the images folder, the engine specified above will store the thumbnail rendition in images/.renditions.

The folder thumbnail.

The thumbnail size in pixels.

7.1 Content Services Properties

The Content Services properties are stored in the backbase.properties file, the general configuration file of the Backbase Portal modules. For more information, see Content Services Settings.

Top

7.2 Importers

Importer configurations are dynamic: you can add, edit or remove configurations at runtime. Each external source needs a separate configuration file: manipulate configuration files with a WebDAV client like BitKinex. For more information, see Enabling WebDAV.

Warning

Do not edit configurations directly on the host file system, but use a WebDAV or CMIS client instead. The repository is not able to monitor these revisions and the repository metadata can become corrupted.

Importer configurations for RSS and Atom feeds reside in the importers/feed folder of configurationRepository, for CMIS in the importers/cmis folder. For more information, see Feed Importers.

Feed Importers

The following table shows the properties you can use in an importer configuration for RSS and Atom feeds:

Table 7.1. Importer Configuration Properties

Property

Mandatory

Description

id

✓

A unique identifier for the configuration.

group

✓

A unique identifier for a group of configurations.

description

-

An optional description of the configuration.

targetRepositoryId

✓

The name of the repository storing imported feeds, i.e. the value of the repository cmis:repositoryName property.

targetFolderPath

✓

The folder storing imported feeds in the repository specified by targetRepositoryId.

✓

The URL of the feed.

✓

The encoding of the feed.


Note

Configuration files must have a .properties extension.

Example

This is an example of an RSS feed configuration:

id=myFeedImporter
group=feedgroup
description=some_description
targetRepositoryId=contentRepository
targetFolderPath=/myfeeds
remoteLocation=http://www.host.com/feeds/rss/general.rss
defaultEncoding=utf-8
