7.3 Importer Jobs

Content Services uses Quartz Scheduler to automatically run importer jobs.

Job configurations reside in the scheduler/jobs folder of configurationRepository. Add more locations in the META-INF/spring/bb-contentservices-repository-importer-scheduler.xml file in WEB-INF/lib/repository-5.3.0.0.jar in the unpacked WAR file of Content Services. Use this syntax: 

<list>
    <value>/scheduler/jobs</value>
    <value>another_location</value>
</list>
Enabling Quartz Scheduler

Content Services uses Quartz to schedule Importer Jobs. The scheduler is disabled by default. To activate it, open the backbase.properties file and add the following line to the file:

contentservices.repository.scheduler.enabled=true
Quartz Configuration

You can configure Quartz in the quartz.properties file located in WEB-INF/lib/repository-5.3.0.0.jar in the unpacked WAR file of Content Services. For more information, please refer to Quartz Configuration Reference.

This is an example of the Quartz configuration file:

org.quartz.scheduler.instanceName=ContentServicesImporterScheduler
org.quartz.scheduler.instanceId=AUTO
org.quartz.scheduler.skipUpdateCheck=true

org.quartz.threadPool.class=org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool
org.quartz.threadPool.threadCount=3
org.quartz.threadPool.threadPriority=5

org.quartz.jobStore.misfireThreshold=60000
org.quartz.jobStore.class=org.quartz.simpl.RAMJobStore
Importer Job Configurations

This is an example of an importer job configuration:

#this job runs the feedgroup importer configurations every 4 seconds
id=myJob1
jobGroup=feedgroup
cron=0/4 * * * * ?

The following table shows the keys you can use in an importer job configuration:

Table 7.3. Job Configuration Properties

Property

Description

id

A unique identifier for the job.

jobGroup

This property maps a job to a group of importers identified by the importer group property. The job runs all the importers in the group.

cron

Defines the interval at which an import job is triggered. For details of Cron syntax, please refer to Quartz 1.x Tutorials: crontrigger and Cron Expressions.


Top

7.4 Enabling WebDAV

Web-based Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV) is a set of methods based on the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaboration between users in editing and managing documents and files stored on World Wide Web servers. For more information, please refer to WebDAV Resources.

WebDAV access is disabled by default. To enable it, open the backbase.properties file and add the following line:

contentservices.repository.webdav.enabled=true

Restart the application server after editing the file.

You can access Content Services repositories with a WebDAV client like BitKinex, by mapping a network drive to the repository URL under Microsoft Windows Explorer, or by mounting the URL to your file system under Linux. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

Top

7.5 Cache-Control Header Configuration

HTTP Cache-Control Headers

Whenever Content Services sends a representation in response to a client request, it attaches HTTP headers specifying, among other things, the caching configuration for the representation. The image below shows a simple HTTP session:

The cache-control header specifies where a representation can be cached and for how long. Its syntax is as follows:

cache-control: cache-directive

The cache-directive is anything valid according to the W3C HTTP 1.1 Specification. Commonly used directives are public, private, and max-age.

Content Services Configuration

The default configuration sets max-age for the image MIME type to five minutes (300 seconds), and to 0 seconds for all other MIME types: in other words, images are cached for five minutes, and non-image files are not cached. One can override the default configurations and set exceptions for individual MIME types (like text, image or application) and sub-types (like text/html, image/jpeg and application/x-javascript).

Follow the steps below to override the pre-defined settings:

  1. Set a default configuration in the properties file

    Open the backbase.properties file and add the contentservices.contentservices.cache-control.default key to set the default caching configuration. All the ensuing keys are exceptions to this configuration.

    The default key accepts any directive valid according to the W3 HTTP 1.1 Specification. For example, the following default key caches all representations for ten minutes (600 seconds):

    contentservices.contentservices.cache-control.default=public; max-age=600

  2. List the MIME types and sub-types overriding the default configuration.

    Every MIME type or sub-type requires two keys: the first one to identify the MIME type, and the second one to specify the cache directive. The keys should conform to the following syntax:

    contentservices.cache-control.<index>.mime-type
contentservices.cache-control.<index>.cache-value

    <index> is an integer sequence number identifying the mime-type and the cache-value. The sequence number must be the same for both keys, is zero-based and must increment in steps of 1.

    MIME sub-types like text/html, application/x-java-applet or image/jpeg are more specific and match before MIME types like text, application and image.

    The following example sets a default configuration for the cache-control headers and adds exceptions for images and HTML files:

    contentservices.contentservices.cache-control.default=public; max-age=600
contentservices.cache-control.0.mime-type=image
contentservices.cache-control.0.cache-value=public; max-age=600
contentservices.cache-control.1.mime-type=image/jpeg
contentservices.cache-control.1.cache-value=public; max-age=300
contentservices.cache-control.2.mime-type=text/html
contentservices.cache-control.2.cache-value=public; max-age=900

    Overrides the default settings and caches all representations for 10 minutes.

    Images may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of ten minutes (max-age=600).

    JPEG images may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of five minutes (max-age=300). Note that this directive is more specific than the one above and matches first.

    HTML files may be cached by any cache (public) for a maximum of fifteen minutes (max-age=900).

    The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) keeps an updated list of MIME content types and sub-types on its website.

  3. Restart the application server to apply the configuration changes.

Top

7.6 JMX Interface

JMX Integration

Content Services, offers JMX access to the logback, Ehcache, and Hibernate MBean:

  • Ehcache MBean: exposes configuration parameters like timeToLiveSeconds, timeToIdleSeconds, maxEntriesLocalHeap, maxEntriesLocalDisk and memory-store eviction policy. The configuration can be changed dynamically with, for example, JConsole. This MBean also gives access to statistics about cache hits and misses, cache usage, and memory management.

  • Hibernate MBean: exposes statistics about, for instance, the number of open and closed sessions, cache usage, CRUD operations, and executed queries.

  • logback MBean: allows configuring logback from the default configuration file, a designated file or a URL, list loggers and modify logger levels.

You can add more MBeans through annotations or by reconfiguring the <context:mbean-export/> element. For more information, please refer to Spring JMX Reference.

Specifying the MBean Server

Java Management Extensions is configured to start an auto-scanning JMX exporter and connect to an existing MBean server. If no server is found, Java Management Extensions can start one. The Java Management Extensions server can in turn interface with applications like JConsole.

If no server is specified, the MBeanExporter tries to automatically detect a running MBeanServer. This works in environments with only one MBeanServer instance, but when multiple instances exist, you need to specify the instance with MBeanServer agentId.

To do so, edit the bb-contentservices-jmx.xml file in the contentservices/WEB-INF/classes/META-INF/spring folder within the unpacked contentservices-webapp-5.3.0.0.war file and modify it as follows:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<beans>
    <bean id="mbeanServer" class="org.springframework.jmx.support.MBeanServerFactoryBean">
        <!-- indicate to first look for a server -->
        <property name="locateExistingServerIfPossible" value="true"/>
        <!-- search for the MBeanServer instance with the given agentId -->
        <property name="agentId" value="<MBeanServer instance agentId"/>
    </bean>
    ...
</beans>

If the MBeanServer has a dynamic or unknown agentId that is retrieved through lookup methods, use factory-method as follows:

<beans>
    <bean id="exporter" class="org.springframework.jmx.export.MBeanExporter">
        <property name="server">
            <!-- Custom MBeanServerLocator -->
            <bean class="platform.package.MBeanServerLocator" factory-method="locateMBeanServer"/>
        </property>
    </bean>
    ...
</beans>

For more information, please refer to Spring JMX reference.

8 Glossary

C

Cache

A store of server responses that improves performance by avoiding unnecessary server requests.

Content Services sets the cache-control headers for served content items to limit the time the individual items are kept in the browser cache.

For more information, see Cache-Control Header Configuration.

Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS)

An open standard for content management systems and repositories.

Content Services implements parts of the CMIS standard.

I

Importer

A service that retrieves content from an external source. Importers can be actioned by Quartz jobs.

O

Object model

The Content Services hierarchy of repository objects and related properties.

The Content Services model implements and extends the CMIS object model. For more information, see CMIS Object Model.

Q

Query

A request for information retrieval to Content Services.

Content Services implements a subset of the query language specified in the CMIS Standard.

For more information, see CMIS Query.

R

Rendition

The alternative representation of a document, like the thumbnail preview of an image, or the PDF version of a text document.

In Content Services the creation of renditions is managed by rendition services that invoke a rendition engine, i.e. the piece of software actually carrying out the transformation.

For more information, see Renditions.

Repository

A storage of content items. Repositories are the highest-ranking objects in the Content Services object model.

For more information, see Overview.

V

Validator

A process that verifies that a requested CRUD operation conforms to some given rules before allowing the operation to be executed.

For more information, see Validators.

content:
1 Overview

Content Services is a content delivery platform provided as a Backbase Portal optional module. It provides repository capabilities and relies on a library of importers to harvest content from sources like CMIS repositories or RSS and Atom feeds.

The following figure shows the elements composing Content Services:

Repositories

Content Services implements the CMIS Standard and relies on three repositories to manage content and configuration files:

  • contentRepository stores content used by Backbase Portal, like images, text, and content harvested from remote sources. One can navigate this repository from the Content Browser in Backbase Portal Manager. For more information, see Architecture.

  • configurationRepository stores configuration files for Importers.

  • resourcesRepository stores Backbase Portal resources.

Interfaces

Content Services is accessible via the following interfaces:

  • CMIS interface: enables interaction with any of the three repositories (contentRepository, configurationRepository, and resourcesRepository) at a very low level, for example down to metadata. You can establish connections using a CMIS client such as CMIS Workbench, a REST client, or by implementing a Mashup Services custom data provider. For more information, see Paging, Filtering, and Sorting and Custom Data Provider.

  • WebDAV interface: allows to manipulate objects and folders in Content Services repositories. WebDAV clients such as BitKinex and WebDAV-enabled applications such as Adobe Dreamweaver CS5 provide both file system and editing support. For file system operations alone, a WebDAV-enabled file manager like Microsoft Windows Explorer is sufficient. For more information, see Mounting Repositories.

  • JMX interface: manages and monitors the content delivery service and is useful to configure and administer the Content Services server. For more information, see JMX Interface.

1 Overview

Mashup Services is an embedded module delivering remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter, and transform HTTP requests and responses.

This figure shows the workflow of requests and responses through Mashup Services:

The Mashup Services proxying, transformation, and caching features are tailored specifically for delivering content to Backbase Portal widgets:

  • Proxy

    The proxy service retrieves content from a remote data source and provides compliance to the same origin policy.

  • Transform

    The transform service filters and/or transforms external data. Mashup Services ships with a library of predefined filters, transformers, and data providers. For more information, see Pre-defined Elements.

  • Cache

    The cache service improves performance by storing remote server responses in a cache. This prevents unnecessarily frequent requests and responses. The cache service relies on Ehcache.

2 Configuration

2.1. Mashup Services Properties
2.2. Proxy Configuration File
2.2.1. Pre-defined Elements
2.2.2. Proxy Service Configuration
2.3. Spring MBeans
2.4. Profiler Configuration

The following table lists the configuration files for Mashup Services:

Table 2.1. Mashup Services Configuration Files

Default Name

Description

backbase.properties

The Backbase Portal main configuration file.

Set its location in an environment entry with the JNDI binding name backbase/config as explained in How to Set an Environment Entry.

For a list of all available properties, see Mashup Services Properties.

ptc-config.xml

The proxy configuration file. Define here pipes and caches.

Set its location in the ptc.configfile.location property in the backbase.properties file mentioned above.

For more information of configuring caches and pipes, see Proxy Configuration File.

filename.properties

Stores placeholders for values used in the ptc-config.xml file.

Set its location in a context parameter in the web.xml of the Backbase Portal Foundation or Mashup Services WAR file. The following example sets the file location to a folder on the file system:

<context-param>
    <param-name>com.backbase.portal.ptc.web.PROPERTIES_FILE</param-name>
    <param-value>file:/home/user/backbase/config/ptc-server.properties</param-value>
</context-param>

For more information, see Using Placeholders.

backbase-ptc.xml

Contains the MBeans for Mashup Services.

Set its location in the web.xml file in the WEB-INF folder in the Backbase Portal Foundation or Mashup Services WAR file. The web.xml file contains a context-param with the name contextConfigLocation. Add path/to/custom-backbase-ptc.xml to the value of this context parameter.

For more information, see Spring MBeans.


2.1 Mashup Services Properties

The backbase.properties file overrides the default settings for the different modules. For a list of all available properties, see Mashup Services Settings.

Top

2.2 Proxy Configuration File

The ptc-config.xml file is the main configuration of Mashup Services. To change its location or define additional proxy configuration files, see Configuration.

Top

2.2.1 Pre-defined Elements

The pre-defined ptc-config.xml file contains the following pre-defined elements:

  • mustachePipe — establishes a connection to a CMIS repository and formats the contents according to a Mustache template. It is required for ICE widgets. For more information, see Pre-defined Data-Providers and ICE.

  • rss — turns RSS files into HTML through an XSL transformation. For more information, see Pre-defined Response Transformers.

  • mustache-cache — stores requests going through mustachePipe. Publishing a content item to a different environment empties the mustache-cache. For more information, see Publishing.

  • defaultCache — applies to all other requests.

Top

2.2.2 Proxy Service Configuration

This section explains how to configure pipes, caches, transformers, data providers, and filters. For the complete XML tag reference, see Mashup Services XSD Reference.

Defining Pipes

Pipes apply to requests to data providers delivering content to Backbase Portal widgets.

  • named pipes have a name attribute. For example:

    <pipe name="RSS">
    <cache referenceId="cache1"/>
</pipe>

  • URL pipes have a url attribute. For example:

    <pipe <![CDATA[<pipe url="*.com">
    <cache id="defaultCache"/>
</pipe>

    URL pipes can also have multiple <url> child tags:

    <pipe>
    <url>
        <value>*.nl</value>
        <value>*.com</value>
    </url>
    ...
</pipe>

Mashup Services uses the first matching pipe and gives an error if it finds none.

You can use the asterisk as a wildcard character. For example, the following pipe indicates all requests:

<pipe url="*">

Note that the pipe above makes all subsequent pipes useless. It is recommended to use it only in testing environments, and not in production environments.

Defining Caches

One can define a cache as:

  • A child of the root element <proxy>, for example:

    <proxy>
    ...
    <cache id="cache1">
        <param name="timeToLiveSeconds" value="30"/>
        <param name="maxElementsInMemory" value="100000"/>
    </cache>
    ...
</proxy>

    The cache above can be referenced from pipes across the proxy configuration file, for example:

    <proxy>
    ...
    <pipe name="RSS">
        <cache referenceId="cache1"/>
        <request-transform>
            <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.PreferenceGadgetProxy"/>
        </request-transform>
    </pipe>
    ...
</proxy>

  • A child of a <pipe> element. For example:

    <pipe name="RSS">
    <cache id="cache2">
        <param name="timeToLiveSeconds" value="30"/>
        <param name="maxElementsInMemory" value="100000"/>
    </cache>
    <request-transform>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.PreferenceGadgetProxy"/>
    </request-transform>
</pipe>

    The cache above can only be referenced from within the pipe.

On receipt of a client request, Mashup Services attempts to retrieve the resource from its cache. If it can find it, it returns the resource to the client, otherwise it forwards the request through the proxy service to the remote data providers.

The cache key for a resource consists of one of the following:

  • The pipe name or the URL pattern that matches the pipe.

  • The URL of the remote resource without the query.

  • The pipe name or the URL pattern that matches the pipe.

  • The GET or POST parameters.

  • The HTTP headers. Mashup Services forwards a default list of request headers and returns a default list of response headers. For more information, see Pre-defined Request Transformers and Pre-defined Response Transformers.

Mashup Services ships with a number of pre-defined filters and transformers. These are listed in Pre-defined Elements.

Example

The following configuration file defines two pipes and two caches:

<proxy>
    <pipe name="RSS">
        <cache referenceId="cache1"/>
        <request-transform>
            <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.PreferenceGadgetProxy"/>
        </request-transform>
    </pipe>
    <pipe url="*">
        <cache referenceId="defaultCache"/>
        <request-filter>
            <filter class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.SpringAuthenticationRequestFilter">
                <param name="roles">
                    <value>ROLE_ADMIN</value>
                </param>
            </filter>
        </request-filter>
    </pipe>
    <cache id="cache1">
        <param name="timeToLiveSeconds" value="15"/>
    </cache>
    <cache id="defaultCache">
        <param name="memoryStoreEvictionPolicy" value="LRU"/>
        <param name="isOverflowToDisk" value="false"/>
        <param name="diskStorePath" value="c:/proxy"/>
        <param name="isEternal" value="false"/>
        <param name="timeToLiveSeconds" value="30"/>
        <param name="isDiskPersistent" value="true"/>
        <param name="diskExpiryThreadIntervalSeconds" value="10000"/>
        <param name="maxElementsOnDisk" value="100000"/>
        <param name="diskSpoolBufferSizeMB" value="30"/>
    </cache>
</proxy>

This element defines a pipe named RSS that applies the cache1 cache settings and the custom request transformer com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.PreferenceGadgetProxy to outgoing requests. For more information, see Customization.

This element defines a pipe for requests to all URLs, it applies the custom filter com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.SpringAuthenticationRequestFilter to outgoing requests and applies the defaultCache settings to the responses.

The cache1 cache stores requested content for fifteen seconds. This cache is only used for content going through the RSS pipe.

These are the default cache settings for all requested content.

Using Placeholders

You can define placeholders in property files and reference them from the ptc-config.xml configuration file. To define placeholders, create a .properties file and declare it in the web.xml file as explained in Configuration.

For example, you can define diskStorePath, a parameter of the <cache> tag, and set it to "c:/proxy":

diskStorePath="c:/proxy"

Edit the ptc-config.xml file and use the placeholder instead of a hard-coded value:

<cache id="someCache">
    ...
    <param name="diskStorePath" value=${diskStorePath}/>
    <param name="maxElementsOnDisk" value="100000"/>
    ...
</cache>

Note

All parameters in the ptc-config.xml file accept placeholders as values, except for class and id.

Top

2.3 Spring MBeans

Set the location of the configuration file in the web.xml file as explained in Configuration. You can find the default file in ptc-core-5.3.1.0.jar in the WEB-INF/lib folder in the unpacked WAR file. The following are the available MBeans:

  • ptc_requestHeadersToForward — the list of headers from the Mashup Services request to be forwarded. Headers that are not in this list will not be forwarded. The following listing shows the default definition:

    <util:list id="ptc_requestHeadersToForward">
    <value>Accept</value>
    <value>Accept-Charset</value>
    <value>Accept-Language</value>
    <value>Authorization</value>
    <value>Connection</value>
    <value>Content-MD5</value>
    <value>Expect</value>
    <value>From</value>
    <value>Host</value>
    <value>Pragma</value>
    <value>Range</value>
    <value>Referer</value>
    <value>TE</value>
    <value>Upgrade</value>
    <value>User-Agent</value>
    <value>X-Forwarded-For</value>
</util:list>

  • ptc_responseHeadersToForward — the list of headers from the remote resource response that will be forwarded when preparing the Mashup Services response. Headers that are not in this list will not be forwarded. The following listing shows the default definition:

    <util:list id="ptc_responseHeadersToForward">
    <value>Allow</value>
    <value>Content-Encoding</value>
    <value>Content-Language</value>
    <value>Content-Length</value>
    <value>Content-Location</value>
    <value>Content-Range</value>
    <value>Content-Type</value>
    <value>Date</value>
    <value>Expires</value>
    <value>Last-Modified</value>
    <value>Location</value>
    <value>Pragma</value>
    <value>Retry-After</value>
    <value>Server</value>
    <value>Trailer</value>
    <value>Transfer-Encoding</value>
    <value>Vary</value>
    <value>Warning</value>
    <value>WWW-Authenticate</value>
</util:list>

These MBeans define the global behavior. To define the requests and response headers for individual connections, see Configuration.

Top

2.4 Profiler Configuration

The Mashup Services Profiler is a process that relies on Apache log4j to gather information about the duration of content retrieval from remote sites. On the basis of such information, you can configure Mashup Services for optimal performance.

Enabling the Profiler

To enable the profiler, define a new profiler MBean in the applicationContext.xml Spring configuration file:

<bean id="simpleProfiler" class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.utils.profile.SimpleProfiler"/>

Redefine the ptc_responseProvider bean, as shown below:

<bean id="ptc_responseProvider"
class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.response.provider.processor.ProxyResponseProvider">
    <constructor-arg ref="ptc_rawResponseCacheAdapter"/>
    <property name="profiler" ref="simpleProfiler"/>
</bean>

3 Pre-defined Elements

3.1. Pre-defined Data-Providers
3.2. Pre-defined Request Transformers
3.3. Pre-defined Response Transformers
3.4. Pre-defined Filters

3.1 Pre-defined Data-Providers

Data-providers implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.DataProvider interface. Mashup Services ships a few pre-defined data-providers:

HttpDataProvider

The HTTP data-provider establishes a HTTP connection to an external server. It uses the com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.HttpDataProviderImpl Java class and is the default binding for <data-provider> configurations if no class attribute is specified.

HttpDataProvider uses the parameters listed in data-provider.

For example, the following configuration redirects all calls to www.google.com. If the test pipe is omitted in the URL, Mashup Services redirects to www.yahoo.com instead.

<proxy>
    <pipe name="test">
        <data-provider id="goToGoogle">
            <param name="hostname" value="google.com"/>
            <param name="port" value="80"/>
        </data-provider>
    </pipe>
    <pipe url="*">
        <data-provider id="goToYahoo">
            <param name="hostname" value="yahoo.com"/>
            <param name="port" value="80"/>
        </data-provider>
    </pipe>
</proxy>

You can test the pipe by pointing a browser to:

http://host:port/portalserver/proxy?pipe=test&url=http://www.backbase.com

The Google home page should appear.

Instead, pointing the browser to:

http://host:port/portalserver/proxy?url=http://www.backbase.com

redirects to the Yahoo homepage.

HttpDataProvider can authenticate to firewalls and establish secure connections to remote servers with either NTLM or basic authentication (i.e. by providing a user name and a password). To enable authentication, set the authenticate parameter to true, and provide the domain, username, and password parameters:

  • domain: the domain controller from which the end-user credentials can be retrieved.

  • username: the user name to use for HTTP proxy server authentication.

  • password: the password for server authentication. This is required if the server uses basic authentication.

The following example establishes a connection to secureserver.com through a firewall with address 192.168.45.45, and provides credentials for basic authentication:

<pipe name="AuthenticationTest">
    <data-provider id="goToFirewalledServer">
        <param name="hostname" value="secureserver.com"/>
        <param name="authenticate" value="true"/>
        <param name="domain" value="192.168.45.45"/>
        <param name="username" value="username"/>
        <param name="password" value="firewallpassword"/>
        <param name="port" value="80"/>
    </data-provider>
</pipe>
MustacheRendererDataProvider

The Mustache renderer data-provider establishes a connection to a CMIS repository, makes the content available to ICE widgets, and applies Mustache templates. This data-provider is configured by default in the mustachePipe within the ptc-config.xml file and uses the com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.impl.MustacheRendererDataProvider Java class.

MustacheRendererDataProvider makes use of the following parameters:

  • cmisServerUrl: the URL of the CMIS server proxy.

    The default value is the Content Services URL as set in the ice-config.properties file, but can be replaced with the URL of any CMIS server.

  • repositoryId: the id of the repository storing the content. In Content Services, this is contentRepository.

  • username: the user name for the CMIS server.

  • password: the password for the CMIS server.

  • portalServerUrl: the URL of Backbase Portal Foundation.

For an example usage of MustacheRendererDataProvider, look at the ptc-config.xml in your Backbase Portal Foundation installation.

MustacheRendererDataProvider applies the template specified in the widget templateUrl property. For more information, see Content Template.

Top

3.2 Pre-defined Request Transformers

Mashup Services ships with the following pre-defined request transformers:

HeadersRequestTransformer

This transformer modifies the following list of request headers that Mashup Services forwards by default. The default list is specified in the ptc_requestHeadersToForward bean in the the file declared after classpath:backbase-ptc.xml in the list of Spring configuration files. For more information, see Spring MBeans. These are the possible values:

  • Accept

  • Accept-Charset

  • Accept-Encoding

  • Accept-Language

  • Authorization

  • Connection

  • Content-MD5

  • Expect

  • From

  • Host

  • Pragma

  • Range

  • Referer

  • TE

  • Upgrade

  • User-Agent

  • X-Forwarded-For

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.HeadersRequestTransformer request transformer accepts the following parameters:

  • onlyTheseHeadersToRequest: the values defined for this parameter will replace the default list of forwarded headers.

  • addHeadersToRequest: the values defined for this parameter will be added to the default list of forwarded headers.

  • blockHeadersFromRequest: the values defined for this parameter will be excluded from the default list of forwarded headers.

All three parameters are optional, and all accept * as wildcard. If none are specified, the request is not altered. The order of parameter processing is onlyTheseHeadersToRequest, addHeadersToRequest, and blockHeadersFromRequest.

The following example of a ptc-config.xml HeadersRequestTransformer onlyTheseHeadersToRequest definition only forwards headers containing a dash:

<request-transform>
   <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.HeadersRequestTransformer">
        <param name="onlyTheseHeadersFromRequest">
            <value>*-*</value>
        </param>
    </transform>
</request-transform>

The following example of a ptc-config.xml HeadersRequestTransformer addHeadersToRequest definition adds the cookie header to the default list:

<request-transform>
   <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.HeadersRequestTransformer">
        <param name="addHeadersToRequest">
            <value>cookie</value>
        </param>
    </transform>
</request-transform>

The following example of a ptc-config.xml HeadersRequestTransformer blockHeadersFromRequest definition excludes accept-encoding and accept-charset:

<request-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.HeadersRequestTransformer">
        <param name="blockHeadersFromRequest">
            <value>accept-encoding</value>
            <value>accept-charset</value>
        </param>
    </transform>
</request-transform>
SetHeaderRequestTransformer

This transformer modifies the request headers that Mashup Services forwards according to the settings in the configuration file. The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.SetHeaderRequestTransformer request transformer accepts any parameter whose name and value will be, respectively, the new header name and value. For example:

<request-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.SetHeaderRequestTransformer">
        <param name="myFirstHeader" value="myFirstHeaderValue" />
        <param name="mySecondHeader">
            <value>mySecondHeaderFirstValue</value>
            <value>mySecondHeaderSecondValue</value>
        </param>
        <param name="Cookie" value="someCookieValue" />
        <param name="Accept-Charset" value="ISO-8859-1" />
    </transform>
</request-transform>

MethodTransformer

This transformer changes the request type GET to POST, and vice versa.

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.MethodTransformer request transformer accepts the following parameter:

  • method: specifies the request type, either GET or POST.

The following example of a ptc-config.xml MethodTransformer definition changes the request from GET to POST:

<request-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.MethodTransformer">
        <param name="method" value="POST" />
    </transform>
</request-transform>
MoveToInternalPostParamsTransformer

This transformer is used to prevent POST parameters from reaching the remote server. The blocked parameters are stored as internal Mashup Services parameters and can be used in response transformations. For more information, see XSLTTransformer.

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.MoveToInternalPostParamsTransformer request transformer accepts the following parameter:

  • parametersToMove: the blocked parameters - you can specify multiple values.

The following example of a ptc-config.xml MoveToInternalPostParamsTransformer definition blocks all parameters starting with internal_ and the parameter parameter1:

<request-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.MoveToInternalPostParamsTransformer">
        <param name="parametersToMove">
            <value>internal_*</value>
            <value>parameter1</value>
        </param>
    </transform>
</request-transform>
UrlTransformer

This transformer overwrites the url parameter specified client-side.

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.UrlTransformer request transformer accepts the following parameter:

  • url: the requested location.

The following is an example of a ptc-config.xml UrlTransformer definition:

<request-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.UrlTransformer">
        <param name="url" value="http://www.backbase.com"/>
    </transform>
</request-transform>

Top

3.3 Pre-defined Response Transformers

Mashup Services ships with the following pre-defined response transformers:

ContentTypeResponseTransformer

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.ContentTypeResponseTransformer response transformer is used to set the Content-Type header in the response. It accepts the following parameters, all of which are converted to name/value pairs:

  • charset: specifies the encoding.

  • contentType: specifies the type of the returned content.

Example of a content type response transformer configuration in combination with a (prior) XSLT response transformer:

<pipe name="xslt">
    <response-transform>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.XSLTTransformer">
            <param name="xsltFile" value="/xslt/cdcatalog.xsl"/>
        </transform>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.ContentTypeResponseTransformer">
            <param name="charset" value="UTF-8"/>
            <param name="contentType" value="text/html"/>
        </transform>
    </response-transform>
</pipe>
DecompressResponseTransformer

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.DecompressResponseTransformer response transformer decompresses gzip and deflate responses.

Example of a decompress response transformer configuration in combination with a (prior) headers request transformer:

<pipe name="decompress">
    <request-transform>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.HeadersRequestTransformer">
            <param name="addHeadersToRequest" value="contentType" />
        </transform>
    </request-transform>
    <response-transform>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.DecompressResponseTransformer" />
    </response-transform>
</pipe>
HeadersResponseTransformer

This transformer modifies the following predefined list of response headers that Mashup Services returns by default:

  • Allow

  • Content-Encoding

  • Content-Language

  • Content-Length

  • Content-Location

  • Content-Range

  • Content-Type

  • Date

  • Expires

  • Last-Modified

  • Location

  • Pragma

  • Retry-After

  • Server

  • Trailer

  • Transfer-Encoding

  • Vary

  • Warning

  • WWW-Authenticate

The HeadersResponseTransformer response transformer accepts the following parameters:

  • onlyTheseHeadersToResponse: this parameter forwards only the headers specified as values. The default list of forwarded headers will be overwritten.

  • addHeadersToResponse: this parameter adds the specified headers from the remote request to the response sent to the client.

  • blockHeadersFromResponse: this parameter removes the specified parameters from the response to the client.

All three parameters are optional, and all accept * as a wildcard. If none are specified, the response is not altered. The order of parameter processing is onlyTheseHeadersToResponse, addHeadersToResponse, and blockHeadersFromResponse.

SetHeaderResponseTransformer

This transformer modifies the response headers that Mashup Services returns according to the settings in the configuration file. The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.SetHeaderResponseTransformer response transformer accepts any parameter whose name and value will be, respectively, the new header name and value. For example:

<response-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.SetHeaderResponseTransformer">
        <param name="myFirstHeader" value="myFirstHeaderValue" />
        <param name="mySecondHeader">
            <value>mySecondHeaderFirstValue</value>
            <value>mySecondHeaderSecondValue</value>
        </param>
        <param name="Cache-Control" value="max-age=315360000" />
    </transform>
</response-transform>
StaticContentResponseTransformer

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.StaticContentResponseTransformer response transformer is used to serve a static response. Typically, it will be used in conjunction with the cache-miss-response tag. For more information, see cache-miss-response.

The StaticContentResponseTransformer response transformer accepts the following parameters:

  • resourceURL: path to a classpath resource or a web resource, which then becomes the body of the response. For a classpath resource, prefix the path with classpath:. For a web resource, prefix the path with either web: or /. resourceURL is a required setting with no default value.

  • resourceEncoding The response includes the Content-Type header. resourceEncoding is an optional setting with a default value of mutableProxyResponse.getEncoding().

  • mimeType: the MIME Type sent as part of the Content-Type header. mimeType is an optional setting with a default value of text/html.

  • statusCode: the HTTP status code of the response. statusCode is an optional setting with a default value of 200.

Example of a static content response transformer configuration:

<pipe name="cacheMissReponse">
    <cache referenceId="primaryCache"/>
    <cache-miss-response>
        <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.StaticContentResponseTransformer">
            <param name="resourceURL" value="/static/cacheMissReponse/cacheMissReponse.html"/>
            <param name="resourceEncoding" value="UTF-8"/>
            <param name="contentType" value="text/html"/>
        </transform>
    </cache-miss-response>
</pipe>
XSLTTransformer

The com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.XSLTTransformer response transformer accepts the following parameters, all of which are converted to name/value pairs:

  • xsltFile: the XSLT file location using internal Mashup Services parameters or in configuration. The transformation will receive all parameters from the request and from the configuration file. The internal parameter definition has precedence. Specify the location of the XSLT file as follows:

    • classpath:/xslt/weather.xsl: to retrieve the file from the classpath.

    • /xslt/weather.xsl: to retrieve the file from the servlet context.

    • http://server/xslt/weather.xsl: to retrieve the file from a remote server.

  • cacheXSLFile: whether the XSLT file should be cached locally. This parameter is necessary because the XSLT file can be recuperated from other servers. This parameter is optional.

  • cacheTimeToLive: the number of second that the XSLT file should be cached. This parameter is optional.

  • customXSLTParam: any name/value pair for use by the XSLT.

Example of an XSLT response transformer configuration: 

<response-transform>
    <transform class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.impl.XSLTTransformer">
        <param name="xsltFile" value="/xslt/weather.xsl"/>
        <param name="cacheXSLFile" value="true"/>
        <param name="cacheTimeToLive" value="86400"/>
        <param name="xsltParam1" value="xsltParam1Value"/>
        <param name="xsltParam2" value="xsltParam2Value"/>
        <param name="xsltParam3" value="xsltParam3Value"/>
    </transform>
</response-transform>

Top

3.4 Pre-defined Filters

Mashup Services ships with the following pre-defined request filters:

BlockAllowRequestFilter

The request filter com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.impl.AllowDenyRequestFilter accepts the following parameters:

  • block: a list of URL patterns for which matching requests will be blocked.

  • allow: a list of URL patterns for which matching requests will be allowed to access the system.

  • prioritizeAllowed: a boolean value (true or false) that specifies if the allowed patterns have priority or not. It is used to decide whether to allow or block a request if it is matched by both an allow and a block pattern. The default value is false: if a resource is matched both by a block pattern and an allow pattern, it will be blocked.

The following ptc-config.xml filter definition allows all requests except those from .com and .org domains:

<request-filter>
    <filter class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.impl.AllowDenyRequestFilter">
        <param name="allow">
            <value>*</value>
        </param>
        <param name="deny">
            <value>*.com</value>
            <value>*.org</value>
        </param>
        <param name="prioritizeAllowed" value="false"/>
    </filter>
</request-filter>

Top

subnames.content:
4 Customization

4.1. Custom Filters
4.2. Custom Data Provider
4.3. Custom Transformers

4.1 Custom Filters

Implement custom filters as follows:

  • Request filter: either implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.RequestFilter interface or extend the com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.request.AbstractRequestFilter. Extending it is recommended because it provides implementations with filter parameter methods.

  • Response filter: either implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.response.ResponseFilter interface or extend the com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.response.AbstractResponseFilter. Extending it is recommended because it provides implementations with filter parameter methods.

Implementing a custom request transformer depends on implementing the transform() method, as the following example shows:

import com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.AbstractResponseTransformer;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.context.MutableProxyContext;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.request.ProxyRequest;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.response.MutableProxyResponse;

public class HelloWorldResponseTransformer extends AbstractResponseTransformer {
    public void transform(MutableProxyContext mutableProxyContext, ProxyRequest proxyRequest, MutableProxyResponse proxyResponse) {
        proxyResponse.setBody("Hello World");
    }
}

For more information, see request-filter and response-filter.

Top

4.2 Custom Data Provider

The default data provider binding is com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.impl.HttpDataProviderImpl: it is designed to establish a HTTP connection with the data source, and supports setting request parameters for the following aspects of an HTTP connection:

  • Routing a connection through an HTTP proxy server.

  • Controlling the duration of a connection. The following code fragment shows an example of how to use data-provider to configure a connection to a data source through an HTTP proxy server:

    <data-provider id="dataProviderId1">
    <param name="hostname" value="localhost"/>
    <param name="port" value="8888"/>
    <param name="authenticate" value="true"/>
    <param name="username" value="username"/>
    <param name="password" value="password"/>
</data-provider>

The following is a list of parameters available to data-provider:

Table 4.1. Data-provider Parameters

Parameter

Data Type

Description

hostname

string

The remote server hostname.

port

integer

The remote server port.

excludeList

string

A list of blocked URLs. The * placeholder is allowed in URL patterns.

URLs matching this list must be accessed directly from Mashup Services.

connectionTimeout

integer

The remote connection timeout in seconds. The default is 60.

socketTimeout

integer

The timeout in seconds for communicating with the remote server (sending and receiving data) using an already established remote connection. The default is 60.

authenticate

boolean

Whether the remote server is authenticated. The default is false.

username

string

The user name for remote server authentication. Required when authenticate is set to true.

password

string

The password for remote server authentication. Required when authenticate is set to true and the server authenticates using the BASIC method.

domain

string

The domain controller from which the end-user credentials can be retrieved. This parameter is required when authenticate is set to true and the server authenticates using NTLM (NT LAN Manager).


For more information, see data-provider.

Custom implementations allow connections to any type of remote data sources. Parameter support for custom data-provider implementations depends on the particular implementation.

Creating Custom Data Providers

Follow these steps to create a custom data provider.

  1. Create a Java class

    This class should implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.DataProvider interface.

  2. Bind your Java class to a data provider

    Enter the class in the class attribute of the configuration of the data-provider. For example:

    <data-provider id="dataProviderId1" class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.MyDataProvider">
    [parameter_list]
</data-provider>

The following code fragment shows an empty custom implementation:

@Override
public class MyDataProvider implements DataProvider {
    public MutableProxyResponse executeRequest(
        DataProviderConfig dataProviderConfig,
        MutableProxyContext mutableProxyContext,
        ProxyRequest proxyRequest) throws IOException {

        // Custom code

    }
}

Top

4.3 Custom Transformers

Implement custom transformers as follows:

  • Request transformer: either implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.RequestTransformer interface or to extend the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.AbstractRequestTransformer. In general, the recommendation is to extend the AbstractRequestTransformer because it provides implementations for transformer parameters methods.

  • Response transformer: either implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.ResponseTransformer interface or to extend the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.AbstractResponseTransformer. In general, the recommendation is to extend the AbstractResponseTransformer because it provides implementations for transformer parameters methods.

As shown in the following example of a transformer that replaces the original body content, implementing a custom request transformer depends on implementing the transform() method:

import com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.AbstractResponseTransformer;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.context.MutableProxyContext;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.request.ProxyRequest;
import com.backbase.portal.ptc.response.MutableProxyResponse;

public class HelloWorldResponseTransformer extends AbstractResponseTransformer {
    public void transform(MutableProxyContext mutableProxyContext, ProxyRequest proxyRequest, MutableProxyResponse proxyResponse) {
        proxyResponse.setBody("Hello World");
    }
}

For more information, see request-transform and response-transform.

Top

5 Glossary

C

Cache

A store of server responses that improves performance by avoiding unnecessary server requests.

The Mashup Services caching service relies on Ehcache. One can define caches in the proxy configuration file with the <cache> element. For more information, see Proxy Configuration File.

D

Data provider

A connection to a remote server.

Data providers implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.DataProvider interface. One can define caches in the proxy configuration file with the <data-provider> element.

For more information, see Proxy Configuration File.

F

Filter

A service that processes requests and responses according to given URL patterns.

Filters implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.RequestFilter and com.backbase.portal.ptc.filter.ResponseFilter interfaces.

One can define filters in the proxy configuration file with the <request-filter> and <response-filter> elements.

For more information, see Proxy Configuration File.

P

Pipe

A sequence of one or more filters, transformers, caches, and data providers.

One can define pipes in the proxy configuration file with the <pipe> and <response-filter> elements.

For more information, see Proxy Configuration File.

Placeholder

A value stored in a .properties file that can be referenced from the ptc-config.xml file.

For more information, see Using Placeholders.

Profiler

A process that relies on Apache log4j to gather information about the duration of content retrieval from remote sites.

For more information, see Profiler Configuration.

T

Transformer

A service that modifies requests or responses:

  • Request transformers modify requests according to HTTP header patterns. They implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.request.RequestTransformer interface.

    One can define request transformers with the <request-transform> element.

  • Response transformers modify requests according to ?. They implement the com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.ResponseTransformer interface.

    One can define response transformers with the <response-transform> element.

For more information, see Proxy Configuration File.

content:
1 Overview

Mashup Services is an embedded module delivering remote content to Backbase Portal widgets. It acts as a proxy and allows to cache, filter, and transform HTTP requests and responses.

This figure shows the workflow of requests and responses through Mashup Services:

The Mashup Services proxying, transformation, and caching features are tailored specifically for delivering content to Backbase Portal widgets:

  • Proxy

    The proxy service retrieves content from a remote data source and provides compliance to the same origin policy.

  • Transform

    The transform service filters and/or transforms external data. Mashup Services ships with a library of predefined filters, transformers, and data providers. For more information, see Pre-defined Elements.

  • Cache

    The cache service improves performance by storing remote server responses in a cache. This prevents unnecessarily frequent requests and responses. The cache service relies on Ehcache.

1 REST Interface

1.1. Portals
1.2. Pages
1.3. Containers
1.4. Widgets
1.5. Links
1.6. Users
1.7. Groups
1.8. Templates
1.9. Catalog
1.10. Tags
1.11. AuditEvents
1.12. Caches
1.13. URL Modifiers
1.14. HTTP Status Codes

You can manipulate objects through the REST interface with GET, PUT, POST, and DELETE calls on the object URI. Backbase Portal Foundation returns an HTTP status code after each call.

If Audit Trails is enabled, it logs all CRUD successful operations made in the editorial environment. For more information, see Architecture.

The following topics list the objects, their URI, the applicable HTTP methods and a description of the expected responses. The last topics describe these other aspects of the REST interface:

  • URL parameters, see URL Modifiers

  • HTTP status codes, see HTTP Status Codes

For an overview of the available REST clients, see Third-party Tools.

For more information, please refer to Wikipedia - RESTful.

1.1 Portals

This object has the following REST interface:

Table 1.1. Portal REST

URI

Method

Description

/portals

GET

Returns the list of portals without children. If you want the children of a portal, request the portal XML directly: /portals/[portal_name].xml.

POST

Creates a portal according to the XML code included in the call. The XML code must conform to portal. If successful, the call redirects to the new portal.

PUT

Updates one or more portals according to the XML code included in the call. The XML code must conform to portals. Returns whether the action was successful.

/portals/[portal_name]

GET

Redirects to the default landing page of the specified portal: /[portal_name]/pages/[home].

PUT

Updates the specified portal according to the XML code included in the call. The XML code must conform to portal. Some elements can only be changed by an administrator. It is not possible to update the following elements: contextItemName, type, createdTimestamp, lastModifiedTimestamp. Returns whether the action was successful.

DELETE

1.13 URL Modifiers

The following table lists the URL modifiers. For more information, see URL Modifiers.

Table 1.13. URL Modifiers

Modifier

Description

f

Filter objects by their fields or properties.

ps

Page size. Defines the number of results on a page. On the /auditevents URI, ?ps=-1 shows all results. The default page size varies per object, see Controller Properties.

of

Page number (offset): the first result number in the response. The default is 0, which returns the first result. You can adjust the default in a configuration file, see Controller Properties.

s

Sorts the results in ascending order (asc) or in descending order (desc).

pc

Whether the results should include the children of objects. The default is true. You can adjust the default in a configuration file, see Controller Properties.

depth

The number of children levels. The numbering is one-based. The default is 0, which returns all children. The default for pages is 1, which returns no children. You can adjust these defaults in a configuration file, see Controller Properties.

type

The tagType of a tag to be deleted. If omitted, it defaults to "regular".

context

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made on objects in the specified portal. It expects the name of a portal.

user

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made by the specified users. It expects a list username of users separated by logical OR, i.e. ||.

item

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made on the specified item. It expects the name of an item.

itemTitle

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made on the item with the specified itemTitle. It expects the Title of an item. Note that the value is case-insensitive.

itemtype

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made on the specified item type. It expects one or more of the following values:

  • PORTAL

  • PAGE

  • CONTAINER

  • WIDGET

  • CATALOG

  • TEMPLATE

  • LINK

Multiple values must be comma-separated.

from

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made after the specified date. It expects a date in yyyymmdd format.

to

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls made before the specified date. It expects a date in yyyymmdd format.

action

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, returns records of REST calls of the specified type. It expects one or more of the following values:

  • CREATE

  • UPDATE

  • DELETE

Multiple values must be comma-separated.

dates

Only applies to the /auditevents URI. If Audit Trails is enabled, diplays or hides <auditDates>, i.e. a list of dates on which audit events were recorded. If set to true or omitted, <auditDates> are displayed. Otherwise, they are hidden.

1.14 HTTP Status Codes

The following table shows HTTP status and error codes returned by the REST interface. For more information, please refer to Wikipedia - HTTP status codes.

Table 1.15. HTTP Status Codes

Code

Description

200 Ok

The request was successful. The response includes the requested object. This status code applies to GET methods.

201 Created

The request was successful and a new object was created. The response includes the created object. This status code applies to POST methods.

204 No content

The request was successful, but there was no need to return an entity body in the response. This status code applies to PUT and DELETE methods.

302 Found

The requested resource resides temporarily under a different URI. This status code applies to PUT, POST, DELETE and GET requests made by anonymous users on URIs requiring authentication. For an overview of the different user profiles, see Authentication and Authorization.

400 Bad Request

Bad syntax of the request. This status code applies to POST and PUT requests. For example when the attached XML does not conform to the XSD Reference.

403 Forbidden

The request has failed. The server understood the request, but is refusing to fulfill it. This status code applies to PUT, POST and DELETE requests made by users with insufficient rights. For an overview of the different user profiles, see Authentication and Authorization.

404 Not Found

The request has failed. The server has not found anything matching the request URI. This status code applies to GET, PUT, POST and DELETE requests made to non-existing objects or made by users with insufficient rights. For an overview of the different user profiles, see Authentication and Authorization.

generatedUrl

String Part

Description

Whether the property can only be modified from within Backbase Portal Manager. Acceptable values are:

If omitted, the property can be modified both within and outside Backbase Portal Manager.

role

The role needed to modify the property. Acceptable values are:

  • admin: users with ADMIN role can modify the property.

  • manager: users with at least MANAGER role can modify the property.

  • user: users with at least USER role can modify the property.

What input control is displayed in the Settings tab. Accepted values are:

  • text-input: displays a text field.

  • checkbox: displays a boolean.

  • select-one: displays a drop-down menu. The values for the drop-down menu are taken from a list of <g:enumeration> elements in a g:preference in the object definition. For more information, see preference.

Defaults to text-input.


For example, the following string shows a property as a text area modifiable by users with MANAGER role:

manager,text-input

3.1. Backbase Portal Foundation
3.2. Content Services

3.5. Startup Logging

Backbase Portal returns log messages of different logging levels:

  • Trace — low priority developer log

  • Debug — low priority developer log

  • Info — medium priority information log

  • Warn — medium priority warning log

  • Error — high priority error has occurred

  • Fatal — critical priority error has occurred

You can configure the location of the Logback configuration file in the backbase.properties file. For more information, see Configuration.

6.1. include
6.2. preferences

6.11. onPrefModified

Use the widget namespace in the Widget Definition to define preferences that the end-user can edit. The widget namespace URI is http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget, and its default prefix is g.

6.1 include

This element includes dynamic contents in the widget. Backbase Portal Client makes a GET or POST request to the specified URL with the preferences of this widget as parameters. The response, e.g. an RSS feed, is inserted into the widget content.

Attributes

This element has the following attributes:

Table 6.1. Include Attributes

Attribute

Mandatory

Description

src

-

The URL that will deliver the content.


Example
<g:include src="//docs.backbase.com/extranet/portal/get-rss-contents.jsp" />

Top

6.2 preferences

Define the preferences in the head of the Widget Definition. A preference is a name/value pair. Preferences are stored as properties in the Backbase Portal object model. The widget namespace allows you to define how the end-user can change the preference of a widget, e.g. a check box or a slider.

Attributes

This element has the following attributes:

Table 6.2. Preferences Attributes

Attribute

Mandatory

Description

requireSubmit

-

Whether the end-user has to confirm changes to the preferences. If true, save and cancel buttons appear when editing preferences. The default value is false.


Example
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
 xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <title>Your Local Weather</title>
        <g:preferences>
            <g:preference name="location" label="My location" type="text" />
            <g:preference name="unit" label="Temperature scale" type="select-one">
                <g:enumeration value="c" label="Celsius" />
                <g:enumeration value="f" label="Fahrenheit" />
                <g:enumeration value="k" label="Kelvin" />
            </g:preference>
        </g:preferences>
    </head>
    <body> ... </body>
</html>

Top

6.3 preference

A preference is a name/value pair. Preferences are stored as properties in the Backbase Portal object model. The widget namespace allows you to define how the end-user can change the preference of a widget, e.g. a check box or a drop-down box. You need to wrap a single preference in preferences.

Attributes

This element has the following attributes:

Table 6.3. Preference Attributes

Attribute

Mandatory

Description

name

✓

The name of the preference. The name has to be unique within the widget definition.

type

-

The type of interaction model for the preference. See Type. If omitted, the default type is text.

label

-

The text label of this preference when the end-user is editing preferences. If omitted, the name of the preference will be the label text.

You can add extra markup to the label as follows:

label="<span class='redlabel'>My location</span>"

default

-

The default value of the preference. The preference will have the default value in case the widget object has no corresponding property. When the user changes the preference, Backbase Portal Client will store changed value in the corresponding property in the widget object.

onchange

-

Specifies the JavaScript code that Backbase Portal Client will call when the user changes the preference.

min[a]

✓

The minimum value of the preference. You can specify a non-integer value as follows: 0.5.

max[a]

✓

The maximum value of the preference. You can specify a non-integer value as follows: 0.5.

step[a]

-

The step increment (positive number) from the minimum to the maximum value. You can specify a non-integer value as follows: 0.5. If omitted, the step is 1.

[a] These attributes only apply if the type is range.


Children

This element has the following child:

Table 6.4. Preference Children

Child

Mandatory

Description

enumeration

-

The values for preferences of type radio or select-one.


Type

Preference can have the following types:

Table 6.5. Type

Type

Rendered As

Description

text

<input type="text">

An entry field for string values.

This is the default type.

checkbox

<input type="checkbox">

A checkbox for boolean values.

hidden

-

This preference is not visible. The user cannot change it, but JavaScript code can.

readonly

<input type="text" disabled="disabled">

The user can view but not change this preference. JavaScript code can change it, but Backbase Portal Client does not persist changes to the server.

password

<input type="password">

An entry field for passwords.

radio

For each enumeration:

<input type="radio">

Radio buttons. Use enumeration to specify the options.

range

<select>
    <option>min</option>
    ...
    <option>max</option>
</select>

A drop-down box with values ranging from the min to the max attribute. The step attribute specifies the interval of values between min and max.

select-one

<select>
    <option>enum1</option>
    <option>enum2</option>
    ...
    <option>enumn</option>
</select>

A drop-down box with a limited set op options. Use enumeration to specify the options.

textarea

<textarea></textarea>

A text area for multiple string lines.


Example

This example shows a widget definition with preferences suitable for a customizable feed list:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
 "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
 xmlns:g="http://www.backbase.com/2008/gadget" xml:lang="en">
    <head>
        <title>Custom Feed</title>
        <g:preferences>
            <g:preference label="Feed URL" name="feed" type="text" />
            <g:preference label="Feed type" name="feedtype" type="radio" default="rss">
                <g:enumeration label="Atom" value="atom" />
                <g:enumeration label="RSS" value="rss" />
            </g:preference>
            <g:preference label="Show only headlines" name="onlyheadlines"
             type="checkbox" default="false" />
            <g:preference label="Maximum number of displayed feeds" name="maxnumber"
             type="range" min="1" max="10" />
            <g:preference label="The refresh rate in minutes" name="refreshrate"
             type="range" min="5" max="60" step="5" default="30" />
        </g:preferences>
    </head>
    <body> ... </body>
</html>

6.4 enumeration

The values for a preference of the type radio or select-one.

Attributes

This element has the following attributes:

Table 6.6. Enumeration Attributes

Attribute

Mandatory

Description

label

-

The text label of this enumeration when the end-user is editing preferences. If omitted, the value of the enumeration will be the label text.

value

✓

The value of the enumeration.


Example
<g:preference type="select-one" label="Temperature scale" name="unit">
    <g:enumeration value="c" label="Celsius" />
    <g:enumeration value="f" label="Fahrenheit" />
    <g:enumeration value="k" label="Kelvin" />
</g:preference>

6.5 model

This element includes lists of items returned by a query and renders them according to a Mustache template. For more information, please refer to Mustache.

Attributes

This element has the following attributes:

Table 6.7. Model Attributes

Attribute

Mandatory

Description

objectType

✓

The type of the objects being queried. Possible values are portal, page, container, widget, and link.

portalUid

-

The uuid of the portal. For more information, see itemType.

navLevel

-

The first link level to be displayed in the navigation tree. It only applies to queries on link items.

depth

-

The number of link levels to be returned. It only applies to queries on link items.

depth is one-based, so for example depth="3" returns all links in a portal up to two levels below the root level.


Children

This element has the following children:

Table 6.8. Preference Children

Child

Mandatory

Description

-

9.1 cache

The <cache> tag configures how Mashup Services caches the response from the remote server.

Parent

<proxy> or <pipe>.

If declared as a child of <proxy>, it can occur in multiple pipes.

A <pipe> can only contain one <cache>.

Attributes

The <cache> tag can have the following attributes:

Table 9.1. Cache Attributes

Attribute

Description

id

The <cache> unique identifier. If you declare the <cache> as a child of <proxy>, you can use id in multiple pipes to refer to the cache.

Either id or referenceId is mandatory.

referenceId

A reference to the id of another cache. You can only use this attribute when you declare a cache as child of a pipe and enter the id of another cache that you have declared as child of a proxy.

Either the id or the referenceId is mandatory.

enabled

Whether this cache is enabled. The value of this attribute is either true or false.

fallbackCacheId

A reference to the id of a <fallback-cache>.


Children

<param>. Can occur several times and form a parameter list. For more information, see <param>. The available parameters are listed below.

Parameters

The parameters supported by the default caching framework (Ehcache) are listed in the following table. For more information, please refer to Ehcache configuration.

Table 9.2. Cache Parameters

Parameter

Data Type

Description

maxElementsInMemory

integer

The maximum number of objects that will be loaded in memory before they are evicted. The default value is 100.

maxElementsOnDisk

integer

The maximum number of objects on the disk. The default value is 1000000. To define an unlimited number of objects, set the value to 0.

isEternal

boolean

Defines whether the elements in the cache never expire. The default value is false.

isOverflowToDisk

boolean

Defines whether data can overflow to disk when the limit of the in-memory cache is reached. The default value is false.

timeToIdleSeconds

long

This parameter defines one of the following:

  • The idle time before an element expires.

  • The default amount of time to idle for an element from its last accessed or modified date.

  • The maximum amount of time between accesses before an element expires.

The parameter is only needed if the element is not eternal. The default value is 3600. To define an infinite idle time, set the value to 0.

timeToLiveSeconds

long

This parameter defines one of the following:

  • The time to live before an element expires.

  • The default time to live for an element from its last accessed or modified date.

  • The maximum time between accesses before an element expires.

The parameter is only needed if the element is not eternal. The default value is 3600. To define an infinite idle time, set the value to 0.

diskPersistent

boolean

Defines whether to persist the cache to disk between restarts of the Java Virtual Machine. The default value is false.

diskExpiryThreadIntervalSeconds

long

Defines how often to run the disk store expiry thread. An interval longer than 120 seconds is recommended. The default value is 7200.

diskSpoolBufferSizeMB

integer

Defines the amount of memory to allocate to the write buffer. Writes are made to this area and then asynchronously written to disk. If out-of-memory errors are encountered, consider lowering the value. To improve disk store performance, consider increasing the value. Trace level logging in the disk store will show if backups are occurring. The default value is 30.

memoryStoreEvictionPolicy

string

The policy used to evict elements from the memory. The options include:

  • LRU — least recently used

  • LFU — least frequently used

  • FIFO — first in first out, the oldest element by creation time

The default value is LRU.

diskStorePath

string

The directory in which to create data and index files.

Note

You can use the user.home, user.dir, java.io.tmpdir, or ehcache.disk.store.dir Java system properties with the following syntax:

${java_system_property}

Example

This example shows the parameters and their default values for the default caching framework (Ehcache):

<cache id="myCacheId" fallbackCacheId="myFallbackCacheId">
    <param name="maxElementsInMemory" value="100000"/>
    <param name="memoryStoreEvictionPolicy" value="LRU"/>
    <param name="isOverflowToDisk" value="false"/>
    <param name="diskStorePath" value=""/>
    <param name="isEternal" value="false"/>
    <param name="isDiskPersistent" value="false"/>
    <param name="timeToLiveSeconds" value="3600"/>
    <param name="getTimeToIdleInSeconds" value="3600"/>
    <param name="diskExpiryThreadIntervalSeconds" value="7200"/>
    <param name="maxElementsOnDisk" value="10000000"/>
    <param name="diskSpoolBufferSizeMB" value="30"/>
</cache>

Top

Child

Description

Example

     class="com.backbase.portal.ptc.transform.response.impl.StaticContentResponseTransformer">

9.3 data-provider

The <data-provider> tag configures the connection to a remote server.

Parent

<proxy> or <pipe>.

If declared as a child of <proxy>, <data-provider> can occur in multiple pipes. A <pipe> can only contain one <data-provider>.

Attributes

The <data-provider> tag can have the following attributes:

Table 9.4. Data-provider Attributes

Attribute

Description

id

The <data-provider> unique identifier. If <data-provider> is a child of <proxy>, id refers to each <data-provider> occurrence in a pipe.

Either id or referenceId is mandatory.

referenceId

A reference to the id of another <data-provider>. You can only use this attribute when you declare this <data-provider> as the child of a pipe and enter the id of another <data-provider> that you have declared as the child of a <proxy>.

Either id or referenceId is mandatory.

enabled

Whether this <data-provider> is enabled. Possible values are true or false.

class

The fully qualified class name of a custom <data-provider> implementation. Enter the class name of a custom implementation to bind the <data-provider> to your class. The fully qualified class name prepends all the packages to the class name, e.g. com.backbase.portal.ptc.provider.impl.HttpDataProviderImpl. For more information, see Custom Data Provider.


Children

<param>. Can occur multiple times and form a parameter list. Available parameters for pre-defined implementations are listed below.

Parameters

These are the parameters supported in pre-defined implementations:

Table 9.5. Data-provider Parameters

Parameter

Data Type

Description

hostname

string

The remote server hostname.

port

integer

The remote server port.

excludeList

string

A list of blocked URLs. The * placeholder is allowed in URL patterns.

URLs matching this list must be accessed directly from Mashup Services.

connectionTimeout

integer

The remote connection timeout in seconds. The default is 60.

socketTimeout

integer

The timeout in seconds for communicating with the remote server (sending and receiving data) using an already established remote connection. The default is 60.

authenticate

boolean

Whether the remote server is authenticated. The default is false.

username

string

The user name for remote server authentication. Required when authenticate is set to true.

password

string

The password for remote server authentication. Required when authenticate is set to true and the server authenticates using the BASIC method.

domain

string

The domain controller from which the end-user credentials can be retrieved. This parameter is required when authenticate is set to true and the server authenticates using NTLM (NT LAN Manager).


Example

This example configures a HTTP connection to a remote server:

<data-provider id="dataProviderId1">
    <param name="hostname" value="example.com"/>
    <param name="port" value="8888"/>
    <param name="authenticate" value="true"/>
    <param name="username" value="myusername"/>
    <param name="password" value="mypassword"/>
</data-provider>

Top

9.3.1 param

The <param> tag is used in several tags to form a parameter list.

Attributes

Table 9.6. Param Attributes

Attribute

Description

The parameter value. Equivalent to the <value> child tag.

Example

This example shows a parameter with one value and a parameter with multiple values:

<param name="hosts">
    <value>first.example.com</value>
    <value>second.example.com</value>
    <value>third.example.com</value>
</param>

Parameters
